movie_review_blurb: The result is an absorbing and illuminating portrait of a composer whose popularity actually exceeded that of Wolfgang and Ludwig during his day.
No more important, or more beautifully filmed, documentary about Mozart's life and music has emerged from the Mozart Year 2006 than writer-director Phil Grabsky's In Search of Mozart.
By aspiring no higher than campy adulation, it ill serves the memory of the most storied opera diva of the last century.
You would be better off investing in the worthy EMI recording that serves as the soundtrack, or the home video of the 1992 Malfitano-Domingo production.
An operatic rarity worth catching even if you don't happen to be an opera fan.
At 140 minutes, The Age of Shadows is a film that peaks early and ends late. Still, there is an upside to this ponderousness.
Viewed as a cautionary tale about the dangers of hazing, Burning Sands dutifully does its job. As hard-hitting sociopolitical commentary, it falls short.
Despite the evidently esoteric subject matter, Grabham and Sharp provide enough stimuli to guide us from cynicism to curiosity - perhaps even captivation.
The film's combination of gloopy sentiment, macho horns-locking and recondite enzyme research isn't a winner; and the slushy music, by Andrea Guerra, has you begging for mercy.

Moore is marvellously indignant and confrontational (he tries to make a citizen's arrest of the AIG board), and dramatises moments of rebellion and fight-back with relish. But there's something self-righteous and teenage-lefty about his rhetoric.
Nobody beats [Jeunet] for sheer comic inventiveness and the speed with which he whips ideas into crazy reality. The only problem with his approach is that black humour clearly isn't enough for him.
I'm Gonna Explode never quite explodes but it sets up a potent, sometimes funny, opposition between domestic complacency and youthful rejection, and a slow-burning love story that draws you in.
It's a neat idea, of one life "standing-in" for another and starting afresh, but badly handled. It's a glum 79 minutes.
It's a long anti-climax, full of crunching but pointless fights between Wolverine (Hugh Jackman) and his brother Victor (Liev Schreiber). Wretched.
There isn't an original thought in the film, but it bounds along amusingly.

This grainy documentary that lets the Cockney hard men brag about violence, honour codes and the changed East End. Director Collins appeared with her sister Teena in Guy Ritchie's Snatch. That explains a lot.
De Niro, while initially expressionless, gives the film a heart. Barrymore and Beckinsale stay one-dimensionally cute. A weepie that wholly fails to make you weep.
It's an interesting story, more accessible to non-Trekkers than previous entries.

This Disney film is a hand-tooled, eight-cylinder charm offensive: the landscape is ravishingly shot, the songs are cute and the plot moves from slapstick to romance at a cracking pace. Your 13-year-old daughter will utterly love it.

This remake of George A Romero's 1973 movie is gross, bloody and savagely effective, with its palette of sickly browns and reds, and the nasty surprises that jump out of clapboard barns and innocent meadows.
An intelligently-written, smartly-handled study of laughter in the dark.
A sparkling new print of Howard Hawks's 1953 musical comedy, which paired Monroe and Russell at their spangled, curvaceous, lipsticky best.

Adams is perky and watchable and almost saves the film. But it's so dumb: how come the eventual proposal, supposedly set a few yards from the Dingle pub, seems to take place on the Cliffs of Moher, 75 miles away?
[A] breathtakingly clueless, misconceived, stupid, humourless, unexciting, dim, dumb farrago, the worst film I've seen in years.
It's directed with flair and energy, spirited, funny and charming.
From time to time, clever ideas rear their heads, but they soon return to the film's default setting of laddish japes.
There are some watchable 3D sequences in a boat on the rapids and a makeshift airplane, but it's pretty grim for anyone over six.
Never tell Hollywood action heroes in their 50s and 60s, that they're a bit past it.
At an uncertain time for heroes in America, there's no wonder it's packing 'em in.
The 8-12s will love it, but grown-ups may feel they've seen lots of it before (especially the caribou stampede, a shameless pinch from The Lion King.)
A sparkling moral tale about a small lie that ramifies out of control.
It's a 20-year story that absorbs and beguiles, despite the ugly subject matter.
The stars of this computerised epic are the Design and Art departments, who provide stunning landscapes, caves and kingdoms, and whose 3D magic is genuinely thrilling.
movie_title: Legend of the Guardians: The Owls of Ga'Hoole (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Despite everyone's efforts, Ramona comes across as an insufferably spoilt and attention-seeking little horror.
[Bunuel] remains as brilliantly in control of his own emotions as he does of the process of making the film.
Rogue One is better than [the prequels] by a long shot, but after the high bar set by last year's Episode VII - The Force Awakens, simply being better than the prequels isn't good enough anymore.
movie_title: Rogue One: A Star Wars Story (2016)

movie_review_blurb: The subject matter screams out for cleverness and depth, the sort of mind-bending twists and satisfying darkness that Poe himself would love. It finds them only in small doses.
Like punk rock or alternative comedy, it's a DIY pursuit that pits go-it-alone types against an industry machine, often breeding exciting but intensely idiosyncratic art in the process.
It's a big, bold, schizophrenic pageant that still manages to work on a surprising number of levels -- creative liberties and indulgences be damned.
movie_title: The Hobbit: The Battle of the Five Armies (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Creed stirs emotions with a strong yet artful hand.

From the iconic opening crawl through the wordless last frames of Star Wars: Episode VII - The Force Awakens, director J.J. Abrams steers pop-culture's most beloved sci-fi saga in an exhilarating new direction.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode VII - The Force Awakens (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Like Tarantino's best work, the film forces you to see and feel something on its own terms -- in this case, loyalty and identity unraveling under extremes.
The film nails both the malaise and creative vigor of Curtis' short, bruised and chillingly relatable life.
This neo-Western works splendidly as a self-contained tale of loyalty, loss and redemption, with polished turns from a smoldering Chris Pine and spunky Ben Foster.

The script contains enough core truths and grand philosophical concepts that no spoiler could touch them, such as the co-dependence of slavery and freedom, or the paradoxical way the future echoes and restates the past.

At best, Passengers is glib and cutesy in the face of otherwise serious themes. At worst, it's an argument that men can do whatever they want with the knowledge that things will always work out for them.
It's not exploitative or overtly political, and the violence is both sickening and sad. That's what makes it effective, but also impressive as a still-fresh take on a recent tragedy, messy as it is.

Improbably, the film vaults over most pitfalls of long-threatened sequels while evolving the delicately crafted world in the original. It's a more sober, mature film, but no less entertaining or provocative.
Here's hoping the inevitable Vol. 3 rebuilds some of the first film's heart, because Vol. 2 feels like hollow spectacle, however gorgeously rendered.

Sheridan has professed admiration for Clint Eastwood's towering anti-Western "Unforgiven" and dark-night-of-the-soul dramas from Michael Mann. Both are reference points for his adept mix of masculine posturing and wounded soul-searching.
When everything pulls in the same direction, as it does consistently in "The Last Jedi," it's like watching a mind-boggling clockwork click into a deft ballet.
It's uniquely satisfying popcorn entertainment, a triumphant trifecta of subject matter, talent and timing.
As things build toward the long, bloody and by-the-numbers (if ably staged) showdown, it's hard not to mourn for the film this could have been, considering the assemblage of talent.
The Poker House is one of the most personal, wounded films in years. That it is also one of the most confused reflects how deeply it springs from the psyche of its director.

The film is raucously funny during Saffron's professional and personal meltdowns, but the long scenes of repetitive jokes, the dreary reality-TV style and some very strange accents bring down the whole affair.
A red, digital countdown timer counts down the story's seemingly eternal 96 hours (and its 91 minutes of screen time).

Yesterday Was a Lie deals with some heady themes, and Brown strikes some nice notes on her character's frustrated journey, but the film is finally too disjointed and incomprehensible to be enjoyed as much else besides an exercise in style.
An involving new documentary by Hilari Scarl.

The compelling documentary Believe condenses the comedian's fascinating life into 105 minutes of interviews, archive material and -- most importantly to understanding any performer -- several decades of performance footage.
Anthony Quinn plays with impressive savagery and assurance as Zampano; and it is a mark of his quality that, for all the character's unmitigated brutality, he makes it seem touchingly helpless.
It achieves an effective balance between the ever-escalating action sequences that each successive Bond picture apparently demands, fresh use of charismatic talent, and nods to the legacy
The good news is that Eastwood does his thing to perfection, Adams provides the spunky cuteness, and Timberlake couldn't scrub his eager charm off with a Brillo pad if he tried.

Knuckleball! is more than enjoyable if you are a fan of the game of baseball. And while it wouldn't be an obvious win for the uninitiated, Wakefield and Dickey do not make it difficult for the viewer to cheer for them.
The movie successfully keeps you guessing throughout as the young woman's memories vividly flash by and the truth is that you'll still be guessing as the credits roll.
The many chases and ludicrous narrow escapes offer respectable doses of adrenaline.
Annoying flatness permeates Feast of Love, preventing characters from reaching convincing depths of expression.
The delightful Enchanted gives Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs a sweetly subversive spin.

Mr. Magorium's Wonder Emporium isn't the awful experience so many movie critics labeled it. Most of all, it's a pleasure to see the warm rapport Hoffman and Portman conjure in this sweet, short story.
Vaughn is a funny guy in the right vehicle. This isn't it.
Bee Movie is never an unpleasant experience, but it's never a particularly engaging or funny film either.
Dan In Real Life is neither bad nor particularly good. It's simply more disposable, soon to be forgotten, entertainment.
The unscary 30 Days of Night has shallow bite.
Depending upon your tolerance for cinema as meditation, this moody trek to the inevitable murder of the outlaw Jesse James may actually seem as long as its title. Yet there's much to admire.
movie_title: The Assassination of Jesse James by the Coward Robert Ford (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Hitman's performances outclass the film's video-game origins. These are credible characters, not video drones.
Across The Universe goes irretrievably off key thanks to thin, artificial storytelling and director Julie Taymor's hammer-handed approach to an already floundering script.
An attention-holding ride through rough country of both the physical and spiritual kind.

The Kingdom uses explosive current events as the starting point for a fictional film that strains to stir emotions, seemingly instill tolerance and be a bloody action flick. It's a manipulative, mannered film that often fails.
A contender for least funny comedy of the year.
Joel and Ethan Coen have a great catalog of films behind them, but they paint their masterpiece with No Country For Old Men.

Every character in The Nanny Diaries is ill-defined, including Johansson's floundering nanny. Exhibiting a dull to puzzled expression, Johansson gives a shapeless performance in an embarrassing misfire of a movie.
Superbad may not linger in the memory, but its often riotous comedy is engaging and the journeys that Evan, Seth and McLovin take are, believe or not, eventually heartfelt.
An irresistible rush of action and suspense, The Bourne Ultimatum also shows that a hellacious action movie need not be mindless.
A very bad dog of a movie.

While Sunshine echoes some previous films, especially 2001: A Space Odyssey and Alien, Danny Boyle imprints his distinctive mark. This visionary director from Manchester, England, may be on his way to being one of moviemaking's greats
For Simpsons fans, seeing Homer, Marge, Bart, Lisa and baby Maggie on a movie screen must be like watching old friends blown up to the size of Macy's Thanksgiving Day parade floats.
Another zesty foreign flick ground into American hamburger.
Hairspray opens on the upbeat with big-girl heroine Tracy Turnblad bopping down a Baltimore street. She's gotta dance. From there this frantic musical comedy rarely takes a breath.

A movie for younger children, especially girls, The Game Plan goes into overtime, surely taxing kids' attention. But parents looking for children's entertainment at the movies don't have all that much from which to choose.
An entertaining start for this new series.
A swoon of thwarted love, Atonement is missing something, the heartrending something that would make an otherwise gorgeous film a romance for the ages.
Some plot turns in The Kite Runner feel predictable and contrived, but there's nothing false about the film's overall redemptive flight.
A dryly funny and demented film featuring the most likable hit man you'd ever want to meet.
This year's Superhero Movie isn't as epically bad as last year's Epic Movie, but it does provide more evidence that the spoof genre is tapped out.
No one needs a telephoto lens to see what's coming in Shutter.
If the experience of the real-life MIT students who beat Las Vegas was as dreary as 21, what happened in Vegas should have stayed in Vegas.
If Doomsday was designed to be trash cinema, the filmmakers achieved their goal and then some.
Despite the stretch of adapting Horton's tale to a feature movie, Dr. Seuss' original story and the worlds he created, plus some particularly winning characters, put Horton Hears A Who! over the top.
movie_title: Dr. Seuss' Horton Hears a Who! (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Despite its often stagy stab at classic screwball comedy, Miss Pettigrew Lives for a Day eventually finds its feet.
movie_title: Miss Pettigrew Lives for a Day (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Unlike the many heist movies obsessed with high-tech gadgetry and beyond-human stunts, The Bank Job, in more ways than one, gets down and dirty.
Despite Christina Ricci's charming performance, Penelope is trapped in a twilight zone between fairy tales and play-it-safe romantic comedies.
A not-ready-for-primetime tale that should have stayed on the bench.
A wickedly entertaining blood feast.
movie_title: Sweeney Todd: The Demon Barber of Fleet Street (2007)

movie_review_blurb: A brilliant black comedy that successfully moves from character-driven shenanigans to suspenseful thriller.
Shaped from Cobain's own words, the film tells his story with care, in inventive style and without phony reverence or pretentious pronouncements.
It's easy to see what's coming, but the payoff is still touching. The Spiderwick Chronicles finds its magic.
Mike Joyce and Andy Rourke, the rhythm section in the Smiths, that influential '80s indie rock band from Manchester, England, give their account of Smiths history.
A goofy romantic comedy and a clumsy action-adventure collide at sea.
The Eye contains little worth seeing.
A sloppy, ugly splatter flick.

Such unflattering scenarios are common in movies about the rural South, but the melodramatic crescendos in Little Chenier don't play out smoothly or credibly. Heavy-handed storytelling undermines the film's good intentions and authentic locations.
Beautifully crafted and acted though There Will Be Blood is, Daniel Plainview remains an enigma. This and weak, reaching developments in the third act make the film a lesser epic.
This bucket's got a hole in it.
If Juno were cheese and macaroni, it would be among the most satisfying mac-and-cheese dishes ever conceived.
Not better than the real thing, but close.
In amusing, opinionated and sometimes moving style, Michael Moore points his accusing camera at health care in the United States.

The Last King of Scotland, fitting its brutal subject, is not an easy film. Yet in the realm of movies that depict seductive, evil men of power who easily smile as they kill, it's a bloodstained achievement.
Efficiently trimmed from a nearly 900-page novel, the latest Harry Potter film adaptation is an especially absorbing entry in the series.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Guillermo del Toro's Pan's Labyrinth brilliantly melds the realms of fairy tale and brutal 20th-century history. Beautiful, horrible and deeply affecting, it's the 21st century's first film masterpiece.
Notes on a Scandal bubbles with brilliant writing and acting. The arc of its great story rises like a monster from dark water.
Clint Eastwood, the director, achieves another milestone with Letters From Iwo Jima. Maybe only a filmmaker of his multi-Oscar-winning, all-American rank could stage such a brave project.

Simon Pegg gives it the old college try, but his character isn't worthy our cheers. Maybe Pegg should resurrect his most famous character, the resourceful, much funnier Shaun, and do battle with the zombies of London rather than the marathon runners of Lo
The stirring Freedom Writers earns a place alongside memorable earlier movies about inspirational teachers and their fortunate students.

A film for the fans, especially if you were one of those sonic youths venting steam at a guerrilla show in someone's basement, a VFW hall or club that condescended to present a hardcore show. For once-upon-a-time kids now irrevocably middle-aged, the kick
Stomp the Yard gives moviegoers rousing dance scenes, but otherwise stops short of its dramatic potential.
A bad movie only fans of deeply bad movies can love.
Reaches for inspiration but finds mediocrity.
Plenty charming and the theme of friendship and loyalty is beautifully illustrated.
A laugh-deprived misadventure.
The fight sequence is more tongue-in-cheek than glorification. That's fine, because Stallone and his cast earn enough points before the match to make Rocky VI a heartwarming winner.
Blood runs often in Blood Diamond, an often admirable action-drama that takes some wrong turns.
A simple story told in the most feverish extremes. Apocalypto is nightmare, morality play, triumph of human will and, most of all, virtuosic cinema.
The Fountain overflows with three centuries of gloom.
The film has moving moments, but it's also timid and tentative.
Scott's direction added to Washington and Patton's charm prevents the flawed Déjà Vu from being fatally ridiculous.
The best Bond yet.
Babel is skillful filmmaking, but the film's whole is less than its parts. After the drama ends, little has been learned.
This is Will Ferrell's Being John Malkovich or Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind, but not as good as either of those other comedies of the mind.
Ken Takakura's memorable performance, occasional light comedy and striking Chinese scenery don't keep Riding Alone for Thousands of Miles and its big message from being ponderous and affected.
movie_title: Riding Alone for Thousands of Miles (2006)

movie_review_blurb: The Santa Clause 3 strikes out.
movie_title: The Santa Clause 3: The Escape Clause (2006)

movie_review_blurb: So skillfully written, acted and mounted for the screen, The Queen is among the year's most accomplished films.
When it's not too far over the top or redundant, Transformers is a fun summer-movie ride.
Pedro Almodóvar gives Penelope Cruz a great woman's role that recalls the classic performances of Italian actress Anna Magnani.
Somewhere between a minstrel show and a lesser Jerry Lewis movie there's Norbit.
Willis' working-class hero gives the mayhem spunky soul and the human touch.

The script, which doesn't play cheap or obvious to children or adults, and the film's fluid animation and luxurious palette make Ratatouille one of this summer's high-water marks for viewers of any age.
It takes an annoying while for Evan Almighty to launch, but laughs, or at least chuckles, do come forth.
The new Nancy Drew isn't great but it is fun and, best of all, Emma Roberts breathes lively presence into this classic character.
Actors having a good time plus Soderbergh's style and lush Vegas imagery compensate for the plodding prelude to the heist.
Not enough wit for parents and not enough action and comedy for kids.
Clever and engaging, Mr. Brooks contains some of Kevin Costner's best work.
An unpleasant curiosity and train wreck of a movie that never completely sells its stage bound, feverish events.
Carice van Houten is a persuasive heroine -- beautiful, daring, wry and, when it counts, poignant.
Writer-director-co-star Adrienne Shelly and her talented co-workers serve many charming scenes in Waitress.
At its best, the low-budget Last Sin Eater achieves some powerful moments.
The film is slow in delivering its goods, but At World's End finally finds the mad fun and rousing action that fans expect.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: At Worlds End (2007)

movie_review_blurb: The Reaping's last-act adrenaline can't save it from the genre clichés that precede it.
This film from Russia about a child's dream of love and family is poignant and genuine enough to earn classic status.
Whatever negative things there are to say about Blades of Glory, it's still funny.
Exciting and affecting, The Last Mimzy is a great surprise. It's among this year's best films for families and anyone else who appreciates a great story well told.
Writer-director Florian Henckel von Donnersmarck is a master of tone and place.

Not winning the Oscar takes nothing away from Peter O'Toole's unforgettable performance as Maurice, a gifted, once devastatingly handsome man who, as the doleful lyrics of a recent Morrissey song state, falls in love even as he lies on his deathbed.

While writer-director Craig Brewer's Black Snake Moan isn't the film his earlier Hustle & Flow is, it's got its peculiar Southern Gothic appeal. Moan transcends its trashy, exploitative trappings, rising to a homey sort of salvation.
Ten-year-old best-supporting-actress Oscar nominee Abigail Breslin and 78-year-old James Garner easily steal this show.
Once all the blood and madness run out, The Number 23 is one of those disposable movies that so often fill the film industry's off season.
Amazing Grace may not accomplish the depth of poignancy inherent in its subject, but it's a steady effort.
A long, blood-splattered stunt of a movie, Grindhouse, may be something only critics and film nerds can love.
Despite being so false and slight, the movie entertains.
Such benign vampire behavior is a stretch, but Twilight gets away with its revisionism, creating something new and, of course, romantic.
The outcome of What Happens In Vegas is obvious, but the journey there is fun.
An exceptional cast, including child actress Isabelle Fuhrman, make Orphan a cut above.
The maestro of mayhem, Jerry Bruckheimer, does a kids movie.
An ugly, mean-spirited romantic comedy that lacks comedy and romance.
Sacha Baron Cohen's smiling and gregarious Borat, as opposed to his haughty and selfish Bruno, scores much higher on the likeability scale.
Hats off to the young cast and director David Yates for bringing such depth to this latest stage of the characters' lives.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince (2009)

movie_review_blurb: The Ice Age series' creativity is clearly melting.
movie_title: Ice Age: Dawn of the Dinosaurs (Ice Age 3) (2009)

movie_review_blurb: A tear-fest medical drama that seems much longer than it is.
Johnny Depp plays John Dillinger with wry charm, but the famous actor also gets in the legendary gangster's way.
John Turturro's very human, comic energy lifts an otherwise flat and re-dundant sequel.
Shuffling, mumbling and musing about his loser's life, Vincent D'Onofrio stealthily steals the picture.
There she goes, a chestnut mare who can't be lassoed, an elusive butterfly traveling to the beat of a different drum.
Cecil B. DeMille meets Monty Python meets Superbad, Year One has some funny moments, but it eventually flops.
Thankfully freed by a child's imagination though it is, Imagine That eventually obeys well-worn, adult-imposed convention.
The film's leading men exceed the action genre's usual requirements, if only briefly.
Seethes with atmosphere and characters that echo the hallmarks of Universal horror.
The Wayans are the masters of spoof.
Technical brilliance and nuanced storytelling lift Pixar miles above the competition.
Best to refuse this delivery
If, in real time, the dull X-Men Origins prequel actually were the first X-Men film produced, it might have been the last.
The greatest prequel ever told.
This bright and lively computer-animated 3D comedy-adventure gives the masters of animation at Pixar a run for their box office riches.
With Virginia Madsen leading the cast, The Haunting In Connecticut tells a good ghost story.
The Proposal restores Sandra Bullock to comic glory. It's her best role since While You Were Sleeping.
The story turns flips to keep audiences guessing. Unfortunately, indiffer-ence, not fascination, results.
Judd Apatow gives old pal Adam Sandler a deep but still funny script that lets the comic-actor go where he's never gone before.
Wielding wicked retribution, the clever District 9 reinvents alien invasion with a wry wink.
A weary hound of a movie.
A powerful and devastating adaptation of Cormac McCarthy's novel.
As uncompromising and genuine as movies that receive mainstream distribution get.
movie_title: Precious: Based on the Novel Push by Sapphire (2009)

movie_review_blurb: For true Twilight believers, the slow moments are more opportunity to gaze at pretty-boy young men playing characters who're both the best and worst boyfriends a girl could ever have.
Pirate Radio misses cues but doesn't run completely aground.
A quietly wacky military satire good for scattered chuckles and laughs.
movie_title: The Men Who Stare at Goats (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Inept to the core, The Vampire's Assistant never rises to the occasion.
movie_title: Cirque du Freak: The Vampire's Assistant (2009)

movie_review_blurb: A beautifully assembled tribute to a great artist.
Better not set foot, hoof or paw on this isle of pain.
Gorgeous to behold, the film also devastates with its meticulous portrait of impassioned lovers against whom fate conspires so mightily.
Trash with a whiplash.
This couples-in-conflict comedy starts strongly but then slips into the turquoise water of paradise lost.
The script doesn't earn the C average students must maintain for continued enrollment in their performing arts school.
Set in the rocky world of roller derby, Whip It proves Ellen Page can carry a good script without Kimya Dawson's songs and Michael Cera's sensitivity.
Sorority Row is most successful at creating characters even more insufferable than the usual young people who serve as slasher-flick fodder.
Perry sticks to his storytelling principles, doing what he does so well.
movie_title: I Can Do Bad All By Myself (2009)

movie_review_blurb: 9 does a good job of mounting its post-war, post-human world, but the emphasis on noisy action sequences and fingers-on-a-chalkboard brutality leave storytelling behind.
A quietly subversive, sometimes delicious, little comedy.
A good idea lurks in the latest Sandra Bullock comedy but it quickly falls into a deep hole.
Despite the added 3-D imagery, elaborate sequences that lead to doomed characters' deaths remain the most interesting thing about this latest Final Destination.
Its plot developments are safe and predictable, but the things Post Grad does well suggest it could have been more than just another middling romantic comedy.
The stylish Inglourious Basterds means next to nothing, but its pure outlandishness draws eyes to the screen.
The amusement park sequence definitely merits a best zombie kill, or kills, of the week award.
Iron Man gives the summer movie season a smashing start.
As threats of annihilation go, the imperfect but effective Knowing presents its big picture with thoughtfulness and style.
The film to beat in the Oscar race for 2009's best animated feature.
The popular Disney Channel series moves to the big screen for a full-fledged movie musical.
Freewheeling fun and romance make Nick and Norah's Infinite Playlist special enough to become a future romantic comedy classic.
Gervais' deadpan expression and sharp comic timing are good for, if not outright laughs, numerous chuckles, in this charming ghost story-meets-romantic comedy.
Maestros of time and place, the Coen brothers orchestra a convergence of incompetence, bad decisions and all-around silliness.

Not to be a contrarian, but as predictable as the movie is, its events often feel as if there were no alternative. The Pang brothers, besides being artisans of action and suspense, tell a good story -- or maybe I'm simply suffering from heat and Hurricane
The Rocker neither rocks nor rolls.
Running an economical hour and 45 minutes, Death Race is all muscle, no fat. Anderson and his exceptional cast tell their tightly built story and get out of the way.
Allen stages a late-career coup, placing his finely sketched characters in an ideal milieu of comedy, romance and madness.
Even if Tropic Thunder doesn't move you to tears, it deserves your consideration.

The big-screen Mamma Mia! rises above its flaws through an A-list leading lady and, like its stage-musical predecessor, skillful exploitation of the both fun and pathos in Benny Andersson and Björn Ulvaeus' undeniable music.
Saw V may still have the power to make audiences squirm, but only for the most obvious reasons.
Hellboy II, like the recent Chronicles of Narnia sequel, sacrifices story and character on the altar of action, effects and underwhelming creatures.
Its 3D effects aside, this latest big-screen adaptation of Jules Verne's Journey to the Center of the Earth unreels like a Hollywood adventure film made many decades ago.
movie_title: Journey to the Center of the Earth (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Wanted's torture-training, its depiction of murder as sport and its feeble justification for a thousand years of slaughter suggest a broken moral compass.
This grim vision of Earth's future is not so funny and not so cute. Nonetheless, the Pixar guys send another enthralling entertainment to the planet's movie screens.
Mark Wahlberg's sturdy performance saves The Happening from becoming a protracted Saturday Night Live spoof of M. Night Shyamalan movies.
The big-screen Get Smart aspires to being an action movie. Big mistake. But raising Maxwell Smart's IQ? And transforming him into a post-20th century sensitive guy? Even bigger mistakes.
Even fans may find themselves wondering when this very long episode will end.
Spielberg and Lucas give fans exactly what they'd given them before and this time it's jumbo size.
movie_title: Indiana Jones and the Kingdom of the Crystal Skull (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Writer-director David Mamet's wheel turns, spinning a dense texture of concise characters and deviously effective manipulation.
Much of what makes the first Narnia movie work is, literally, missing in action in the spiritless sequel.
movie_title: The Chronicles of Narnia: Prince Caspian (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Speed Racer is more Toy Story than Days of Thunder. That could be a good thing, but, in this case, it isn't.
During the summer of 2008, at least, the price of a single movie ticket isn't likely to buy more on-screen entertainment value and cinematic ambition than The Dark Knight.
As movies about killing sprees go, Friday the 13th is OK.
This raunchy romantic comedy's glass is half-filled with amusement.
movie_title: Zack and Miri Make a Porno (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Anne Hathaway is the only reason to witness the rambling Rachel Getting Married.
A cast of appealing big-name talent marginally pulls this messy romantic comedy into positive territory.
movie_title: He's Just Not That Into You (2009)

movie_review_blurb: In the preposterous but gripping Taken, international scumbags mess with the wrong dad.
Elizabeth Banks does commendable work as the movie's boogie woman.
A nearly perfect portrait of a lovable loser who leaps to a place among the screen's most unforgettable underdogs.
Built around Kate Winslet's enigmatic Hanna, this impeccably staged, nuanced drama is not easily forgotten.
Nothing special, but it convincingly transports viewers into its Medieval realm of vampires vs. werewolves.
movie_title: Underworld: The Rise of the Lycans (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Mendes' skillfully struck detachment sabotages pathos.

Documentary-style reminiscences from supporting characters slow the film's momentum. The run-up to the big broadcasts, too, aren't so suspenseful. The best drama comes from Langella and Sheen as Nixon and Frost, and not necessarily while they're face-to-f
Designed around poverty, love and questions though it is, Slumdog Millionaire never really answers big questions. But there's no denying that it's bravura entertainment.
So much more touching, fun and substantive than the silly, formulaic romantic comedies starring younger, hotter box office stars.
Changeling isn't Eastwood's best, but it's very well-told.
An admirable, lovingly crafted film that misses the dramatic depth and historical resonance to which it aspires.
Another compelling story from an American master.
Valkyrie works as a full-dress military drama, fleshing out a historical footnote in vivid detail.
Streep and Hoffman inhabit their roles to the fullest. Even for actors in their league, parts as rich as these don't appear too often.
The movie flows gracefully along, unrushed but ever forward, like time itself. And New Orleans' lovely old neighborhoods and romantic ambiance form the ideal locale for a gently fantastical tale.
movie_title: The Curious Case of Benjamin Button (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Penn's best performance and Van Sant's best film.
No future classic, but a pleasant little movie with a fiercely devoted little hero.
Maybe most funny movie-film you see in your lifes.
movie_title: Borat: Cultural Learnings of America for Make Benefit Glorious Nation of Kazakhstan (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Nothing great comedy or drama happens in Soul Men. The pleasure comes in seeing Samuel L. Jackson and the late Bernie Mac do their stuff.
Nothing to phone home about.
The latest Bond movie can't top its smashing predecessor, but it more than lives up to its action-packed trailer.
The film's mangled chronology and melodrama ring flat alongside Ray, Walk the Line and the classic Patsy Cline biopic, Sweet Dreams.
A dingy smear of butchery.
The gimmick of releasing The Omen on the sixth day of the sixth month in the year 2006 doesn't distract from its mediocrity.
The bizarre but beguiling characters in Tim Burton's Nightmare Before Christmas truly do dwell in a world of their own.
Spielberg seldom gives Cruise, not to mention the audience, a break from the unstoppable peril of merciless invasion.
The movie drowns in stultifying dialogue, mediocre pop music and Locklear's dull-eyed mom-on-the-run.
A paint-by-numbers script means that Herbie: Fully Loaded, despite its dying to please four-wheeled star, often comes up flat.
Cedric The Entertainer is a smart, charismatic guy, but those qualities are MIA in The Honeymooners. The movie doesn't deserve him.
The stars' sizzle plus dialogue to die for and stylish direction make Mr. and Mrs. Smith a summer hit.
The Dark Knight is redeemed in Batman Begins. This is the best Batman movie of all.
A biopic about skateboard heroes of the 1970s that's only truly alive when the Z-Boys are inventing their new sport.
Despite some soapy scenes, this adaptation of Ann Brashares' best-selling teen novel holds touching drama.
movie_title: The Sisterhood of the Traveling Pants (2005)

movie_review_blurb: The brutal, not funny Longest Yard joins the list of most pointless remakes.
So far, this great drama directed by Ron Howard and starring Russell Crowe is the summer movie season's real champ.
Romero's masterfully executed allegory is the High Noon of horror flicks.
Unlike many children's films, Madagascar really is entertainment for little ones. It's no Finding Nemo, but it is leaps above Shark Tale.
A sizzling grand finale is among the few reasons to endure House of Wax.
Once Liam Neeson's noble knight Godfrey exits, Orlando Bloom's lightweight Balian can't carry this message-heavy lecture.
The wisecracking Wanda Sykes steals this mediocre girl-fight from her big-name co-stars.
The Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy has inspired moments, but it becomes a conventional boy-meets-girl, boy-loses-girl -to-the-president -of-the-galaxy sort of tale.
movie_title: The Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Off The Map's landscape is intermittently engaging.
A drama mined with comic moments, the movie's got an Oscar-worthy performance from three-time Oscar nominee Joan Allen.
Sin City translates the cool swagger and ultra-violence of Frank Miller's graphic novels to the screen with high fidelity.
Playing a couple divided by sports and career, Fallon and Barrymore make a great romantic-comedy team.
Stumbling between failed comedy and stilted drama, Imaginary Heroes never finds a convincing tone.
Miss Congeniality 2 is one of those sequels that gives sequels a bad name.
Flat performances and even flatter dialogue give the final Star Wars prequel a hollow ring.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode III - Revenge of the Sith (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Shakespeare needs no special effects or short-sighted novelties. Michael Radford's straightforward telling of The Merchant of Venice does the great play justice.
movie_title: William Shakespeare's The Merchant of Venice (2004)

movie_review_blurb: The movie has more wit than the usual summer fluff, but it's also a forgettable confection that squanders the surprising potential it finds.
The low-scoring Rebound makes Martin Lawrence's upcoming sequel to Big Momma's House seem like a blessed event.
Even among the dogs of summer, The Cave scrapes bottom.
Art-house director Sally Potter casts a great actress in her canvas.
Steve Carell soars with the best comics in funny business.
A nearly perfect thriller.
A frenzied sideshow sprinkled with Terry Gilliam's familiar ticks and excess but lacking funny or winning characters.
The Dukes of Hazzard better have a big opening weekend. Once the Dukes remake hits thousands of movie screens, it's got to win its own race.
The intended surprises aren't all that surprising.
An entertaining, escapist, not particularly ambitious ride.
These pigeons don't fly.
This indie film's wrong turns include a feel-good finish as phony as any Hollywood ending.
This vastly entertaining documentary follows 10- and 11-year-olds as they gain poise and self-esteem through ballroom dancing.
Maggie Smith and Judi Dench are a great duo, but the film isn't so great.
Has little more than color and motion going for it.
What happens to these not-so-interesting people isn't nearly as compelling as writer Amy Fox and first-time feature director Chris Terrio intended.
The march of Antarctica's emperor penguins is among nature's incredible journeys.
The film meanders to every predictable place possible. It's Screenwriting 101, including the big romantic dash as grand finale.
Less discriminating, younger viewers may find Sky High amusing, but actual high school students are way beyond this kid stuff.
The frontrunner for this summer's funniest flick, Wedding Crashers is American Pie for grownups.
The Island is more than the usual Michael Bay action fest. Beyond the mayhem, there's a timely theme, strapping performances and even jokes.
Fantastic Four functions at the level of a below average Saturday-morning cartoon.
Brazilian director Walter Salles' first Hollywood project is both a chilling ghost story and a heart-pulling drama.
Whatever flaws it has, this sweet and sour morality tale is a beautifully crafted and bizarrely amusing delight.
A sincere but less than inspiring war-time drama.
Greed, corruption and murder conspire to make The Constant Gardener an unusually intelligent thriller.
The Ring Two's abandonment of the original film's videotape-of-death hook leaves it floundering.
This Hollywood-set tale of music business corruption never finds it feet.
The idea of casting Ben Affleck as some kind of giddy holiday angel who drops in and makes everything all right again was doomed from day one.
Jamie Foxx masterfully assumes his role as the beloved American music pioneer. The line between Foxx and Ray Charles blurs to the point of being no line at all.
Hypocrites of all stripes better stay out of the South Park boys' sights.
Richard Gere slips into his dancing shoes again for a romantic comedy of sorts that's anything but swift on its feet.
Taxi, former SNL cast member Jimmy Fallon and those arrogant Brazilian supermodels should all be junked.
Unparalleled realism and hard-hitting performances make Friday Night Lights one of the great sports movies.
Pranks, rituals and fires keep coming throughout the melodramatic, cornball Ladder 49.
A giant ad for stuffed toys and plastic figurines, Shark Tale's best suited for the smallest human fry, moviegoers who'll watch anything that's colorful and in motion.
Condoleeza Rice says: "Saddam Hussein cavorts with terrorists."
Woman Thou Art Loosed isn't the most polished film to roll down the pike, but it has authenticity in its dialogue and situations that Hollywood films lack.
The rich collection of animated characters really lives on screen. Once again, Pixar raises the bar for computer-animation storytelling.
Directed by John Kerry's friend, George Butler, the film is clearly pro-Kerry, but it comes off as less a hagiography than a genuine history of the Vietnam War era.
movie_title: Going Upriver: The Long War of John Kerry (2004)

movie_review_blurb: The leads' good performances are sabotaged by a script that lacks the wit and spark of Notting Hill and Four Weddings and a Funeral.
Elaborately conceived and beautifully executed, the movie's a great marriage of fantastical, old-fashioned storytelling and new technology.
movie_title: Sky Captain and the World of Tomorrow (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Fox News eventually comes off as a circle of buffoons yapping catch phrases. The movie hammers its points and, like a Bush campaign stop, there's no room for dissent.
movie_title: Outfoxed: Rupert Murdoch's War on Journalism (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Resident Evil: Apocalypse has some shocks, but its flesh-chomping zombies and evil corporate honchos amount to the same old mayhem, just bigger and louder.
A few cast members bring a scene or two alive, but Vanity Fair is mostly mismanaged.
Anacondas might provide some diversion for a rainy Sunday afternoon of TV viewing, but it's not worthy of the big screen.
movie_title: Anacondas: The Hunt for the Blood Orchid (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Hero dazzles with its visual storytelling
This Exorcist prequel is more or less what used to be called a B-movie. Even B-movies, however, had to please audiences on some level.
In a less media-frenzied world, this small movie would find some admirers at art house theaters. As it is, Open Water nearly sinks beneath the hype that surrounds it.
Like Vermeer's paintings, Girl is a diminutive masterwork, deftly reflecting the master's mysterious art.
For the satirically inclined, many chuckles are found in the run-up to the survivors' late-in-the-film, unfunny desperation.
Along with its computer-animated thrill rides, Robots' tin men and ladies really do have a heart.
Modeled upon real actors though the movie's characters are, they lack the communicative power of genuine human expression. Frankly, they're creepy.
Leading man Pierce Brosnan leaves his world-saving James Bond exploits behind, but he's still engaged in risky business.
A stylish and fun homage to a classic horror subgenre.
Penn's agonized performance in this under-the-radar drama is better than his Oscar-winning work in Mystic River.
Because of Winn-Dixie's heart-tugging sadness makes its joy even sweeter.
Hitch falls predictably in place, but it throws surprises out along the way and has surprising substance.
Part romantic comedy, part soap opera, part travelogue, The Wedding Date fails to deliver on all counts.
In a classic case of bait and switch, Hide and Seek squanders its carefully built setup.
Ice Cube's torturous misadventures inspire a major laugh or two, but more often than not, the jokes are lame and cruel.
The fog of war frames a sprawling romantic fable and epic mystery.
Driven by characters etched deeper than the lines in Clint Eastwood's face, Million Dollar Baby is a quiet triumph for its director and star.
The big-screen rendition of The Phantom of the Opera resembles a ridiculously expensive installment of Masterpiece Theatre.
After wounding and dumping lots of ladies, Alfie finally faces the minor-key music, but he doesn't inspire empathy.
Billed as the first action event movie of the year, superhero flick Elektra isn't so eventful.
What peculiar cinema of the sea Wes Anderson's The Life Aquatic With Steve Zissou is.
movie_title: The Life Aquatic with Steve Zissou (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Finding Neverland usually sustains its magic. Return to Earth though it must, the movie's joys and sorrows leave memorable impressions.
Language barriers are the least of the problems in Spanglish.
Managing to be both stilted and bizarre, Birth never achieves life.
Sex, lies and betrayal form a high-stakes game of love in Mike Nichols' Closer.
The amused twinkle in Anthony Hopkins' face suggests he knows he's crossed the line into parody with Ptolemy's memories of a conqueror "born from the loins of war."
Mel Brooks at his hysterical peak.
That Santa Clause guy, Tim Allen, dashes through the winter sludge of another Christmas Carol knockoff.
The latest installment of the life of Bridget Jones is tired and sloppy.
movie_title: Bridget Jones: The Edge of Reason (2004)

movie_review_blurb: The grisly Seed Of Chucky fails to entertain on any level. Chucky and his family should take a permanent vacation.
In the spirit of last year's Hero, House of Flying Daggers elevates the martial arts flick into the realm of high art.
Maybe November wanted to be the missing link between more conventional art-house films and the hallucinogenic dreams of David Lynch. It fails.
This neo-western suffers from chronic predictability.
Neither one of these guys is the man.
Despite its Messiah complex, Superman Returns successfully revives the series for the big screen.
Jack Black finds the perfect role.
Initially capricious though the film is, this murder ballad transposed to film reveals a devastating hand.
A genuine tale of redemption.
Deserves a prominent spot in the run for this year's best-animated feature Oscar.
Using the classic radio show for his template, Altman helms his most fluid and fun work in years.
Aspires to be a story of redemption and discovery, but it's too undercooked to be either.
Beautiful but slight.
movie_title: The Promise (Master of Crimson Armor) (Wu ji) (2005)

movie_review_blurb: X-Men marks the real start of the summer-movie season.
This Poseidon Adventure remake capsizes.
As lectures on film go, An Inconvenient Truth sends its message in clear and engaging fashion.
The secret is out. The Da Vinci Code is dull.
This sharply drawn satire gets so much about art school right.
A powerful and moving drama.

Writer-director Christian Carion doesn't achieve the depth of poignancy he may have aspired to, but his elegantly simple storytelling does illustrate the futility of the war that was supposed to end all wars.
Keke Palmer's performance delivers on the script's promise.
As refreshing as a mid-morning cancer-stick break.
Instead of the authentic excitement of last year's documentary, Mad Hot Ballroom, Take the Lead presents contrived teen melodrama.
A movie recycled from too many previous movies.
Before its predictable third-act resolutions, ATL presents a rich urban tableau.
Scrat, the pre-historic squirrel-rat, easily upstages the pedestrian storytelling.
Earns higher grades than the average high-school comedy.
Way smarter than the average bear.
An unflattering look at America's military-industrial complex.
Dead Man's Chest suffers from the sequel curse.

movie_review_blurb: Owen Wilson crashes a marriage.

Stocked with unfunny formula.
The ticklishly comic School For Scoundrels earns a good grade.

Life is full of choices and sacrifices, after all, and the makers of this unusually smart romantic comedy know it.

The movie jumps overboard during an insane third act that threatens to undercut the accomplished filmmaking that precedes it. It's such an engaging ride beforehand, though, that the freaky climax is forgivable.
All the King's Men has so much going for it, but this Louisiana political drama goes off the rails, wandering through a muddle of momentum-stalling flashbacks and poorly rendered accents.

The film's originally speculative scenario became reality on Aug. 29, 2005.
A fascinating look at this epically tortured artist.
The Wicker Man occupies some silly, nebulous middle ground between mystery and horror.
Beerfest is what it is, silliness that entertains at its own lowbrow level.
Clunky, cliché-filled and embarrassingly melodramatic.
The film provides a journalistic service, telling a story that most people in the United States have not heard. It's a fascinating tale.
Snakes plus a plane plus a year of Internet hype do not a blockbuster make.
By personalizing the tragedy of 9/11 and checking politics at the door, Stone mounts a first-class tale of strength and courage.
A raunchy, subversive little satire about unlikely redemption.
Soulless and dimwitted.
Under Review series examines works of Smiths, Kate Bush
A grim, dark ride.
If moviegoers are willing to go with the movie's questionable, sometimes painfully self-conscious flow, Shyamalan's new tale may once again sweep them into his idiosyncratic world.

Like old Burt Munro from down under, the movie's a charmer.
A sharp mix of substance and entertainment.
Chappelle's payback to the people is a great and funny documentary-concert film.
Despite its good points, the movie has at least one ending too many.
The most frightening Potter film and the best.

movie_review_blurb: Late-coming satisfaction helps make the movie almost worth the outer space trek.
A rare thing happened at the Monday night showing I attended. When the movie ended, several people in the small but attentive audience applauded.
This second Zorro adventure starring Antonio Banderas and Catherine Zeta-Jones isn't nearly as sharp as the first.
North Country wins its case with powerful moments and exceptional performances.
A rip-off of the Alien movies and George A. Romero's far superior zombie flicks, Doom is doomed to be awful.
An epic of feel-goodness that can't find the exit.
Mold-covered clichés are the most frightening things in The Fog.
Solid work by Kurt Russell, Dakota Fanning, Kris Kristofferson and the equally sincere Elisabeth Shue can't win the race against a lame script.
movie_title: Dreamer: Inspired by a True Story (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Hoffman's Truman Capote is an exacting portrayal.
Thumbsucker has plenty of bite.

In the wee world of clay animation, the brilliant Wallace and Gromit are big dogs indeed.
movie_title: Wallace & Gromit: The Curse of the Were-Rabbit (2005)

movie_review_blurb: What phony hooey this is.
A good-natured, multi-leveled space opera that earns more big-screen voyages.
More bikini-modeling session and Bahamian travelogue than thriller.

Walk the Line isn't the great musical biopic Ray is, but it has golden moments.
The dreaded friend zone turns out to be a funny place after all.
The movie is OK, but it doesn't come close to the power of the book.

movie_review_blurb: Huffman makes Transamerica worth seeing.
The sweep and classic themes of The Three Burials of Melquiades Estrada make it a rare modern western, and a good one, too.
movie_title: The Three Burials of Melquiades Estrada (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Intriguing, shocking, frustrating and meticulously crafted.
Better break this date.
Disney throws family audiences a bone with this chilly dog story.
A worthy final collaboration from James Ivory and his late partner, Ismail Merchant.
More teenagers dying gruesomely.
A pale Pink Panther.
An affecting story that dares to dig deeper than the usual romantic comedy fluff.
If you answer, you may be bored to death.
The mugging Lawrence steps out of character to promise that Big Momma will be back. Fine, but someone should hire writers next time.

Dame Judi Dench rules the screen. It's 2005's richest performance by an actress.
The characters' sundry fates never become a great concern, leaving the viewer, more or less, adrift in indifference.
Underworld goes overboard.
Fields of wind-blown grass, rippling inland waterways and the hum of nature are more important to Malick than dialogue and plot.
Michelangelo Antonioni's classic vision of alienation returns.
An unconventional love story that doesn't match its hype.
Little Red Riding Hood gets an extreme makeover.
Glory Road doesn't live up to its title, but it plays a good game.
An offbeat fairytale populated by colorful characters and spot-on performances.
Must be among director Rob Reiner's worst movies.
The greatest ape of all.
A devastating yet beautiful film from Brazil, House of Sand tells an epic story of love and desolation.

Unlike his American peers, Japanese writer-director Mamoru Oshii makes animated films that are as serious as a heart attack.
A brutal jackhammer of a movie that's more Jerry Bruckheimer than Sherlock Holmes.
A film for admirers of artist Ralph Steadman, people whose politics align with Steadman's politics and the most devoted followers of Steadman's celebrity fan, Johnny Depp.

Third Person' echoes writer-director Paul Haggis' Oscar-winning "Crash" ─ weakly.
A great 'Apes' movie.
movie_title: Dawn Of The Planet Of The Apes (2014)

movie_review_blurb: The movie's wholesale lack of invention includes a plot and characters that parallel 2011's much better sci-fi kids adventure, "Super 8."
Trots out standard romantic-comedy characters and situations.
"Word and Pictures" fails to communicate.
Wild, fast, fun and, in the service of comedy, bromantic.
John Green's bestselling teen love story has been adapted into affecting, beautifully staged film.
A history-based story that both stilted and melodramatic.
Irish writer-director John Carney is a master at depicting musicians on the cusp of something special.
Raunchy and irreverent, "A Million Ways to Die in the West" proves there are a million ways to laugh in the West.
movie_title: A Million Ways to Die in the West (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Hoffman plays a skillful straight man to the crazy stuff around him, simultaneously integrating his character into the story but also rising above its flat drama and muted comedy.
Nicolas Cage doing some of his most focused, deepest work.
Million Dollar Arm scores a triple.
Modestly engaging, the film is more suited to cable TV and Netflix.
The subtitled "The Raid 2" is in Indonesian, Japanese, Arabic and, briefly, English. But its action and drama translate to any language. It fights its way to the top of this year's action movies.
A hallucinogenic plunge down a rabbit hole of no return.
Not much comedy. Even less redemption.
Writer-director Ritesh Batra's "The Lunchbox," a romantic-comedy about two strangers in Mumbai who develop an unlikely connection, may well be the start of a distinguished cinema career.
Huge bears, cute bears, stunning vistas and an age-old story of survival, the G-rated "Bears" is fine entertainment for families and animal lovers.
Anderson serves his guests meticulously assembled fun in "The Grand Budapest Hotel."
Jolie, appearing in her first live-action film since 2010, must be and is the movie's strongest asset.
Despite the exhausting quest taken up by the documentary's hero, the film doesn't register as inspirational.
A goofy parody of dystopian storytelling.
A Marvelous sci-fi adventure that flies by in a whoosh of nimble action and colorful characters.
"Before I Disappear" suffers from a bland, disinterested tone. In the end, few will care when all of these people disappear.
This half-a-novel adaptation bides its time and, in doing so, diminishes its heroine.
The sprawling confrontations and many sideline fights in "Five Armies" equal overkill. A few quieter, character-revealing scenes provide some respite.
movie_title: The Hobbit: The Battle of the Five Armies (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Beautifully directed and acted, the immersive, moving "Wild" is an exceptional redemption movie.
"The Babadook," a small but inventive and seriously chilling horror story, is a monsterpiece.
This latest "Annie" could have been told more efficiently, and with more depth, but with Wallis and Foxx leading the cast, it's an engaging enough, if not memorable, remake.
In the unfocused "Big Eyes," Adams, like the rest of the production, doesn't quite know where to step.
An epic drama about an incredible life, "Unbroken" certainly is a story about surviving incredible odds, but it's not a vehicle for inspiration or revelation.
Benedict Cumberbatch gives an empathy-stirring performance in the year's best biopic.
Blunt's Baker's Wife, Streep's effects-aided badness and underlying vulnerability as The Witch, as well as a fleeting encounter with Depp's Wolf are the primary reasons to go into the woods.
A story of a life well lived, told with appreciation and honesty.
Pulling the supremely naive yet mystically wise Gump off is a feather in Hanks' hat.
So much about The Identical is so wrong.
A mesmerizing drama from Poland.
Stranger than fiction and fascinating.
An uninspiring sports melodrama.
Admirable work indeed, but also a painful walk in the darkness. Meanwhile, Brendan Gleeson's tender scenes with Kelly Reilly and Marie-Josée Croze shape the movie's loving soul.
A dystopian flop.
Too realistic to be inspirational but too genuine to fault, "Boyhood" is, against all odds, a cohesive cinematic feat not likely to be matched any time soon.
A grand seduction staged in an intimate space.
A high-velocity download to the finish.
The jumbled "Get On Up" can't touch the star it purports to represent.
It's a drama, it's a cartoon. It's playful and sad, satirical and moving. All these things and a chaotic visual feast as well.
This biopic about the very young Abraham Lincoln is cinema as visual poetry.
A clunker speeding to the junkyard.

Packs light and plays it safe.
A romantic comedy disaster, in costume.
Thornton, Duvall, Bacon, Hurt and LaNasa part of a rich ensemble taking a trip in 'Jayne Mansfield's Car.'
The two principal characters' interactions and extended conversations deftly blend comedy and poignancy.
Backup singers step into the light in a great music documentary.
The film doesn't earn a place among the great music documentaries, but it presents its stars in 3D immediacy that likely will inspire screams and sighs wherever movies are shown.
Writer-director Sebastián Silva takes viewers on a physical, spiritual, hallucinogenic journey. He's a marvelous filmmaker and storyteller.
After briefly catching comic lightning, the fun fades. Actor-screenwriter Simon Pegg and director-screenwriter Edgar Wright paint their characters into a pub corner.
The best of The Butler contains moving, powerful moments.
Not in the same class as J.K. Rowling's Harry Potter series, Sea of Monsters nevertheless is a passable late-summer action-fantasy-adventure for younger audiences.
A movie that reminds us what a great storytelling medium film can be.
An impressive launch for the film's young writer-director and a signal that the movie's leading man will be a major presence in American film.
A sweet and sour summer song of a movie, it's one of this season's best reasons to go to the movies.
More fun than a sequel has a right to be.

A funny new take on one of Hollywood's biggest clichés.
The tone varies wildly but there's still some fun to be had and the movie's massive budget shows up on the screen.
Gru and his minions in a sequel that doesn't run out of gas.
Despite some slow spots and incongruities, Pitt and his zombie movie win the day.
Saying Monsters University isn't nearly as fun and fresh as its predecessor is letting this low-achiever off lightly.
A intense, smartly cast drama about anti-corporation vigilantes and the young woman who infiltrates their inner circle.
Man of Steel plays like two movies in one. One film is the familiar story of Earth's invasion by merciless aliens. The other, better movie is about a young man discovering his identity and purpose.

A touching romantic comedy that doesn't take the easy way out.
Rather than rouse passions, the film's sterile sci-fi action and Earthly melodrama foster a grim, cold feeling.
The film's principal characters descend into the nightmare made real that compelling storytellers Stratton and Zola build around them.

An extraordinary story of singers, songwriters, musicians, producers and, most of all, two recording studios in a small Southern city.
An uninspiring approximation of Mandela's life.
A wonderfully assembled film that depicts Harris Glenn Milstead as a performer, show business trouper and a dear friend to many. It's a divine documentary.
