A visual feast and a hell of a dragon set within a thin story.
movie_title: The Hobbit: The Desolation of Smaug (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Action-drama "Homefront" has screenwriter Sylvester Stallone's touch written all over it. Director Gary Fleder keeps things moving.
Following Disney animation tradition, the sparkling "Frozen" features a pair of princesses and dozens of charming non-human characters.
McConaughey pulls his character's unlikely alliances off with a truthful mix of newfound tolerance and common-sense grit.
Teen actress Adèle Exarchopoulos, more than anyone or thing, makes "Blue is the Warmest Color" glow.
Not a homerun, but Shia LaBeouf never lets his reckless passion fail.
There's much heart and humor in "The Best Man Holiday" but also jolts from laughter to tears in the blink of a false eyelash.
This sequel gets a slow short before becoming worlds more entertaining than its 2011 predecessor.
Awards-worthy work by director Paul Greengrass and leading man Tom Hanks.
British director Steve McQueen and American screenwriter John Ridley adapt Solomon Northup's meticulous slave narrative into a masterpiece of clear-eyed historical drama.
A more fawning than illuminating documentary about the Bikini Kill and riot grrrl movement co-founder.
Keaton's intensely focused performance probably is the best of his life. Some especially moving scenes achieve almost physical impact.
Bill Murray finds the perfect Bill Murray role in 'St. Vincent.'
Produced quickly on a slight budget, 'The Zero Theorem' devolves into a dead end that asks that old question: Is that all there is?
Steven Spielberg's cinematic fanfare for a common man who's uncommonly good.
Uneven though this horror film from Guillermo del Toro is, this haunted mansion is worth a visit.
Movie junk food.
The movie finally rises from its dullsville crypt - just before it ends.
Lily Tomlin's performance as the rascally old Elle belongs on short lists for 2015 acting awards.
Despite Patricia Clarkson's performance and screenwriter Sarah Kernochan's expansion of Katha Pollitt's 2002 New Yorker essay, the film still feels undercooked.
Madcap horror, coiled and ready to spring.
A dark period of Irish history revealed as unvarnished drama with a little romance.
Moviegoers who sampled Baumbach's movies in the past and left with a bad taste in their mouths may do well to give "Mistress America" a chance. It's funny and poignant.
Amiable, if shallow, entertainment, until it falls off a cliff.
A daring, unconventional biopic that succeeds through the power of words and vastly talented group of actor and filmmakers.
A deftly executed, suspenseful drama from Germany.
More dull than dark.
More for Woody Allen completists than general audiences.
Not fantastic.
Surface-bobbing childhood memories may not deserve movie treatment
A bleak, daring drama from Ukraine.
'Southpaw' punches new life into a familiar scenario.
A harrowing, liberating documentary.

A story about an old man striving to make the best of the remains of the day, 'Mr. Holmes' succeeds most of all through forceful performances by Ian McKellen, Laura Linney, Hiroyuki Sanada and spunky junior cast member Milo Parker.
Flying in the face of the Schumer character's initial independence, 'Trainwreck' slips into romantic-comedy formula. In the end, it's just an old-fashioned love story.
A rapid-fire superhero adventure, 'Ant-Man' earns a place alongside Marvel Studios' other superhero movies.
A bloody valentine wrapped in sharply orchestrated madness.
Heavy with grief and the knowledge that a daughter, friend and musical genius has been lost, "Amy" is a tough watch.
Despite Cate Blanchett's and Robert Redford's earnest work, the truth about "Truth" is that it fails to engage on the emotional and intellectual levels that would have made it commanding drama.
It's too long and padded, but on balance "Mockingjay - Part 2" wins. That's a tribute to Jennifer Lawrence's commitment to Katniss and to some of the strongest action scenes in the series.
The results don't quite achieve inspiration, but it's still powerful stuff.
Rob Reiner directs a high-achieving cast led by Woody Harrelson, who grabs his role as Lyndon Baines Johnson by the ears.
Writer-director Dee Rees' adaptation of Hillary Jordan's 2008 novel contains powerful moments and loads of atmosphere.
In writer-director Geremy Jasper's impressive first feature, Australian actress Danielle Macdonald brings the aspirational title character all the spunk and vulnerability she needs.
As exploitation movies go, "Kidnap" delivers in primal, high-octane style.

'Girls Trip' is about friendship and loyalty. But that warm foundation is also fertile ground for ladies on the loose in the Big Easy. Director Malcolm D. Lee and his quartet of ready-to-play actresses hit the streets running.

A droll, atmospheric adaptation of Thomas Cullinan's 1966 novel. Although the 1971 film adaptation starring Clint Eastwood is well-regarded, writer-director Sofia Coppola deftly reimagines the story from a delectably feminine point of view.
Never Go Back never met a cliché it didn't like.
Peter Berg directs the calamitous spectacle in mesmerizing style. The movie delivers a spellbinding, heart-rending story about the human cost of the catastrophe.
A devastating romance that lingers feverishly in the mind.
movie_title: My Golden Days (Trois Souvenirs De Ma Jeunesse) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Heavy on homage, short on originality.
Finding Dory has its moments, but it's not one of Pixar's home runs.
A worthy 'Macbeth' refresher course, highlighted by Michael Fassbender's feverish Macbeth and Marion Cotillard's simmering Lady Macbeth.
"Of Mind and Music," an intimately told story with few characters, surprises with unexpected impact, thanks to the talented cast and the powerful dual forces of music and human kindness.
movie_title: Una Vida: A Fable Of Music And The Mind (2016)

movie_review_blurb: The performances, appearing as they do in an intimate, elegant drama of love, separation and loyalty, are so affecting and so devoted to the characters in the most unselfish ways.
Director Colin Hanks lets his affection for his subject run over. The film probably is for record aficionados only.
movie_title: All Things Must Pass: The Rise and Fall of Tower Records (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Trumbo leaves a door open for someone, sometime to make a better movie about the blacklisted screenwriter who lived long enough to be vindicated and honored.
A beautifully staged and acted immigrant drama.
Beautiful sights, stale storytelling.
A documentary that's at its best when it's dealing with the irony of Hunter as a heartthrob to millions of young woman and a closeted gay man.
Other than a moving conclusion, this is a mediocre sports drama.
Seth Rogen climbs to gonzo comedy heights in this Christmas Eve buddy-picture
In the bloody muddle "Triple 9," Chiwetel Ejiofor, Anthony Mackie, Woody Harrelson and Kate Winslet manage to make a few scenes count.
Less inventive and entertaining than the "Despicable Me" movies but still engaging.
The characters and their problems are not worth their 90 minutes on screen.
An unexpected comedy about motive and manipulation.
Writer-director Mike Leigh renders an intimately detailed portrait of the artist and Timothy Spall portrays Mr. Turner in brilliant strokes.
Director Michele Josue depicts the personal side the famous victim of hate she knew as friend.
movie_title: Matt Shepard is a Friend of Mine (2015)

movie_review_blurb: The filmmaking craft is admirable, but the story never commands the audience do its bidding.
The Dardenne brothers are too wise in their storytelling to settle for easy exits. That makes their new film all the more powerful.
McFarland, USA, its leading man Costner and the seven novice actors who play the story's cross-country team run their feel-good story to the finish line in inspirational style.

Returning director Steve Pink and screenwriter Josh Heald re-create the goofball, quick-tempo chaos of their original film. It's a silly, gross-out frolic that's often irritating but somehow turns tolerable.
After showing the audience how much Alice has to lose, the film shows her losing it. Julianne Moore's finely honed, affecting performance makes her an Oscar frontrunner.
There's no escape from the silly, pulpy predictability of Fifty Shades of Grey.
If "Force Majeure" writer-director Ruben Östlund makes more films as amusing, perceptive and deftly crafted as this one, he'll be a force in world cinema.
Despite leading man Jude Law's passionate performance, his vessel continuously springs leaks.
Definitely second best, and not in a good way.
movie_title: The Second Best Exotic Marigold Hotel (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Kevin Costner's and Octavia Spencer's confrontational scenes are "Black or White's" strong suits.
J.K. Simmons excels in 'Whiplash's' hand-to-the throat storytelling.
Steve Carell's leering du Pont, a sad, damaged soul who's blind to his princely vanity, becomes, in the character's stealthy way, an unforgettable villain.
This shaky action flick directed by Michael Mann botches its shot at being the of-the-moment cyberdrama it might have been.
Briefly messes with Kevin Hart formula, but more often shoehorns prerequisite celebration scenes and implausible plot turns into Hart's party mix.
A character-driven drama that's among the most incisive military movies of the post-9/11 era.

Horses, wagons, occasional Indians and villainous white settlers don't stop "The Homesman" from transcending the western tag. In ways both simple and deep, it's a stark, tender, heartrending, universal tale.
A dense and dreamy trip to the end of the 1960s.
Belgian director Michaël R. Roskam, making his American film debut, shows that he's a skilled steward of actors, characters and shadowy crime drama.
By the time Hiro and Baymax summon some genuine emotion, 'Big Hero 6's' 93 minutes are all but finished.
Doesn't leave a single cliché unturned.
Playing partners in business and life, Oscar Isaac and Jessica Chastain radiate genuine heat.
Even with its attractive leads, Lily James and Richard Madden, grand fairy-tale settings and, when it counts, affecting moments, this live-action "Cinderella" is only modestly engaging.
Patricia Clarkson keeps 'October Gale' from completely sinking.
A fascinating documentary that's more than a sports story.
This largely casual coming of age story doesn't adequately prepare the way for big drama and emotion, which consequently comes off falsely.
movie_title: Me and Earl and the Dying Girl (2015)

movie_review_blurb: The movie finds some melancholy poetry in principal character Manglehorn's obsession with a long-lost love. But his decades-in-the-making redemption is too little, too late, for himself and the audience.
In this especially poignant entry in the Pixar catalog, humor, while not entirely absent, takes a backseat to a escalating crisis.
Jurassic World fills the 3D screen with summer-movie thrills and fun.
An unconventional biopic that ranks with Oscar winners "Ray" and "Capote."
Oscar-winner Jean Dujardin stars in this serious and stylish French angle on "The French Connection."
Melissa McCarthy takes the comedic lead and runs with it.
Energetic but underachieving follow-up to 2012's fun musical comedy.
Beautifully acted, grandly romantic cinema that nevertheless doesn't lose touch with the Earth.
However inspiring their Disney source material may have been, writer-director Brad Bird and co-writer Damon Lindelof have fashioned an uninspiring muddle of a movie.
Could be the crime drama Martin Scorsese wishes he'd made. Or may yet make.
Too much talk, too little soul.
Despite its promising ingredients, "Lambert and Stamp" wanders off key.
The film finds a wealth of worthy interviewees but it probably will preach to the choir on the one hand and be ignored by the other.
The grim, contemplative "Maggie" personalizes zombies, thanks in part to an unusually serious performance by Arnold Schwarzenegger.
The D Train doesn't fully exploit its good comic ingredients. It paints itself into a sad, anxious corner from which it cannot escape.
Jonah Hill stars in a drama that's no laughing matter. Even though the film grows muddled in trails of misdirected ambition and deceit, Hill excels.
Monkey Kingdom moves so smoothly and quickly that the filmmakers' time-consuming dedication and labor-intense toil stays, as it should be, invisible.
A long slog of a Russian tragedy that doesn't let its protagonist or the audience off the hook.
Despite tuneless songs, Kendrick's and Jordan's bursting-to-wilting performances are worth the 90 minutes invested in this swiftly moving, set-to-music anatomy of a marriage.
Fabulously stacked with furiously over the top, in a good way, action. Call it Car Wars.
The better things in "It Follows" are a tempting tease for what the film's young director will do next.
A music-filled, appreciative but not fawning account of the session musicians who helped make so many of the 1960s' records great.
The outrageous This Is The End takes an early lead in the summer movie comedy sweepstakes.
There's flash, energy and an exciting chase sequence. There's also much to do about magic tricks that aren't so enchanting.
"61 Bullets" effectively revisits the 1935 assassination of Louisiana's Kingfish, Huey P. Long.
Renders fictional class warfare and fictional misguided government policy as a shocking jolt of entertainment.
With its clichéd, one-dimensional characters, the movie fails to engage at an emotional level.
Evict this roommate.
Liam Neeson ably continues his late-blooming action career.
Seeing Hopkins do his deadpan routine is The Rite's primary attraction.
Michelle Williams and Ryan Gosling take the plunge, reeling beneath their characters' troubled lives.
127 Hours may be more a social media-driven cinema stunt than story, but it has triumphant moments, transcendent imagery and Franco's Oscar-nominated performance.
A not so bad bromance.
A lively but sloppy update for Kato and the Green Hornet.
A holiday turkey.
A stylish historical drama that suffers from self-importance.
A fun ride through a comic twilight zone.
The Coens' triple-barreled gamble - adapting a classic book that's previously been adapted for a classic film headlined by a famous star - succeeds beautifully.
Natalie Portman dances on the edge, in the dark.
An exceptional drama.
It's two movies in one, one of which achieves Showgirls-level badness. Burlesque's soundtrack is a much better investment than a movie ticket.
Love and Other Drugs transforms the recognizable, mostly through its deeply written and beautifully acted principal characters.
The leading candidate for best family film of the holiday-season, Tangled stands tall among Disney's towering animated classics.
A meandering, downbeat steppingstone to the Potter series' grand finale.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows - Part 1 (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Even if it's not great, Megamind manages to be diverting.
Two-time Oscar winner Hilary Swank wins the case.
A meandering, pointless disappointment from the normally exceptional Eastwood.
In its minimal, low-budget way, Paranormal Activity 2 summons some chills, but it's most of all a scheme to make millions from a miniscule investment.
A vastly entertaining boxing tale featuring championship bouts from Christian Bale and Melissa Leo.
Even if the film isn't worth recommending, it's not nearly as bad as it deserves to be.
A beautifully crafted, nevertheless slight animated feature.
A cute and touching look at animals in peril and the dedicated humans who care for them.
A frequent choice for transposing fiction into film, The Three Musketeers returns as an action-filled, slight diversion.
Visible for miles, the predictable turn of the VHS tape undermines a movie that's already weak in scariness.
An unusually immersive filmgoing experience, no 3-D effects necessary.
Delivering the deftly choreographed calamity that's carried the series thus far, Final Destination 5 doesn't cheat the series' followers.
Gross-out comedy The Change-Up is among the worst of Hollywood's body-switching movies.
While 2011's Rise of the Planet of the Apes doesn't achieve the near-classic quality of 1968's original Planet of the Apes, it's close.
movie_title: Rise of the Planet of the Apes (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Occasionally, some clever lines emerge, but the movie mostly fails to charm.
There are laughs elsewhere in this crude comedy, but the film lights up the most when supporting player Jamie Foxx shows up and steals every scene he's in.
The greatest Potter film of them all.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows - Part 2 (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Hanks and Roberts make this sketchy project better than it deserves to be.
A taut, immersive ride.
Moviegoers willing to tolerate Malick's origins-of-the-Earth ruminations eventually will come upon a universal American drama featuring one of Brad Pitt's strongest performances.
The film's bigger, longer, louder battles don't create more excitement.
Brings the fun back to the X-Men franchise.
A clever and fun cinematic postcard that can transport susceptible romantics to the City of Light.
Despite its old Spielberg magic, it's J.J. Abrams' deftly applied human touches that put Super 8 over the top.
More mean spirited than fun.
Kristen Wiig proves she can lead an ensemble comedy that's as raunchy as anything her male counterparts produced.
Lacking wit and imagination, On Stranger Tides hurls less-than-riveting action.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: On Stranger Tides (2011)

movie_review_blurb: To its detriment, this film most of all prepares the way for a sequel.

Russell Brand, the genuinely funny talent upon which this misbegotten remake is hung, brings his manic energy, but neither he nor Oscar-winner Helen Mirren can resurrect Arthur from a laugh-deficient fate.
Beyond being a great new interpretation of a classic novel, Jane Eyre is a superb second feature from Fukunaga, a director who's on track to becoming a major contemporary filmmaker.
The frontrunner for worst film of Carrey's career.
Neither winner nor loser, Secretariat settles for a polished mediocrity.
Haunting and tragic.
In the competitive realm of computer-animated features, Legend of the Guardians: The Owls of Ga'Hoole is as long and dull as its title.
movie_title: Legend of the Guardians: The Owls of Ga'Hoole (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Predictable though the film is, Vanessa Redgrave does nearly mystical work and the film in general has enough humor to make the trip worthwhile.
Ridley Scott and a vast army of actors, crew and extras produce a massive new Robin Hood that stands with the veteran director's best work.
The 3-D is underwhelming; the movie's not so bad.
The movie labors long, but realistically so, before finding hints of light in a very long tunnel.
Following a slow, overly verbal start, this dragon tale takes flight.
Creepy and sleazy, the film gets most of its power from Julianne Moore, Liam Neeson and Amanda Seyfried's overachievement.
A classically stupid-funny teen comedy with a retro twist.
Not great police drama or film noir, but engrossing.
Eisner stages a tight, confident and relatively big horror film. And farm machinery has rarely been so eerie.
Burton brings his distinctive touch and Johnny Depp, Mia Wasikowska and Helena Bonham Carter do their stuff but a hodgepodge of Hollywood conventionality lessens the wonder.
Shrek's "It's A Wonderful Life," plus lots of action and Donkey teeth in 3-D.
Mirren and Plummer together in The Last Station create their own cinematic event.
Nicolas Cage goes off the deep end even more than usual in the crazily entertaining, Werner Herzog-helmed Bad Lieutenant: Port Of Call New Orleans.
movie_title: Bad Lieutenant: Port of Call New Orleans (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Jeff Bridges wears his character, one-time star Bad Blake, as comfortably as a favorite old cowboy hat.
Despite appealing leads and a little guys vs. corporate honchos scenario, it's a muted rendition of a family's real-life drama.
The film's populist avenger is quintessential Gibson.
Rich in personal drama, political intrigue and royal pageantry but also satisfyingly compact.
There's depth and realism in the way Frances Ha shows aspiration versus reality.
A muted tragedy about a murdered girl who watches her family and killer from a place between heaven and Earth, The Lovely Bones remains oddly remote.
Baldwin, Martin and Meyers stage an ensemble comedy that's among the funniest movies of 2009.
Nine doesn't achieve the dynamic range that might have made it far more captivating than it is.
Well-crafted, well-acted and ambitious as Up In The Air is, the movie's third act taxies to nowhere.
An embarrassment to Universal's horror legacy.
Prince of Persia has the high-spirited air of an old-fashioned boys' action-adventure movie but, tuned to modern audiences, the conflict is predictably amplified, accelerated and constant.
movie_title: Prince of Persia: The Sands of Time (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Episodes of high hilarity make the movie worth the trip.
In execution, entertainment value and integrity, the latest Pixar animated feature vastly outdoes the live-action summer movie fare that surrounds it.
Because the prospect of being trapped in an elevator is so naturally frightening for many of us, 'Devil' obviously underachieves.
An American movie star, an Italian leading lady, a Dutch director and a British screenwriter pool their talents for for the best-crafted American film of the year.
The Virginity Hit confuses humiliation with comedy.
A clever, small film that depicts showman-preachers and horror movies with a wink and nod, The Last Exorcism spends most of its 88 minutes staying a cut above the average horror flick.
Robert Duvall expresses his character's eccentric charm best during one-to-one scenes with fellow screen veterans Bill Murray and Sissy Spacek.
Noisy, forced and much less magical than Nanny McPhee I.
Lottery Ticket sags in its middle buts its energy, comedy and characters also provide much entertainment.
Botched sensitivity aside, The Expendables delivers epic action.
Not to be blunt, but The Other Guys is dumb, mostly.
The first martial arts-romantic-comedy-action-adventure-fantasy-musical.
Carell charms in a scene or two but otherwise this is far from a pleasant night out.
A heartwarming little film that makes a genuine connection to the joys and trials of childhood.
Never a dull moment.
A brilliant small film that deals with big issues in a beguiling way.
No magic here.
Like many sequels, remakes and reinventions, Predators rarely assumes a life of its own.
The Last Airbender blatantly sets the stage for a sequel. Unfortunately, this awful film's huge box office receipts may make a sequel reality.
Despicable Me is charming, fun and poignant. Maybe Pixar and its minions should be watching their backs.
More than ever %u2014 and all for the love of sullen high school senior Bella Swan %u2014 it's teen wolf vs. teen vampire.
John Malkovich and Josh Brolin are too good for the sloppy, overripe Jonah Hex.
Fast-paced and charming, Knight and Day may well restore the box office fortunes of its well-matched leading man and lady. It's the Mr. & Mrs. Smith of 2010.
Real joys and sorrows must be bigger and deeper than this.
At best, this is entertainment for pre-teen boys who prefer meaningless action and little else in their movies.
Eddie Murphy returns to comedic form in Tower Heist but his character, and the movie in general, lose their sense of humor.
The most engaging Twilight movie yet.
More for Terry Gilliam completists and Heath Ledger's more devoted fans than a general audience.
Martin Scorsese's affecting, gorgeously rendered 3-D debut is one of the best films of this year and any other year.
It's a pleasure to watch Pitt work in dialogue-rich, subversively comic film noir.
The actors' passion overrules the filmmakers' artifice.
Surprisingly funny and touching.
Breaking Dawn - Part 2 isn't the best Twilight Saga movie, but it does contain the best Twilight battle.
movie_title: The Twilight Saga: Breaking Dawn Part 2 (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Lincoln lives, vividly, in Daniel Day-Lewis' performance.
A smashing new Bond adventure for the superspy's 50th anniversary year.
Washington, already the winner of two Academy Awards, does more exceptional work in Flight.
Ralph and his new friends offer much action and adventure, but the movie scores most of all with its poignant scenes and the relationships among its characters.
Even if comedian Mike Birbiglia doesn't have more stories worth telling on film, he's done one movie that sneaks up on an audience and earns its attention.
A funny trip to Hollywood and gripping escape from Tehran.
A just about brilliant sci-fi crime-drama-thriller mostly set in the years 2044 and 2074. Rian Johnson is a rare director who creates entertainment with depth.
A heartwarming, funny tale about a boy and his reanimated dog.
A fun, young musical comedy boosted by Anna Kendrick's straight-woman chemistry and multiple amusing supporting characters.
An early contender for multiple Oscar nominations.
Matthew McConaughey gives an intensely wry performance while director William Friedkin applies his old-master craftsmanship to a brutal, ugly story.

Trouble with the Curve isn't one of those sports movies that inspires audiences to stand up and cheer. Yet the interior challenges Gus and Mickey face, and Eastwood and Adams' well-gauged performances, make the game worth watching.
Containing almost no story, Resident Evil: Retribution shows the series' video-game origin more than ever.
A great blend of storytelling and technology.
A beautifully assembled documentary that reveals the purposefully low-profiled co-founder of Alcoholics Anonymous.
One of those thoughtful films that arrives after a summer of sequels and superheroes.
Far smarter and original than the phony, empty romantic comedies Hollywood usually churns out.
Earns its stripes as one of those bad movies that's so bad it's good, in its bad way.
Helen Mirren, playing opposite Anthony Hopkins, does the movie's best acting work as Hitchcock's right-hand woman.
In his next movie, maybe writer-director Judd Apatow will integrate comedy and drama more smoothly or, at least, cushion the ride enough to prevent whiplash.
Likely to be this year's biggest inspiration for tears shed in movie theaters, Les Misérables is a suitably tender, sad and stirring adaptation of the beloved stage musical.
Saskia Rosendahl succeeds in a demanding role set amidst a bleak post-war landscape.

Fifteen five-minute movies and one concept are packed into this cinematic love song to New Orleans. The results are, inevitably, mixed, but the flavor of the city, from accents to attitudes, is distilled.
The movie flies by in an entertaining flash.
An earnest biopic that misses the ball.
By the time the last excruciatingly spilled blood drips, Evil Dead stakes its claim as a worthy remake of Sam Raimi's 1981 horror classic.
A clumsy, implausible terrorist-action-drama, Olympus Has Fallen falls in a period between prime movie-going seasons and it shows.
A deadly serious and detailed examination of and meditation upon the Israeli-Palestinian conflict, The Gatekeepers makes no attempt to find a silver lining.

CGI baboons, the wizard's CGI monkey companion and colorful but soulless CGI landscapes of Oz are no substitute for the absence of even one great song and characters who develop the greatest of friendships as they fight the greatest battle of their lives.
The film's tightly scripted hours in New Orleans wield their way to a destination that's worth the time spent getting there.
The choice to include a ponderous narration violates that basic rule of storytelling: Show rather than tell.
Much better than it needs to be given its late-summer horror flick placement.

As the film's characters are reaching the end of their lives, loose ends will be tied and soul searching will be done. Hoffman gracefully orchestrates the story's emotional arc. Quartet is a lovely late-career surprise from a master actor.
First there was Abraham Lincoln: Vampire Hunter. Now there's Hansel & Gretel: Witch Hunters. Neither of them deserved to be mentioned again.
A small film featuring three wily, veteran screen thespians in a storyline based in loyalty and friendship, Stand Up Guys is, in its offbeat and often warm way, a killer little movie.
An entertaining, if not particularly longed for, return for the 65-year-old action icon.
At 80 minutes, the film feels a bit long. That's probably an example of the filmmakers' affection for their subjects, both the Zanders brothers and New Orleans.
The movie is most alive when Bill Murray's Roosevelt and Samuel West's King George VI retreat from the crowd and talk man to man.
An edge-of-your-seat ride through recent history featuring a great performance at its center.
Difficult to watch but difficult to turn away from, The Impossible makes shattering impact.
Cinematically well-crafted and -acted, Promised Land nonetheless is a shallow exploration.
During its rocky road to becoming a fractured love story, Silver Linings Playbook and its great ensemble cast run a funny, conflict-mined, even suspenseful path. It's a total winner.
Tarantino's spaghetti western of the American South is an untamed blast of stylishly rendered, outrageous entertainment.
Filmmakers who want to out-Tarantino writer-director Quentin Tarantino had best back off.

Margot is silly and annoying, but three-time Oscar nominee Michelle Williams' makes her conflicted character believably real. Meanwhile, contrivances, indie-film clichés and overall misery make the movie an unhappy dance marathon.
A promising start.
Even without Jason Bourne and the corresponding Matt Damon, it's a well-cast and well-done continuation of the series.
Teens Gone Wild: Extreme Edition
Rosemary's Baby on hot wheels.
The boneheaded, humorless This Means War cranks out clichés with such frequency that it easily qualifies as an early contender for the most awful film of 2012.
A brutal, bloody action picture that follows a familiar corruption-in-high places theme.
It's got a half-baked script full of holes, villains written in bold type and, even though it's based on a true story, concocted banality.
Daniel Radcliffe outgrows Harry Potter convincingly in this well-done ghost story.
An action movie with a brain and a heart.
She's not much in the acting department, but Gina Carano can punch, kick and pounce, all of which is more important than acting in Steven Soderbergh's action flick.
The Artist delights in an ingeniously straightforward way that exceeds many a modern, technologically advanced, effects-loaded, big-budget blockbuster.
More irritating than touching, healing or any of the positive things one would guess such a story and cast would produce.
The songs are a waste but this candy-colored, animated musical adaptation of Sr. Seuss' cautionary tale from 1971 otherwise is enjoyable.
A few striking scenes don't unite for a satisfying whole. Streep's powerfully measured performance is something greater than the film that holds it.
Gary Oldman's graceful understatement as Smiley makes his slow-burning performance all the more smashing.
Steven Spielberg adds another film worthy of classic status to his credits.
Charismatically played by Rooney Mara in David Fincher's coolly executed, moody rendition of Stieg Larsson's book, this tattooed girl really does kick a hornet's nest.
movie_title: The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo (2011)

movie_review_blurb: The Adventures of Tintin is stuffed with action and fun of the Indiana Jones and Pirates of the Caribbean kind.
The new collaboration from Jason Reitman and Diablo Cody stumbles through the dark end of town.
A rare sequel that's better than the original.
movie_title: Sherlock Holmes: A Game of Shadows (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Writer-director Sean Durkin shows he's a master storyteller. Elizabeth Olsen immerses herself in her subtle, creepy role with all the resonant evil the nightmarish screenplay needs.
Dennis Quaid gives a deep performance of a shallow farmer who's obsessed with success. But the script for this unfocused, distraction-saddled heartland drama needed more cultivation.
A few exceptional musical performances don't mitigate an otherwise stale melodrama.
George Clooney, an actor who more often than not appears in exceptional projects, finds another gem in The Descendants.
A non-scary movie possessed by badness.
Directed and co-written by Andrew Stanton of "Finding Nemo," "Toy Story" and "Monsters, Inc." fame, the fun but sometimes confusing "John Carter" may launch the next big sci-fi-adventure franchise.

Michelle Williams' glowing performance, at times touching, tragic, innocent and sultry, rekindles Monroe's magic. Her British co-stars, especially Kenneth Branagh and Judi Dench, are memorable even in Monroe's light.
An inept message picture.

The similar films, books and myths that went before don't matter. The Hunger Games succeeds on the strength of its fresh, clearheaded narrative and depiction of a brave young woman who rejects the monstrous rules of the game.

When it's over, there's not much worth recalling.
Magic and realism meet in this transporting, immersive tale set in the wilds of south Louisiana.

A diverting visit to the Eternal City, as opposed to a romantic adventure in Paris.

Boys will be boys.

Not just the funniest film in the series, Men In Black 3 has the best story, too.

The Farrelly brothers re-create the Stooges' choreographed mayhem and anarchic spirit with exacting fidelity.

The movie's greatest flaw may be its passive-aggressive approach to the Grimm brothers' tale. Timidity doesn't suit reinvention. But endings being so important, the movie finally puts the pieces together for an entertaining finale.

A fast-paced action-adventure picture written large upon the screen. It's helped along, in this case, by a couple of things: some fine performances, especially from the two leads, and the collective cultural memory of lots and lots of baby-boomers.

Elektra is a strange and emotionally distant picture, redeemed, if not completely, by a nice climactic battle, some moody visuals and a star who seems to be working as hard as she can to heat up a character designed to be chilly.

The script, by five writers, is a melange of role-playing games, Biblical references, mythology and martial-arts and other movie cliches; it's predictable when it's not impenetrable.

A powerful, original look at the hopeless urban underclass in the American city, where lost people nibble at the garbage of our culture -- in a kind of perverse application of the "trickle-down" theory -- hating themselves and us all the while.

movie_review_blurb: Amid all the blood and gore -- and laughs -- Shaun also has something to say.

ultimately The Hamiltons is still a damn solid film.

The Rider is art imitating life in one of the best ways. Because the main characters are not trained actors, the film benefits and it produces a story that is heart-wrenching, unfiltered and intimate.

White Rabbit is a whirlwind of expression and feelings. With quirkiness at its center, the story itself can feel aimless and without a purpose. But truly, it reflects its lead's journey towards meaning.
In the end, The Catcher Was A Spy was much more catcher and not enough spy. What we end up with is a film that's the opposite of how fascinating its lead subject is.

The Light of the Moon is lived-in, in every sense of the word. It's able to provide a point of view of how life continues after something as serious as sexual assault with sensitive but impactful micro-moments.

It does not exist to stretch your mind (it does stretch your time, running a bit too long in the third act) but like the OASIS, it's a wonderful piece of escapism. Sometimes, a vacation from anything meaningful does make for an interesting ride.
The Guilty is a simple, but captivating thriller. However, it is difficult to get on board with the lead as a tragic hero due to his murderous actions.
While Burger, Daughtery and Taylor skimp on the characters' interior lives, they do make some surprising improvements on the book.
Pushing the envelope with many jokes and original ideas it could have been a masterpiece, but turning it into a romantic comedy and starring Gervais does not make that true.
"Where the Wild Things Are" was always a fun book as a child. However it is a daunting task to turn a short story into a feature film.
"Law Abiding Citizen" is a sizzling hot thriller that will have you on the edge of your seat from start to finish.
Bora Bora was a beautiful location to film at and added that much needed taste of paradise to a rather bitter sweet subject of a troubled marriage.
It takes girl power to the extreme and made me wish I was a roller derby girl. Jam packed full of excitement, action, humor and intensity.
Forget Halloween, get your thrills and chills from this film!
"Ninja Assassin" will not be enjoyed by all, specifically the female crowd who will feel assassinated by this action film.
The "The Fourth Kind" poses as another successful documentary on the hot trail of "Paranormal Activity". Too bad this film is missing many ingredients to make it a blockbuster success.
A box full of boredom.
Wes Anderson offered the most unique animation this year and great dialogue; dialogue that was perfected with performances by George Clooney, Jason Schwartzman and Meryl Streep.
"Zombieland" is the freshness the box office needed with its witty writing, directing and outstanding performances.
Don't turn a blind eye to "The Blind Side" as it is one of the best films this year!
Not as intense as it's predecessor Twilight, but still manages to shine."
This defiant and sinful comedy makes for a hilarious start to 2010.
It was your average D Day film with all the bells and whistles and while many will enjoy it, it could have been better.
Can't remember any of their names, except for one. Kudos to Kherington Payne who has come a long way since 'So You Think You Can Dance'. Only standout performance in my book.
Gutsy, pleasurable and very satisfying. Packaged together by the amazing Quentin Tarantino, this film will slap you in the face and say: "Damn good, what a way to end the summer!"
Albeit it has a dull tone and can drag, but once again Damon pulls you back in.
"When in Rome" was the freshness that the romcom genre needed.
Daring and dirty, making it so delicious.
Marc Webb directs this film brilliantly and makes us fall in love with everything from all 500 days.
Director Neill Blomkamp has packaged an original Sci-Fi film filled with CGI and action that most moviegoers will love.
"Bandslam" is a terrific family film that showcases the importance of constructive teenage friendship.
Solid love story that could have reached extraordinary limits, but fails early on.
Yes this film will only target to a certain demographic, but for those who love these whimsical love tales you will be A OK with this one!
"The Goods" has to imply an antonym as it is far from good. Despite starring the Emmy award winning Jeremy Piven, the writing destroyed any chance of success.
movie_title: The Goods: Live Hard, Sell Hard (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Surprising tale of love and perseverance. Writer Max Mayer deals with the touchy subject beautifully, and Hugh Dancy proves to be a noteworthy star with his performance.
A confusing tale of love that will have you questioning your love of film making.
It's as bad as "I Know What You Did Last Summer", except on ICE!
Could not survive the bland dialogue and what a misuse of Kristen Wiig.
An adorable and entertaining film that is appealing to the appetite.
Depressing tale of a mother's love, or at least what she thinks love is.
Burnett even offering one of her best comical acts could not save the lousy uninspired script.
Despite its visually remarkable attempts to engage the film is an utter loss.
With an all star cast and creative writing Machete is the best film I have seen this year.
Comparing "Dear John" to "The Notebook" is like comparing hot and cold. One set the box office on fire, while the other will have viewers wondering why.
Eat Pray Love is a long marathon full of self pity and poor interaction.
"Funny People" contained all the right players, but the humor of the film was lost. During the first half it was a solid comedy, but the second half turned it into a double-feature.
Witty original film that is very appealing due in great part by the charismatic Emma Stone.
The money may not be sleeping, but much of the audience will be following this poor investment of a film.
I had more fun watching "The Social Network" than I do snooping Facebook. Post a comment, tag your friends, like this post but get out and see this film!
"Life As We Know It" is not one of the best rom-coms out there, but it will suffice for a couple hour escape giving you a few laughs along the way.
Inception is the exception to a boring summer!
Seeing it in 3D was disgusting, but that is not a bad thing.
With an abundance of creative talent and laugh out loud moments "Morning Glory" is the perfect film for Fall.
Buckle up and enjoy this ride, this film has unstoppable thrills that make it one of the best this year!
There is much still to uncover South of the Border and Stone has only sold us one side of it...with so much left to uncover South of the Border is missing it's edge.
John needs to move on and leave Lara behind as the Next Three Days felt like three years.
With a strange sense of 'Planes, Trains and Automobiles', but missing the magic, this one would be a great buddy film!
Director Darren Aronofsky again brings a beautiful pure ballerina to a dark demising devil, all without missing a beat.
Hilary Swank offers another stunning performance!
This film will not disappoint Twihards and will have everyone bummed that Breaking Dawn is a year and half away.
Cruise is refreshing and Diaz is not. But that is not enough to ruin the entire film!
Sandler lost his touch a long time ago and that does not seem to be changing anytime soon.
Wax on, wax off...you decide.
We discover a lot about love and that Taylor Swift can't act! Oh and Eric Dane shocks the hell out of us.
I tried to get lost on Shutter Island, but am sad to say even with its ominous tone and dreary setting I found myself dreading its predictable tale.
There was not an overabundance of blood & gore and a great hint of comedy that had me loving "The Crazies".
Going into Cop Out you should expect the expected, a spoof of a comedy that is not an Oscar winner, but rather the first stupidly entertaining film of 2010.
No tears were allowed at this service, only tears from laughter.
Not the best romantic comedy, but as an expectant mother it's humor engaged me!
"Date Night" provided just the escape you need without pretending to be someone else, so go out and enjoy it!
Save yourself the ticket price and buy the original on DVD and see what a true fright is.
"Just Wright" is close to a good romance, but its dribbling and missed shots caused it to be lackluster one for me.
Too much of this and not enough of that. This archer has missed his mark.
Very limited shots of New York City, destroying a beloved character, and the girls have all matured and are no longer what Sex and the City was and has been about.
I can't say it is the hit of the summer, but this film should definitely be on your must see list that you can rock out to.
The Karate Kid is lacking originality that could have made it as powerful as the original.
The A-Team has finally set the summer afire with the first action packed thrills of the year.
Finally a post apocalyptic tale that offers everything you want and expect!
I was engaged by the fiery chemistry between Bullock and Reynolds.
Seth Rogen as an animated blob is awesome, just like this action packed animation.
Kudos to the amazing Sacha Baron Cohen who offers one of the best characters since 2006, an actor who can remain in character even with a gun to his head.
A heartfelt and loving film that is meant to help you remember to not take life for granted and treasure every moment.
movie_title: The Curious Case of Benjamin Button (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Don't expect much more out of this film than what you have seen in Liar, Liar.
Another note worthy Will Smith film and this one should not be missed out on.
Maybe catch one of the other hundred holiday films to be offered over the next few weeks and wait for Four Christmases to come to your local Red Box.
Twilight is a must see and a must for a sequel. Can anyone say New Moon 2010?
Be prepared to laugh out loud and move to the music as Soul Men has plenty of both to offer.
Are you looking for a good holiday film that the whole family can see? Look no further than "Marley& Me".
Kansas City native Paul Rudd is not only taking on a new lead role, but is also making an attempt at writing, and let's say it's a good one.
Tropic Thunder turns out to be a very funny film with an immensely talented cast that will be the topic of any water cooler conversation.

Lakeview Terrace is not a hit by any means, but it is a lot better than Jackson's last film Snakes on a Plane and much improved for director Neil LaBute, known for his previous work on The Wicker Man.
Changeling offers powerful performance and storyline that won't leave you dissatisfied.
Definitely a step down from the first one, but you should not let that stop you from seeing a film with great humor and animation.
"The Reader" definitely could have more to offer the listener.
An endearing film that will bring you to tears and have you cherishing every relationship and day you have.
Definitely can not be compared to Superbad or Knocked Up, but another secure comedy brought to use by both Seth Rogen and Judd Apatow.
This movie is definitely not as good as the first as it seemed to lack showing the bonding moments that made these girls true friends.
movie_title: The Sisterhood of the Traveling Pants 2 (2008)

movie_review_blurb: If you are looking for mixed martial arts with a little magic thrown in, then this is the film for you. Otherwise, let me say I hope this Mummy is a wrap.
movie_title: The Mummy: Tomb of the Dragon Emperor (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Overall "Swing Vote" was left unresolved in the end and could not sustain a viewing audience for the 100 minute run time. It would be much better viewed at home, so you may doze off comfortably.
Another average film that could have had so much more to offer if the screenplay followed more closely to the actual events.
Stop-Loss is an eye opening experience, with a look into the Iraq war and the consequences our troops our paying.
Here's to wishing for more great films from this Apatow clan!!
The 88 minutes given for the doc to live in peril felt more like 88 hours.
Catch the amusing ridiculous scenes on You Tube; don't waste any time or money on this film. What a waste it was for me!!
SNL brings some must needed comedy relief to the big screen and it finally pays off.
Iron Man is a thrilling ride full of excitement and laughs. Finally this year we have a great family film that everyone will enjoy.
What Happens in Vegas is a sorrow attempt at a romantic comedy. So let the saying stand What happens in Vegas, should stay in Vegas.
A great film to catch with your girlfriends or loved one. Mc Dreamy does not disappoint on the big screen.
A film with great flair. Another hit for Carell and a great summer hit for all that is a must see!!
Wanted was found to be on the outlandish side, but it has a thrilling joy ride for all to enjoy.
The fourth of July will not be the only day for fireworks, July 2nd will definitely heat up at your local theatre when Hancock is released. Be sure to check it out.
The film was so exciting and entertaining that I felt swept away. As if I was a wedding attendee, cheering on Sophie to discover herself and for her mother to find happiness.
This film is sure to surpass your wildest expectations. The summer film that is sure to be unforgettable and leave you craving for more.
Another standard comedy where you can get exactly what you have seen before. I was hoping for more this time and sad to say I was disappointed.
I was expecting a grand film, with fireworks and bells, but was disappointed to say the least.
It is not the year for pre-historic comebacks.
movie_title: Ice Age: Dawn of the Dinosaurs (Ice Age 3) (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Dreary and depressing tale that would not have survived without the powerful and emotional performances by Kate Winslet and Leonardo DiCaprio.
"Slumdog Millionaire" is an engaging and inspirational ride that will have you stating a million reasons to see it.
Kicking off the summer with this flick I was hoping for more sizzle, but wound up with a lot fizzle.
Catholics need not worry as "Angels & Demons" falls short in offering anything more to viewers than a lighter wallet.
If you are looking for something positive from the Terminator Salvation, look for Arnold Schwarzenegger's computer generated re-birth.
Upstaging its predecessor with colorful new characters and energy the kids will love.
movie_title: Night at the Museum 2: Battle of the Smithsonian (2009)

movie_review_blurb: How do you craft a horror film to perfection? Just add Sam Raimi to the mix to get the perfect brew of blood, sacrifices and a gypsy curse while leaving viewers dying for more.
"My Life in Ruins" is a stellar romantic comedy where ancient history and love meet.
Two great performers lose out because "The Soloist" has the potential to be better than the directed product.
Defying space and time, we will see one of the worse films of this year.
Travolta as the bad guy unfortunately did not work. I think if Washington & Travolta's roles had been reversed perhaps we would have had fireworks.
Not only a comical view of a shopaholic, but an educational one too.
J.J. Abrams proves his masterpiece can translate into great work on the big screen that all Trekkies will love.
Maya Rudolph and John Krasinski's journey will leave viewers pleased that they tagged along for the ride.
Two hours later I felt as if I was heartless, as all this film did was make me wish I had the last two hours back even after all the melodramatic pain and suffering.
As much as the film had bang for the buck, it just did not cut it.
Pushing the envelope unlike anything the industry has offered us this year; "The Hangover" provides the escape factor. Prepare for the wild ride!
"State of Play" turns in stellar performances, a winding plot and intriguing characters that make it an exhilarating thriller.
A film most teenage girls will swoon over, and I guess I found myself being 17 Again in doing so too.
This mall cop makes Paul Blart look good, and that's not saying much.
If you are a Kevin James fan you probably will want to see him rolling around, otherwise you can pass on this one to save a few bucks.
See the rise of Mickey Rourke to reclaim his much deserved spot in Hollywood.
"Hotel for Dogs" gets 4 paws way up!
Bland common romance. Nothing new here.
Don't be deceived by the trailer as "The Uninvited" has so much more the offer the victim, I mean viewer.
This romantic hit will be swooning all the girls and breaking hearts everywhere.
movie_title: He's Just Not That Into You (2009)

movie_review_blurb: I would not recommend this film and hope the case of Pink Panther is closed for good.
A classic is a classic and attempts to remake are usually ridiculed. This is no exception.
Knowing's path is so far fetched, disturbing and down right awful that I would expect to find very few people who enjoyed this film.
Man do I Love this film!
Taken is the best action thriller of 2009 thus far.
Miss March does not have much to offer aside from nudity and sexist humor.
A story about love that truly binds in an outrageous way and what one man would do to make sure he would not have a broken heart. It's adorable and will have you laughing along the way.
A joy ride filled with trials and tribulations of angst teens just trying to deal with life.
Thrilling ride with high speed chases and action packed fighting that will satisfy any appetite.
"Gran Torino" will knock your socks off, but be prepared to have some ear bleeding after all the graphic comments and cursing you will hear."
Jake Gyllenhaal has all the sex appeal needed to pull of a romantic drama, but for some reason "Love & Other Drugs" was not the right script for me.
This film does not have the shock value of many other horror films, which was a pleasant surprise for my taste. It is scary in the sense that this could this really happen.
"How Do You Know" that this movie is not all that great. Wait till about half way through and then ask for a refund.
A film that has great potential turns into a disaster.
In the end it was a little too strange for my taste, but I know fans of the dark and mysterious will love it.
"The Croods" is fun and wild and exactly what the kids will love.

There are very few movies I regret having wasted my time on or are completely disgusted by. "Spring Breakers" is the definition of disgusting. The characters had no substance and the storyline had nothing to offer.
Gerard Butler is a star and is finally back in his niche.
This film had no use of the 3D.
Not so incredible.
"Trance" is a masterpiece that will leave your imagination running wild.
"42" is a glorious tale of staying strong and having perseverance in the face of hatred.
"The Great Gatsby" not so great, but pays a decent tribute to the novel.
From the opening thrills to the explosive end you will find yourself immersed by everything Star Trek.
Don't expect this Hangover to compare to the original, but it does supersede its dull sequel.
"Man of Steel" is an exciting film that every super hero fan will love.
"The Internship" is a delightful comedy.
A great film that captures how every decision you make has its repercussions.
This will be one of Summer's top blockbusters. Experience the magic and See it Now.
There is little to love about Oz, especially by those who love the classic.
"Snitch" will offer a handful of excitement, but nothing that is worth rushing out for.
An edge of your seat drama that will give you some much needed entertainment!
"Flight" is a must see that gives new meaning to flying the friendly skies.
"Breaking Dawn Part 2" offers readers and moviegoers the ending they hoped for. Only problem is most will be asking for more and wishing it was not the final chapter.
movie_title: The Twilight Saga: Breaking Dawn Part 2 (2012)

movie_review_blurb: "Killing Them Softly" is a package mix of 'The Departed' and 'Pulp Fiction', something you have seen before with very little improvement.
Unfortunately for Butler it is another romantic comedy that misses the mark and does not score.
"This is 40" is fun at times, but in the end is another Apatow flop.
"Silver Linings Playbook" could not be a more awkward love story. But I loved every second of it!
Get in out of the cold and enjoy a family fun evening checking out "Guilt Trip", it's the funniest trip of 2012.
"Zero Dark Thirty" is film making at it's best.
Sean Penn's performance as Mickey Cohen will disturb you.
It is going to take more than a few A-list actors to improve this "Broken City".
"Identity Thief" tries its best to entertain but half way through it loses its appeal and you'll be ready for the criminal chase to end.
Different title, same story.
movie_title: A Good Day To Die Hard (2013)

movie_review_blurb: The novels by Nicholas Sparks' have finally been redeemed.
If you can get past the first twenty minutes of the film you are in for a pretty solid action film.
Pixar has created another charming child's film that will entertain adults.
The intensity of the story had me gripped till the very end.
Sofia Coppola directs another beautiful film that will be the rave of Hollywood.
Aside from a couple sweet and heartfelt moments this movie is a total waste.
A must see that will spark conversations and please the viewing audience.
Jason Statham is at it again. He is proving to be this decades ultimate action star.
Nine years was worth the wait, "Anchorman 2″ is exceptional and outrageous fun!
It's a far cry from your typical relationship, but it is one that will prove how blind love can be and that it truly can make you do crazy things.
"That Awkward Moment" is a fun flirty film that couples and singles will enjoy.
"Frozen" is stunning. From the beautiful snowflakes, to the ice castle everything in this film was exquisite.
This is one romance that did not flourish and you can save a pretty penny by not seeing it.
I wish I had found the meaning of "Enemy" or could have enjoyed it, but I wish I could get my time back.
You will check in to the Grand Budapest Hotel and find yourself not wanting to leave!
Every second I was amazed at the beautiful scenery, costume designs and the magic that was captured.
For the start of 2015 this is a strong film that audiences will enjoy!
It sure was a long ride and one I would not care to take again.
Amy Adams stepped out of her cookie cutter roles and took on a badass role and stole the show. By far her best performance and Oscar worthy in my opinion.
A true masterpiece of a film from the animation to the storyline behind the Lego universe.
"Last Vegas" is pure clean entertainment that will offer a fun night out.
Life is all about time and I would wait for the DVD.
Kids were laughing every minute at these birds and adults will appreciate the select moments of grown up humor.
It's about time there was a cop comedy featuring girls!
Funniest comedy of the Summer.
As a family it is not cheap for a movie going experience, this is one you can skip and save your money on.
The minions are back and better than ever.
"Jobs" seems like a simple film focusing on an incredible genius, but nothing more. Could you be your average made for TV movie.
"Kick-Ass 2″ is a solid film that will surpass your expectations.
Nothing spectacular, skip it.
Prisoners is one of the best films of 2013!
Great chemistry from the cast and the thrilling action made it entertaining for all.
Its brilliant idea of foodimals and striking images will capture the audience's attention and keep them enthralled.
movie_title: Cloudy with a Chance of Meatballs 2 (2013)

movie_review_blurb: "Don Jon" is bold and clever. Very sophisticated and mature in the way it showcases the sexuality of men and women.
"Captain Phillips" is intensity to the max and one of the best movie watching experiences this year.
"Gravity", a beautiful dance in space that is the closest replica anyone could ever ask for. Easily my favorite film of 2013.
Chloë Grace Moretz is a wonderful Carrie, but not even her strong performance could save this failing reboot.
I have no complaints about "Bad Grandpa" except that the journey ended too soon.
Kevin James transformed not only into a fighter, but also managed to perfect his lead role performance.
Another perfect example that some sequels are a very bad idea.
Make sure to check out this fresh scary movie with just enough thrills to have you jumping out of your seat.
"The Words" seems to have jumbled the lines and created a melodrama that is a sore disappointment.
"Larry Crowne" is an adult story about starting over and finding love. Inspiring the audience to never give up, whether it is for an education or finding that one true love.
There is a heat wave and it is coming from Mila Kunis and Justin Timberlake's sexy chemistry!
With key players Emma Stone and Steve Carell you get a charming grown up comedy. A genuine film that was easily relatable which made it a fantastic surprise .
The surroundings made the movie and gave it an eerie effect, but overall the storyline lacked substance to be a true horror film.
movie_title: Don't Be Afraid Of The Dark (2011)

movie_review_blurb: The film seemed to move at a good pace, but was not something I would care to see again.
Offering the best thrills of 2011, "Contagion" will have audience viewers rapidly spreading the word, much like the virus.
"Mr. Popper's Penguins" the best family film this year and a must for the summer!

I did not care for the slow pace or the finalization of "Drive" but with Gosling's solid performance and scenes that reminisce of "The Departed" it is worth a quick viewing if you can stand the blood & guts.
It's not worth the quality time you could be spending with your children or the extra change in your wallet.
movie_title: I Don't Know How She Does It (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Proving second chances can happen "Moneyball" takes you on a joyous journey that makes it one of the top family films of 2011.
"Spooky Buddies" is a perfect howling surprise for all the little ghouls out there.
Another magical experience that will have the mother's crying and the kids cheering!
"50/50" is a tear jerker film that has me calling it one of the best films of 2011.
This political drama has a juicy tale that you have to see to believe.
The film is very depressing and melancholy that you have a hard time finding the entertainment factor. That is until you get the music.
There was not much to like from this film. The dialogue was bland; the story was lame and felt nothing like what real life is all about.
Summer is heating up with the excitement Steven Spielberg and J.J. Abrams bring to the big screen.
"The Hangover Part II" is what you will expect. I don't think it was better then the first but it did a great job at being just as good.
"Looper" is the best action/sci-fi film in years.
"The Green Hornet" is the first exciting family film of 2011!
Heartbreaking honesty with the challenge of finding the light in a very dark story.
Proving that mixing religion, horror and cinema is something that usually does not pays off.
Adam Sandler is back in the game!
This dirty little secret is one of the funniest films to start 2011!
A strong mystifying story that lays it all out and has you choosing fate over the plan.
"Limitless" is the perfect way to kick of Spring with a highly addictive motion picture that has you wondering would you try NZT?
"Hop" may not be the best holiday live animation, but its attempt is not terribly flawed.
"Source Code" is electrifying action that is lackluster mid way through but comes back in the end to catapult you to another universal ending.
It's time to lay ghost face to rest.
"Fast Five" is easily one of the best in the series. Fast cars, romance, family ties and a heist comparable to that of "Oceans Eleven".
There is not a whole lot to love about this supposed romantic comedy and thus it is not worth the ticket price, wait for the DVD!
Bridesmaids hits the nail on the head with its comedy about a girl who is getting married and the repercussions it can have on friendship ties.
"Kung Fu Panda 2" was enjoyable, but I found this version to be for the older children.
I was not impressed by the original and was pleased to find a slight satisfaction in the refreshed model.
Could Eddie Murphy be getting his comeback? Just maybe with this comical heist!
"The Change-Up" is a raunchy adult film with its seldom comical moments.
Maybe if you have a little rum before viewing you can enjoy the diary, I however was not impressed.
Everyone asks for a sign every now and then, let this be yours to see an original film that will be worth the ticket price.
Overall "21 Jump Street" is an over the top action film with comedy that is not always perfect, but what is perfect is the blast this undercover adventure is!
Fans of the Pie movies will relate and enjoy what "American Reunion" has done. It is a perfect way to round things up and bring things to a final end...or at least I hope so.
Another story of two people thrown together to somehow display that they are soul mates, but all it did was make me dislike these movies even more.
"Lockout" has a very minute amount of cheesy comedy that will have you laughing at it, but maybe that is the point.
In conclusion it's a cute story with some originality, but a little on the long side.
Terrific film for both men and women and any expectant parent needs to go out and see this and prepare for the road of surprises you will have ahead of you over the next nine months!
movie_title: What to Expect When You're Expecting (2012)

movie_review_blurb: There is no denying that "Rock of Ages" is a full on musical, but the heavy metal songs belted out from the 80′s make it easier to swallow.
Refreshed and energized Madagascar offering non-stop entertainment
Despite stellar performances there is an overcast of shifting moods and a forced love story.
movie_title: Seeking a Friend for the End of the World (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Get your Santa hats on and buckle up for the latest adventure of Harold & Kumar. It's the stocking stuffer that you have been waiting for.
The eye candy is worth every penny of your ticket price.
Instead of watching the lame mudslinging ads from home get out and enjoy some real election fire in theaters this weekend.
Overall it will make a fun evening out, but don't expect greatness out of this race to the finish.
A dark twisted comedy that has strong performances making it one of the most memorable films of this year.
If you must know the dark secret "Silent House" holds then prepare for a journey that may not pay off in the end.
Simply stunning.
Who would think a teddy bear would shine in this Summer's comedies?
"Wanderlust" was a huge disappointment that had potential that is quickly trashed with the cheap humor and endless blooper reel.
"Paranormal Activity 3" the best in the bunch. If you are ready for a scare and maybe a sleepless night check out this edition and be prepared for some unanswered questions and a few new answers!
Nothing is remotely attractive about this film. Not even the title is original.
The storyline reached a new depth and is everything every fan will desire.
The talented cast offered stellar performances, but the most surprising was Michelle Williams who took on the daunting task of playing the iconic Monroe.
To say "New Year's Eve" is cheesy is an understatement. Love struck people running around and trying to have a good time. But that is also what makes the film fun.
"The Help" is refreshing and possibly the best film of the year.
For the holidays it does come packaged very well and kids will love the idea of living in the backyard of a zoo, but for some adults it misses the mark.
If you are looking for a family fun holiday weekend then "Happy Feet Two" is for you.
Thomas Horn makes the film! The emotion he manages to evoke in a single scene is brilliant. He captivated me and had me living with him through the emotions.
First excitement of 2012!

The only thing saving this film are the performances from Denzel Washington and Ryan Reynolds. If you are looking for a little excitement you'll get it from this film, but for me I could wait for the DVD.
"Treasure Buddies" is another fun-filled adventure.
Falling in love all over again...but missing a little magic.
Share the love of "Lady and the Tramp" with your loved ones this Valentine's Day.
If you like choir music, you'll love this movie. If you are iffy about the type of music you will find yourself checking your watch as the film does become sluggish towards the end.
Slackers meet Satan in not-quite-so-excellent adventure.
Folklore cartoons are more entertaining than educational.
A more passive-than-usual Barbie in lackluster holiday tale.
Prison rape comedy is offensive and a waste of time.
Cross-country caper with mild peril is OK for preschoolers.
Classic entertaining holiday shorts with perennial lessons.
Sweet Dora holiday movie sprinkled with Latin flavor.
Gripping tale of survival leaves a lasting impression.
movie_title: Far From Home - The Adventures Of Yellow Dog (1995)

movie_review_blurb: Slightly creepy undertone to lovely staging of classic.
Touching horse story wrangles tough issue of loss.
Funny, rowdy, classic cartoons strung together for Easter.
Kids will love Santa's puppy, but watch out for sad moments.
Barbie gets the swashbuckler treatment; some violence.
A not-too-scary headless horseman offers a history lesson.
Fun, funny family dog movie has star moments.
Product tie-ins overshadow this fashion travel adventure.

Actually brings a clean, new and very funny edge to the weathered genre of crime and sleaze.
All perspective on the characters and situations are dissolved, leaving the audience with little more than some lovely photography to enjoy.
Separates and identifies characters not on the basis of their reality and frailty as human beings but as the total of their longwinded whining about their love lives.

Offers nothing more than the chance for Tom Green the actor to just be as insane and disgusting as possible without an arbiter to help him sort out the funny from the way unfunny.

movie_review_blurb: Save for a few crackling wisecracks from Billy Crystal, and some moments of delicious is-she -acting-or -is-it-real insanity from Catherine Zeta-Jones, the fine cast sleepwalks through this film.
It's a shame that this strong cast had such weak material to play.
While New Suit might not be the worst film ever made, it is without question one of the worst films about Hollywood ever made.
The actors improvise and scream their way around this movie directionless, lacking any of the rollicking dark humor so necessary to make this kind of idea work on screen.
It contains language and depicts sexual acts that most will find appalling and intolerable, and this fact overshadows any enticing human element the film tries to extend.

movie_review_blurb: The quirky and bizarre nature of the material would have been better suited to a director more nimble with absurd, broad and physical humor.

Not worthwhile if you value cogent storytelling or the dinner you just ate.
May Bubba Ho-Tep play at midnight drive-ins until Elvis indeed returns.

A modern gem of Iran's always interesting filmmaking industry.

Ultimately, the fan-pleasing HMTM and its bestselling soundtrack album are about building new bridges.

As the insecure, innocent ingenue, Sparks, 22, seems a bit tentative at first. But like her character, she gains her footing.
A must-see for liner-note readers.
A sweetly entertaining, canny celebration of the pop heartthrob du jour.

Sports woefully outmoded cultural punchlines.
An unexpectedly elegant ballet of resistance and attachment.

IIf it's a god on a skateboard you want, a god on a skateboard you'll get in this hagiography ...

movie_title: What We Do In The Shadows (2015)

movie_review_blurb: These man-child hero films haven't worked since the late 90's.
The only thing Trainwreck has in common with its name is that it is something you can't turn away from.
Its witty humor and repartee [has] mostly [been] taken away, leaving only crass, unfunny lines that at the most inspire a chuckle.

movie_title: What We Did on Our Holiday (2015)

movie_review_blurb: If you give it a chance, I guarantee it will win you over with its humor and charm.
Segel showcases an intensity we had yet to see from him, embodying Wallace's mannerisms and down-to-earth demeanor while still providing deep insight through conversations.
...you're left with a sour, metallic taste in your mouth and a longing to re-watch the first two films (maybe even the third one), trying to forget this one exists.
The film boasts a big game, but in this case, it gives us everything we expect.

Like some people, most films want to live forever. In the case of Self/less, it'll be lucky to last the weekend.

movie_title: The Young And Prodigious T.S. Spivet (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Kahlil Gibran's The Prophet is full of ideas and teachings that will majestically soar miles above most children's heads.
The most interesting thing Call Me Lucky does is build up a character we may have been unfamiliar with at the start of the film, only to break him down again to give him even more complexity.
The Final Girls trades in the slasher film staple of gore and wanton dismemberment for an unforced emotional depth that cuts deeper than any wound their killer could inflict.
The Martian doesn't contain anywhere near the intellectual depth of Interstellar because it doesn't need to... it wants to stimulate a different muscle: The heart.

Zemeckis lends his hand in creating the type of engrossing environments his films are known for... His recreation goes well beyond the visual aesthetic (like the marvelous reproduction of the World Trade Center), and envelops our other senses.
Director Peter Sollett offers little cinematic joys beyond the obvious. Everything is meant to be taken at face value with no symbolism to dissect or metaphors to decrypt.
In a statement I don't make very often, this Adam Sandler film is a great, harmless option for your children in this spooky season.
Stonewall is such a cataclysmic disaster of a film that I'm surprised nobody has called FEMA yet to help with all the damage it's done to the GLBTQ+ community.
Time Out of Mind is powerfully compelling because it tempers the real life sense of helplessness with everyday examples of the inherent kindness of humanity.
Cooties had an idea that could have been fleshed out into an uproarious flesh-eating comedy... but what you get instead is a fever-pitch of tropes that are all dead on arrival.
Turbo Kid takes this vehicle as fast and as far as it can go, but it is always careful to stay on the clear coarse set before it.
Grandma boasts a strong, female ensemble cast that is as diverse as it is talented.
Great interactions and performances are only a few of the outer joys in Z for Zachariah, but the deeper symbolism is an added pleasure in this film.
For better or for worse, the pacing mirrors actual conversations by sacrificing brevity for the philosophical build up.
Jesse Eisenberg's performance reminded me of his character in Rio... Just replace the bird with a live-action human and add infinitely more gore.
Manglehorn serves as a sleepy delivery system for Pacino to let us know his best work may still be ahead of him.
The authenticity of the story, or whether any of it was fabricated or exaggerated, is never in question, thanks in big part to the genuineness of the performances.
I Am Chris Farley has an unspoken and not fully acknowledged darkness that remains in the outskirts of the film from its beginning.
Chappie's base programming is that of a rudimentary artificial intelligence film... it tries to show off it's self-awareness, but comes off as unintelligent and uninspired.
In a surprising performance, Melissa McCarthy breaks through her typical crass, ball-busting character shell and gives us a peek at her true range.
Performances and music are only part of what makes this film a great story, but without great visual elements to unite them, this collaboration of the senses would be a bust.
With stunning underwater visuals, and a story that is engaging enough despite its obvious turns, there may be gold here yet.
With inspired performances and an even more inspiring story, this film is more than just a fantastic biopic about a great man; it is also a call to action.
It's a disjointed, frenetic series of unfortunate events that isn't even fun to watch mockingly... Your time is better spent fantasizing about one of the two onscreen leads.
A diviner is a person who can predict the future, but that doesn't excuse why The Water Diviner was predictable and lacking fluidity.
Built on good intentions and flimsy ideologies, this film collapses, undoing any good it has done by moving from moral to moral with the same attention span of a child.
Slow pacing on top of subdued performances and a misappropriation of the film's focus turns us into the real victims of this film.
Unfriended uses its subtle development of suspense to create genuine, well-earned scares, even if there are only a few.
The Babadook will trap you in its pages with its compelling performances. but like every kid's book, your happy ending is waiting for you on the last page.
The film is not only stylized, but it is also about style. From the multipurpose suits and accessories to the deadly prosthetic legs, there is an elegance behind it all.
Assayas writes/directs this film in his typical cerebral style. Every scene is deliberate, every action premeditated, and every visual reference requires further examination.
The story of freedom from oppression and freedom of expression in Iran is a somber and ruthless one, but you'd never know the true extent of it by seeing this film.
White God has all the moralistic themes and allegorical elements to make the film evergreen when applied to almost any social, political or socio-economic conflict.
To Write Love On Her Arms is a symphonious specimen of the melding of dazzling visuals, masterful musical scoring, and remarkable performances.
movie_title: To Write Love on Her Arms (Renee) (2015)

movie_review_blurb: This film is full of missed opportunities, regrets, and bad decisions, and I'm not just talking about the characters in this half-cocked story.
Every scene is played with such authenticity and sincerity that it almost makes you forget the story itself is fiction.
Julianne Moore shows us that she is still in her prime, playing to every subtle nuance of the degenerative disease with precision and respect.
Run All Night doesn't have enough gas to get through the two hour run-time, let alone the stamina to go all night.

Schwarzenegger's endearing and powerful performance will give you a change of heart on not only this film, but also when considering his artistic range.
Insidious: Chapter 3 continues to sneakily seep into our peripheries, creating another flawed but solid horror film.
The varied tone and subject matter makes Tales of Halloween a smorgasbord of devilish delights.
The film is all about deception and betrayal, and the biggest one is this B film misusing its A star cast.
No new ground is covered, no unknown secrets revealed, but instead you get a mildly entertaining trip into the world of professional crime by some attractive, terrible people.
Jupiter Ascending is like the cantina scene in Star Wars. It's a mixed bag of creatures, concepts and characters.
Results not only flexes its dramatic muscles, but also shows us the strength of its most powerful muscle: its whimsical, beating heart.
San Andreas is a blue ruin of borrowed elements that even The Rock was unable to save.
Seventh Son wraps itself in a bland colored shroud of clichés, making you find reality much more interesting than fiction.
Tomorrowland is full of visual pleasures and sweet sounding platitudes, but ultimately you know it's an innocuous attraction.
Poltergeist has too many skeletons in the closet, but unfortunately none of them add up to a particularly scary film.
Clint Eastwood shows us he can still churn out a good war film, but misses the mark on making it a truly great one.
This is not the Marble Hornets we have come to know and love/fear.
movie_title: Always Watching: A Marble Hornets Story (2015)

First time writer/director John Maclean creates Slow West as a sort of unofficial love child of Wes Anderson and Quentin Tarantino.
Writer/Director George Miller set the GPS, aligned the steering wheel and then unrelentingly stepped on the gas, never once stopping or slowing down to second guess himself.
Wiig has proven she can do drama with the best of them, with the bonus of being able to naturally inject subtle humor into her performance without it seeming out of character.

The plot is a bewildering blunder, expecting you to jump right into it even though you're never sure you understand the story's progression.
