No amount of star power or emulation of much better films could have transmuted Gold into anything more than a common metal.

... Hacksaw Ridge feels like a competent execution by Gibson as he flexes a cinematic muscle that may have come close to atrophying from being unused.
Films like A United Kingdom may offer a very familiar cinematic approach, but prove to be no less worthy of being told.

After seeing a very familiar routine performed, I can only assume that even Hart hasn't figured out how to move forward since he's still relying on tactics from his past.

As a historical lesson, Birth of a Nation offers no teachable moments beyond being a cautionary tale about what happens when a group of people, who continue to face daily injustices, reach a boiling point.

Despite the competent script and experienced directing, this film would have just been middling without the performances to inject some personality into it.

... examines the true nature of humans once all of our constructed creature comforts disappear and we are forced to face ourselves in the light of the wilderness.
The entire cast gives a monumental performance that does justice to this monumental story.
There is a certain tune trapped inside of Terrence Malick's head, and it is infecting his work.
Baby Driver is hopefully the first in a long line of experimental films from accomplished auteur Edgar Wright.

The visual style of the film is whimsical, perfectly playing into the imaginative mindset of a child while providing some pleasant nostalgia to the adults.

movie_review_blurb: If the future films are as monstrous as this one, it will be a dark universe indeed.

... the most fun I've had with food since I was a child recreating the extinction of the dinosaurs with dino-shaped nuggets, my mouth, and a giant pool of ketchup.

My Golden Days is undoubtedly anchored by the always captivating performance of Mathieu Amalric, who perfectly represents the adult behind the retrospective and introspective journey down memory lane.

movie_review_blurb: The film not only focuses on the political effects of drone warfare, but also the devastating psychological toll it takes on these operators.

The next-level low brow humor in The Brothers Grimsby makes Adam Sandler's worst film look like a Stanley Kubrick production.
The story is only as compelling as the people who keep it moving forward. Pilou Asbæk and Tuva Novotny are both soldiers in their own respect, trying to keep evil at bay.

Chet Baker's life played out in much the same way, but he came to terms with the fact that he was born to be blue. His self-awareness over his self-fulling prophecy shows in his music as he uses his trumpet as an extension of his own emotional turmoil.
Made with love for fans, this is an indulgent but enjoyable film about the band and the places that have inspired their music.
The style may have dated but the motives which drive the film still feel fresh and energetic.
Relentless, profane, cynical and bitterly funny, this still ranks among the best work by Nicholson and Ashby. An exhilarating trip from start to finish.
A quiet, intelligent, beautifully shot yet oddly distant biopic of post-punk's dark prince. The legend remains intact.
Lolita, with its acute mix of pathos and comedy, and Mason's mellifluous delivery of Nabokov's sparkling lines, remains the definitive depiction of tragic transgression.
Made with Bergman's usual flair for striking visuals and intelligent characterisation, this is rewarding dissection of middle-aged love that manages to be incisive, compassionate and hopeful.
movie_title: En Lektion i Kärlek (A Lesson in Love) (1954)

movie_review_blurb: So far out it ain't never coming back. This flamboyant vehicle for The Beatles' music is boldness exemplified - even if it does frequently trip on its own ambition.
The landscape speaks louder than words in this atmospheric journey through emotional extremes.

Raw, ragged, rambling and romantic - if the sound of a furious violin drifting down the alley quickens your pulse, you may find Gatlif's gypsy drama a seductive and potent experience.
Bergman at his most compelling, detailed and witty. An astonishing and deeply rewarding achievement.
Powerful and thought-provoking allegory that mixes politics, sexuality, myth and art.
Scattered moments of rawness aside, the master of the spiritual crisis directs an unbalanced and uncharacteristically unconvincing melodrama.
One of the least convincing political satires of the millennium so far - no bite, no vision and no laughs.
A powerful and thought-provoking film that succeeds equally as sad human drama and compelling thriller.
Visually exhilarating but also purposefully - and pointlessly - outrageous. Not for the faint hearted.
Cynical, sophisticated movie-industry-murder-mystery made with great attention to detail, and still one of the best examples of Hollywood turning the camera on itself.

Knocked up hurriedly, you feel, in between Apatow's other projects, Walk Hard is the feted writer-producer's first fumble. As Spinal Tap's Nigel Tufnel might have put it, this one only goes to two-and-a-half.
movie_title: Walk Hard: The Dewey Cox Story (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Despite heavy subject matter this is an ambitious and worthwhile attempt to get under the skin of its characters, full of striking images and played with great power by Henning and Malmsten.
True, the various strands are never bound together, but with material this sumptuous it really doesn't matter.
Sprawling and unfocussed but still a fascinating window onto an unreported world.
A brilliantly animated, deliciously macabre and strangely touching triumph.
Touching, comic, visually inventive and emotionally convincing, this remains a jewel in the crown of Disney's golden age.
Highly enjoyable, great looking animated adventure that combines its touching storyline with plenty of wit and style.
Lumet channels Pacino's relentless energy into a sustained and blackly comic study of hopeless desperation.
It's very funny. It's slightly pathetic. It's comforting in a hey-nobody's-human kind of way.
movie_title: A Complete History of My Sexual Failures (2008)

movie_review_blurb: There are some great comic set pieces with a seize-the-day vibe for teens.
Memorable, thought-provoking and courageous.
A bit like an album by The Doors: faultlessly good-looking and loaded with dramatic import. Then you get up close and it turns out there's not much there at all.
John Dahl creates an intelligent and character-driven crime-drama built around solid performances by Damon and Norton.
A fascinating collaboration between two of French cinema's great talents which, in its strange atmosphere, poetic dialogue and creepy tone, has lost none of its ability to shock or compel.
If you already love U2 your conviction will be strengthened. If you hate them, it will confirm your worst fears. Either way, the 3D technology is fantastic.
An impressive and enduring evocation of time and place, this is a moving low-life drama built around Oscar-winning writing and performances.

Fascinating, perplexing and infuriating in equal measure, this spectacular example of dreamlike filmmaking deserves to be approached with an open -- or opened -- mind. Every aspect is ambiguous, but the rewards are there.
movie_title: L'année dernière à Marienbad (Last Year at Marienbad) (1961)

movie_review_blurb: Rewarding, if sombre, slice of Swedish street life that demonstrates Bergman's trademark visual ingenuity and expert characterisation.
A sporadically entertaining but uneven media satire that never quite delivers on its clear sense of moral outrage.
This is tense, dense and highly stylised psychological drama. Visuals, dialogue, characters and tone are all expertly judged, and the critical reception launched Bergman's career.
The drama takes precedence over comedy but the wry tone makes this one of the smoothest and most accessible films from the early stages of Bergman's career.
Nicholson gives one of his best performances in this magnificently shot and lingeringly powerful thriller.
Louis Malle was just 25 when he made this moody piece of Gallic pulp fiction about a girl, a gun and a broken lift.
movie_title: Elevator to the Gallows (Ascenseur pour l'échafaud) (1958)

movie_review_blurb: Bleak, complex and undeniably demanding, this is a rewarding example of a singular talent stretching himself and his medium to the absolute limit.
movie_title: Diary of a Country Priest (Journal d'un curé de campagne) (1954)

movie_review_blurb: The Citizen Kane of chaotic trash, this is car crash cinema at its most compelling.
An atmospheric and unsettling mix of European style and Hollywood muscle, this is a beautifully shot and thought-provoking film about lost love.
Period piece, polemic or tripped out hippy whimsy -- Fantastic Planet is all of these and lingers in the system long after ingestion.
A fresh and fascinating treatment of an abiding myth.
Rarely very stimulating to watch, but significant in the evolution of audiences', critics' and censors' attitudes to film.
movie_title: I Am Curious (Blue) (Jag är nyfiken - en film i blått) (1968)

movie_review_blurb: An expertly executed adaptation of the classic novel. Great indeed.
Henry Fonda and Katharine Hepburn both shine in an impressively executed Hollywood drama.
The atmosphere is potent, and it's impressively shot, but there's also a terrible lack of cohesion that makes the film's desperate reach for meaningfulness look increasingly laboured.
Onibaba graphically illustrates that brutalism, art and allegory can co-exist to spellbindingly powerful effect.
A fascinating, infuriating, cryptic allegory featuring a performance from Terence Stamp as memorable as his brilliant blue stare.
The formidable triumvirate of Bogarde, Losey and Pinter each stamp their personalities on this deliciously unpleasant film.
Ambitious, stylised British satire. Written and acted with conviction, it pulls no punches.
Powerful, gripping, urgent.
Brave, if flawed, attempt to marry the marginal to the mainstream. Cruising suffers from a lack of discipline but there are some memorable and unsettling moments.
A blazingly intense sci-fi thriller and a blinding visual experience.
Not actually that funny ha ha, but a sensitive and unforced little film about the aimlessness of post-graduate life.
A bleak and overwrought yet powerful drama.
By Meyer's terms this is an uncharacteristically conventional B-movie but there's still more than enough of his prurient panache to ensure it's well worth a look.
Bolt's writing is elegant, vivid, shot through with a mounting sense of irony, and both Scofield and Shaw clearly relish their roles.
Spielberg's first film finds the director ruthlessly exploiting a devastatingly simple premise to extraordinary effect.
With its commentary on art and fantasy, this is a radical experiment in non-linear filmmaking.
movie_title: Céline et Julie Vont en Bateau (Celine and Julie Go Boating) (1974)

movie_review_blurb: With its raw performances and lyrical dialogue this is a sombre, resonant, lingering drama about family dysfunction and emotional frustration.
Spielberg lets the story unfold at its own pace, invests the dialogue with pleasing zip, and demonstrates a level of visual ingenuity that becomes the film's great strength.
Southern Gothic at it most vivid and grotesque. With its magnificent central performance from Brad Dourif, this is an unlikely late period triumph from John Huston.

The two charismatic leads prevent this from failing entirely, but the tone is shallow and insincere, largely because Linson wants to do what Thompson never would, which is to please all of the people all of the time.
Skilful performances, subtle visuals and the power of Delaney's writing all contribute to a landmark in British cinema.
Monumental in both scale and running time, it's still one of the most spectacular undertakings in film ever seen.
A lost classic.
movie_title: Le Feu follet (A Time to Live and a Time to Die) (The Fire Within) (1963)

movie_review_blurb: A stark and haunting conclusion to Bergman's main period that combines an intelligent approach to weighty issues with the director's visual flair.
Subtle but sharply observed, it remains one of Bergman's most watchable and rewarding dramas.
Proceed directly to the 'S' section of your local video shop and rent Shaun Of The Dead again instead.
A grand tribute to the power of love.
Uneven and oddly compromised in tone, Choke is a competent enough black comedy, but in the shadow of that other film, it never shines.
Achieves the highly improbable by making one of the most exciting events of the 1960s look really boring.
A sensitive, low-key, touching drama about the complicated issues surrounding international displacement.
An enjoyable if rather pallid rendering of Carroll's classic tale.

This provocative, proudly partisan but consistently entertaining doc is compulsory viewing not just for everyone working within the media, but for anyone who watches TV, reads the papers, surfs the net or has to walk down a city street.
Some great performances and a raw taste of life on the streets of Jamaica, but too ragged and rambling to explain why this music matters.
Cirque Du Freak: The Vampire's Assistant is a film with a chronic identity crisis and no clear idea where it's headed.
movie_title: Cirque du Freak: The Vampire's Assistant (2009)

movie_review_blurb: A fascinating documentary about a life lived on the cutting edge of technology, and the definitive film about the net's own coming-of-age.
A worthwhile doc about an unreported arm of the alt-rock industry.
One of the sharpest male-oriented comedies of the 1990s.
A deftly assembled, wry and touching self-portrait of Agnès Varda as both a filmmaker and an endearing, indomitable spirit.
movie_title: Les Plages d'Agnès (The Beaches of Agnes) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: The enjoyably sarky tone conceals a sympathetic and frequently very funny documentary.
An unconventional yet haunting documentary that shines a strange new light on life in modern Lebanon.
The raw power of the story isn't always very effectively harnessed but the level of conviction is certainly impressive.
Wintour and her colleagues are well-dressed company, but what's really going on stays behind closed doors.

The strange power of those final moments - at once tender, tragic and triumphant - grant this unassuming drama about saying goodbye to Solo the status of a minor masterpiece played in an appropriately minor key.
A fascinating introduction to the big issues in modern philosophy, presented with a pleasantly light touch.
Doesn't quite justify the enormous plaudits heaped upon its shoulders, but a warm-hearted comedy-drama with its own likeably odd sensibility.
Haunting, harrowing yet profoundly enriching. The Road is the most powerful and moving post-apocalyptic film of the twenty-first century.
A sombre exploration of religious faith in all its various guises, directed by Dreyer with a quiet but deep seated compassion for his characters.
There isn't a scene here which isn't strikingly shot and the final impression is of something personal, mysterious and yet frequently profoundly resonant.
Unarguably one of the greatest documentaries ever made, and an intimate portrait of the reality behind a thousand blue collar dramas.
Insufficiently racy in tone as well as pacing, this accomplished but bland costume drama is Dangerous Liaisons' poor cousin.
Like much of Russell's work, Altered States is ostentatious and pretentious yet genuinely engaged with ideas and style.
Hughes' penetrating insight into the minds of 1980s kids makes this one of the best films to bear his name.
An elegant melodrama, acted and directed with precision. Let it unfold at its own unhurried pace and the rewards are ample and long lasting.
An intimate portrait of Britain at war, full of fascinating and valuable footage, put together with Jennings' humanity and wit.
Both bland and slightly daft.
Visually and dramatically, Lee pulls out all the stops, but it's Washington's performance that really energizes the film, and he's an exhilarating presence throughout.
This is an impressive spectacle, rightfully lauded for its myriad innovations. But the sentiments it expresses are pretty damn ugly.
Funny, disturbing, tragic and deeply addictive.
A quality cast, polished writing and the atmospheric evocation of Soho and Whitehall sleaze make for a powerful depiction of Ward's fall from grace.
Mysterious, compelling, visually inventive, The Return is a quiet but intense metaphysical-drama of great emotional impact and insight.
Short and to the point, this is a rewarding mix of punchy storytelling and sensitive characterisation delivered with immense wit and style.
movie_title: Bab el hadid (Cairo Station) (The Iron Gate) (1958)

movie_review_blurb: A quietly intense, strikingly shot coming-of-age drama, Fish Tank establishes Andrea Arnold as a lyrical chronicler of marginalised Britain.
A skilfully written and deftly controlled thriller that refuses to be bound by budget limitations, Jetsam marks Simon Welsford out as a potentially significant new director.
Anderson's debut film is a small-scale delight.
Implausible, formulaic, too ponderous for young kids, not cool enough for teenagers and yet strangely hard to resist. File away under extremely guilty pleasure.

A low budget drama by a writer and director both making their feature debut, it's an uneven but ambitious enterprise which, like its characters, never knows which way to turn, or how best to exploit its own strengths.
François Truffaut's iconoclastic feature debut and one of the most enduring examples of the French New Wave.
A thoroughly researched and engagingly presented portrait of the composer.
A sombre description of age and regret delivered with a deceptively light touch. Wry, tender, full of sympathy and wonderfully acted by Jacques Nolot.
A low-key but genuinely insightful journey through a vanishing way of life.
movie_title: Profils Paysans: la Vie Moderne (Modern Life) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: A lyrical attempt to make sense of grief that appeals shamelessly to the heart rather than the head.
With its unusual blending of the formal and the mysterious, the intimate and the impressionistic, Helen is a film of quiet but deadly power.
Seductive yet unilluminating
Funny, tragic, brilliantly put together and eventually sweetly uplifting. This is the closest thing we're going to get to a sequel to This Is Spinal Tap.
Put away your eight-sided dice and go seek this immensely likable, sparky little comedy about fantasy, reality and love conquering all.
Bleak yet powerful, hushed yet haunting, this is an extraordinary portrait of lives dissolving away into nothing in the chilly English countryside.
Small but sharp and extremely well observed.
Atmospheric in its early stages but a little too reticent towards the end, this is nevertheless a bleakly intriguing drama about the darker reaches of the male psyche.
movie_title: To Get to Heaven, First You Have to Die (Bihisht faqat baroi murdagon) (2006)

movie_review_blurb: A fascinating, entertaining and skilfully assembled documentary about the messed up business of war reporting, and the messed up men who do it.
McMorrow's ideas may be too damn bold and expansive for Franklyn to succeed on every level, but it's a striking debut from a writer-director unafraid to reach as high as he can.
Don't expect to come away a whole lot wiser, but for its duration this film is mesmerising, mysterious and startlingly beautiful.
Thanks to its grand scale and great central performances by Niven and Cantinflas, the original fantastic voyage still holds up very respectably.
A brilliantly pitched exercise in droll comedy with a tender message about seizing the day.
This is one of those once-seen-immediately-forgotten enterprises which avoids anything memorable or imaginative in favour of fast, functional, charisma-free busy-ness.
Azazel Jacobs' film is an enjoyably idiosyncratic tribute to his own eccentric family, and it adopts a fascinatingly novel approach to the strange anxieties of thirtysomething men.
Perez's film ought to be an hour-and-a-half of beery, dumb-ass fun. Instead it has the weary air of a genuinely disastrous disaster movie. Size, it seems, matters after all.

An amiable portrait of the artist as a scruffy slacker, and a useful jumping off point for anyone interested in investigating some of the cultural issues that marked the 1990s and the start of the new millennium.
Brilliant archive footage and blistering live performances - an exhilarating concert film.

Claire Denis has assembled a simple yet achingly touching little drama. On the surface it looks as if hardly anything's happening, but submit to the gently fluid style and it turns out everything is going on.
A clear call for tolerance, deftly executed by a director for whom the personal and the political were indivisible.
Cheerfully camp, terrifically enjoyable teen parody that ranks among Waters' best moments. Oh, and world -- meet Johnny Depp!
A touching, tender coming-of-age drama which balances gritty realism with an intriguing sense of the fantastic.
A smart, sharp British psycho-thriller.
Sacre bleu! C'est un perky British rom a la com avec un great self-mocking performance by Eric Cantona.
Taut, dark, brilliantly acted -- this autopsy on the emotional lives of the English intelligentsia is among Bogarde and Losey's greatest achievements.
An eye-poppingly vivid exercise in genre-busting filmmaking. Here is one of the most persistently intriguing directors of the 1960s at his most watchable and entertaining.
movie_title: Pierrot le Fou (Pierrot Goes Wild) (Crazy Pete) (1969)

movie_review_blurb: A slow but perfectly pitched drama that tells its harsh story with touching tenderness, quiet sympathy and an absence of sticky sentiment. The time it demands is amply rewarded.
movie_title: Maria Larssons eviga ögonblick (Everlasting Moments) (Maria Larsson's Everlasting Moment) (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Funny, touching and cheerfully unlikely in every sense, this ranks among the great British filmmaker's most enjoyable films.
Great retro design, but as comic satire this isn't so much soft-focus as out of focus.
Dynamically shot and paced like a thriller, the film has the density and moral prickliness of a good novel.
It's hard to muster much enthusiasm for a movie that leans so heavily on regressive culture-clash shtick and unimaginative stereotypes.
Endearingly quirky, just this side of precious, but so warm and deftly executed that you go along with it.
With its themes of alienation in the Internet age and cutesy indie-ish trimmings, the film will feel familiar to anyone who's seen a bittersweet romantic comedy from Sundance.
What gives the film its haunting pull, as well as its feminist undercurrent, is the filmmaker's palpable compassion for these women.
Brisk, precisely observed, and bracingly non-preachy in its examination of a very tricky subject.
The movie ever fully shakes off its air of skillfully executed experiment, but it's spirited and charming nonetheless.
How can anyone can get excited over something so grim and redundant?
Director Malgorzata Szumowska seems intent on drowning her film and her leading lady in campy erotic imagery.
The film is seriously tarnished by three blandly conceived main characters and some sulky, wooden acting.
movie_title: Un amour de jeunesse (Goodbye First Love) (2012)

movie_review_blurb: The dialogue is punchy, but the film lacks visual personality, and the insights into Sarkozy and France as a whole don't cut very deep.
Nimble and pleasant to watch without being particularly inspired or inspiring.
Despite its eccentric, boldly obvious central metaphor, the film feels bland and oddly inconsequential.
The film pulls off an impressive balancing act: It's bitter though not cruel, satirical without veering toward obviousness, deeply moving but never maudlin.

Less visceral and tense than the Dardennes' best work, but a beautifully wrought story of a troubled boy and the stranger who saves him, told with the filmmakers' customary skill and lack of sentimentality.
A consistently engaging documentary that's paced like a thriller and spiced up by a few colourful characters worthy of fiction.
movie_title: Page One: Inside the New York Times (2011)

movie_review_blurb: An engaging, dynamic study of mutual inspiration and unconditional love.
movie_title: The Ballad of Genesis and Lady Jaye (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Coming-of-age tales have been done and done again, but Jonathan Segal's Norman delivers a bracing twist on the genre.
Belgian filmmaker Lucas Belvaux offers a thoughtful and unsettling take on the kidnapping thriller genre, anchored by an excellent performance from French actor Yvan Attal.
"Melancholia" is aesthetically ravishing, but dramatically pretty dull.
An almost outrageously ambitious, shatteringly beautiful meditation on memory, childhood, loss, and figuring out one's place in the world.
Fresh and fast-moving, light but deeply-felt, a work of charm, imagination, and even surprise.
Its moments of transporting beauty and visual brilliance overcame my growing aversion to Wes Anderson's brand of ultra-stylized archness.
Veteran French filmmaker Bertrand Tavernier tackles a period drama about passion with dismayingly flat and detached results.
movie_title: La princesse de Montpensier (The Princess of Montpensier) (2011)

movie_review_blurb: A minor, feather-light film, but a vivid and often funny one.
Wildly ambitious both in form and in the ideas about gender, identity, society, and love that it digs into with infectious gusto.
Honoré's heartbreaking, gloriously directed and performed musical suggests that this most hipsterish and Parisian of French filmmakers is best when he sets his stories to song.
Experimental, funny, deliriously original and occasionally maddening.
A forceful argument about the dangers of unchecked greed and brazen lack of accountability.
A nimble and engaging documentary, less about a man than about a myth -- and about the experience of loving an under-loved artist.
A riveting spy procedural, crafted with journalistic rigor and great visual confidence.
Corny ... a revisionist fantasy of French heroism.
movie_title: La nouvelle guerre des boutons (War of the Buttons) (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Even as you wish the material had been reshaped into something riskier, you may find yourself appreciating the sincerity and unshowy workmanship that went into the movie.
Furiously paced, full of powerfully staged action and emotional nuance, and performed with great heart by a cast featuring faces both familiar and new.
Bleaker, quieter, and more despairing than its American equivalents, the film nevertheless plays like a smarter-than-average spin on any number of Hollywood thrillers.
Rarely has one of Allen's movies been so overstuffed with tired subplots and bland characters, and never have his beloved themes felt so superficially explored.
Jacquot injects a welcome shot of immediacy into the costume drama proceedings with an off-center vantage point and dynamic camerawork.
More than two hours and thirty minutes of bland images and platitude-heavy breakthroughs.
A fascinating, satisfyingly complex romantic thriller.
Salles brings evocative images, fresh faces, and some fine emotional shadings to the famous tale of friendship, love, sex, drugs, jazz, literature, and the American landscape.
Hong has fun zooming, panning, and toying with structure and narrative repetition, though the film doesn't have the powerful undercurrent of regret typical of his best work.
Not even Cronenberg's trademark high- and low-angle shots, as well as one glorious moment of erotically charged Cronenbergian body horror, can stir the film from its stylish torpor.
Formally rigorous, but it tosses around the same few ideas about mutual exploitation, racism, and sex for two hours without getting anywhere deeper or more revealing.
Overlong and obvious, with a whimsical score by Alexandre Desplat, as well as a few Fellini-esque flourishes, failing to liven things up.
A heavy-handed, visually insipid take on the Arab Spring and its impact on various segments of Egyptian society.
Mungiu loses himself in broader questions of religion and love, and after a gripping hour, he started to lose me too.
The film's breezy, brutal mix of violence, romance, and redemption feels like nothing new, and Hillcoat never slows down to ponder what any of it means.
It lacks the dark streak of unpredictability that made Certified Copy a slightly richer viewing experience. Still, the film is never less than pleasing to watch.
The movie takes a contrived-sounding romance and turns it into a visceral, idiosyncratic exploration of battered bodies in search of souls.
movie_title: De rouille et d'os (Rust and Bone) (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Dominik's frontal critique of US-style capitalism may be facile, but it gives the movie a bristling anger and a more lasting burn than other recent offerings in the same genre.
A sober, gorgeously directed portrait of an elderly couple facing terrifying questions of life and death.
Lurid, touching, and not quite like anything I've ever seen.
Warm and moderately engaging, though it has little of the shivery visual power or narrative risk-taking that made Take Shelter such a discovery.
Julian Schnabel's stylistic effects can't save this plodding, earnest historical epic that chronicles 50 years of Palestinian struggle through the stories of four different women.
Certified Copy plays like an exercise, and one whose talky script should have been tightened, but it's a provocative and strikingly shot one.
Wrongheaded, off-putting portrait of Midwestern family dysfunction.
The Girl from Monaco is so briskly plotted ( ... ) that it's easy to overlook the sharp, even feminist observations made about male friendship and sexuality.
movie_title: La Fille de Monaco (The Girl from Monaco) (2009)

movie_review_blurb: The White Ribbon is a striking, in many ways indelible work, and it's tempting to be carried away by Haneke's craft and assurance as a filmmaker.
( ... ) Fish Tank feels more fluid, more passionate than other recent English films about the wretched working classes.
We don't come close to understanding Jeanne's very particular choice of fabricated victimization, and Téchiné, erring too much on the side of enigma, doesn't seem to, either.
movie_title: The Girl on the Train (La Fille du RER) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Blue Valentine is a devastating dissection of a young marriage in crisis that is written, directed and acted with passion and clarity.
Although smoothly directed, A Bottle in the Gaza Sea has little visual personality or dramatic urgency.
movie_title: A Bottle in the Gaza Sea (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Neither sufficiently funny to work fully as comedy, nor emotionally involving enough to succeed as a drama, the movie is one of Allen's blander efforts ( ... )
movie_title: You Will Meet a Tall Dark Stranger (2010)

movie_review_blurb: This somewhat sensationalist yet consistently gripping documentary traces the history of nuclear proliferation and spells out, in chilling terms, the danger facing everyone ( ... )
( ... ) a crisp and engaging though extremely conventional follow-up that updates themes explored in the so-so original with a fair amount of savvy.
Scott gives the proceedings an air of sombre importance, resulting in a film that (...) feels strangely laboured and lacking in the pleasure that even the darkest adventure can provide.
Silent Light is a hard film to love, but it just might be an even harder one to shake.
Thoughtful as it is, the movie lacks the poetry or point of view to see its idea through with force.
An affecting, gracefully crafted Peruvian film that struggles to breathe under the weight of too much allegory and symbolism.
movie_title: The Milk of Sorrow (La Teta Asustada) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Jennifer Lynch's nasty little crime procedural is not much more than an exercise, but it's a vivid, smartly executed and refreshingly eccentric one.
After a 10-year absence, French filmmaker Erick Zonca is back with a flawed but gripping English-language thriller powered by a superlative Tilda Swinton.
This French-directed English-language film squanders a fun genre--the kidnapping thriller--in favor of an exceedingly grim and insipid exercise in globetrotting sadism.
A year of uncommonly strong French releases hits its peak with Abdellatif Kechiche's richly entertaining and complex humanistic saga about an extended French-Arab family in the south of France.
movie_title: La Graine et le Mulet (The Secret of the Grain) (Couscous) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Cult director Abel Ferrara bites off more than he can chew with this murky, unfocused exploration of religion and faith in the age of media madness.
The result is an uneven and unwieldy hodgepodge of visions and styles that collectively carry a faint whiff of futility.
The outcome often amounts to an impressive slideshow instead of a fluid, substantial piece of work that involves and challenges us.
One gets the feeling while watching Time to Leave that the feisty director is, for the first time, bored by the story he's telling.
Match Point proves that Allen, at 70 years old, is very much still in the game.
As the credits started to roll, I came to a pleasant and all-too-rare moviegoing realization: The smile that had crept across my face during the very first scene had never left.
Days of Glory is -- disappointingly, but not unsurprisingly -- a dull, plodding war film bursting with noble intentions, but ultimately wearing its agenda a bit too much on its sleeve.
A stylish, fast-moving but disappointingly superficial portrait of a gangster's violent rise to infamy.
A graceful melodrama with the feel and texture of an absorbing novel.
What might have been a condescending social-issue drama about oppressed servants or a shrill send-up of the ruling class instead becomes a carefully etched character study.
The movie leaves you with the depressing feeling that not everyone deserves a biopic.
Tender, dryly witty, and shot with Coppola's typically exquisite eye for colour and detail.
A distinctive, touchingly old-fashioned piece of work, and unmistakably one made by a director whose life has spanned eras.
A work of voluptuous imagination and teasing humour.
movie_title: Uncle Boonmee Who Can Recall His Past Lives (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Rather than serving up a historical film inflated with importance and flash, Beauvois keeps things hushed and spare, adopting a style that reflects the ritualized lifestyle of his characters.
Im doesn't develop the by-now predictable plot, and the film's sedate pace stifles any suspense from this love triangle tinged with class anxiety.
Director Claire Denis offers just enough insight and well-crafted imagery to redeem her otherwise uneven drama about a French woman living in an African nation ravaged by war.
Helena From the Wedding is written, directed, and played with such verve and deep, unshowy feeling that its insights on these tried-and-true themes come through with rare and startling clarity.
Saddling two game actors with a tone-deaf, charmless script, the film makes recent J.Lo vehicle The Back-up Plan look like Billy Wilder in comparison.
The filmmaker overloads his story with highly charged themes, resulting in a movie that feels almost arbitrarily heavy with misery of almost every conceivable type.
A sleek, smart, enormously entertaining film, (....) it has the feel of a classic Hollywood comedy at its snappiest.

What emerges alongside a crackling tale of political betrayal is a convincing portrait of an unconventional marriage, in which two stubborn individuals challenge each other to stay true to their moral standards.

Von Trier tests not just the audience's tolerance for blood-soaked images of genital mutilation, but also our ability to stay awake during some colossally boring and pretentious stretches of filmmaking.
A dizzyingly smart, confident, often riveting drama about the creation of the groundbreaking Web site.
Clark's warmest, loosest work yet, but it would have been better if the director had realized he didn't need to make us hate everyone else in order to get us to love these little dudes.
If you think about it, you'll realize how flimsy-and even lazy-it is; if not, you'll likely give in to its airy charms.
Even if you're like me and find most musical biopics depressingly formulaic, you might think Oliver Dahan's Edith Piaf movie is a slight cut above.
I was lulled by the gentleness of the film, and struck by how closely Ferran observes her characters, as well as how modern and subtle her insights are.
Besson is clearly aiming for something like a fairy tale, but a work this forced and self-absorbed can only end up feeling terribly earthbound.
Delpy has made something rare: a romantic comedy that feels spontaneous and handcrafted ( ... )
( ... ) so perversely fun that a few false notes-a pushy score and certain moments that veer toward a cheaper kind of melodrama-don't nag as much as they might have.
movie_title: Before the Devil Knows You're Dead (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Keret and Geffen observe situations with such a low-key, spaced-out humor that moments in which their depressed characters finally reach for human connection sneak up on you with unexpected emotion.
While it's hardly a great film, Tell No One is the rare convoluted thriller that actually makes you want to keep up with its far-fetched twists and turns.
movie_title: Ne le Dis à Personne (Tell No One) (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Breillat's unflinching instinct for the doomed, all-consuming pull of sexual obsession shakes the story up in rewarding ways.
movie_title: Une Vieille Maîtresse (The Last Mistress) (An Old Mistress) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Kristin Scott Thomas seems to want to move things in a ( ... )more challenging direction, but I've Loved You So Long is too polite, too bent on being emotionally accessible, to follow her.
Theres less than meets the eye in this lightweight comedy loosely based on Thomas Hardys Far from the Madding Crowd.
There are lots of cutesy stylistic touches (iris shots, deadpan framing), but few insights into how the protagonist's various identities (queer, Jewish, French) clash and come together.
A rich, compassionate, unflinchingly perceptive comedic drama that follows an English family and a few of their friends and relatives over the course of one year.
Lean and riveting, a model of clarity, economy and seamless editing, with a slow-building despair that leaves a sting.
Hahn ... injects what could have been another insipid studio hack job with a bracing shot of personality.

While Looking: The Movie isn't as astonishingly fine as Looking the series, there's enough greatness in it to make fans (we're out there!) agonize anew over the fact that, yes, this time it's over for real.
It capitalizes on the chemistry between Hart and Johnson, who convey what seems like genuine delight in each other's company - something that gives this bromantic diversion a giddy kick.
A disappointment, even for the Dolan faithful.
movie_title: It's Only the End of the World (Juste la fin du monde) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: A movie not even a mother could love.

The problem is that a movie like this - limp, lazy, generic - just doesn't cut it at a time when American indies and television offer sharp, witty, satisfyingly complex takes on the "Facebook generation."

The dynamic between the stars feels overly familiar at first (he's the incorrigible but good-hearted boor, she's the irritable scold), but their comfortable rapport is one of the film's most potent assets.
A delicate heartbreaker about friendship, desire and the occasionally blurred line between the two.

The kind of blithely confident, creatively impoverished dud that leaves you slightly stunned someone greenlit it, the movie has the distinction of feeling like a bad idea from its very first frames ...

Small but stirring, thanks mostly to Sarah Paulson.

An absorbing, delicately directed and acted father-daughter drama.

movie_review_blurb: Witty, briskly paced and consistently entertaining.

Ultimately, it's a solid update of a fondly remembered minor hit.
a mildly engrossing lecture on the pitfalls of fame -- drug abuse, failed marriages and egos run rampant -- all set to the melismatic bellowing of semi-catchy show tunes.

"Cowboys & Aliens" (loosely based on a 2006 graphic novel of the same name) provides a slick cinematic vehicle for two of the toughest actors of their generations.
"Friends With Benefits" excels at identifying then deconstructing the clichés of the romantic comedy -- as "Scream" dissected horror platitudes.
The best workplace comedy since "Office Space."
It's not that "Cars 2" is an unpleasant exercise in animated filmmaking. It's just such a perfunctory one. The sequel is about as captivating as a trip to the Disney store at the mall.

It's yet another variation of the uptight character who loosens up through the intervention of (blank). But the transition of Popper turning from corporate raider to familial guardian (and back and forth again) is unconvincing.

Park finds a way to turn very peculiar plots into easy-to-digest adventures

When it's scary, it's extra scary. Nails-in-the-armrest scary.
too generic to offer many scares
a raunchy comedy that also has an undercurrent of sincerity to it.
The setup to this haunted bayou tale isn't particularly exceptional, but the finale is eerie and downright fascinating.
When a movie's misogyny is battling its racism for screen time, you know the project is in trouble.
A not-so-subtle metaphor about popularity and puberty.
Bears is like a pitcher who is nibbling at the strike zone. It's always close to hitting the target, but often frustratingly offline

'Five hundred twenty-five thousand, six hundred minutes.' These opening lyrical lines of Rent also seem to describe how long it takes for a viewer to sit through the movie.
So visceral is the carnage and so believable are the victims' reactions to it that it's impossible not to get caught up in the story.
the quieter scenes far outweigh the noisier ones
For a picture so fetishistically obsessed with death, Running Scared is vibrantly alive.
Signs exploits fear of the unknown better than any movie since The Blair Witch Project.
once the fistfights, car chases and stray explosions begin to mount, the movie veers into exponentially dumb overkill.

it does a capable job of capturing a time and place, bringing to life several unforgettable personalities and illustrating the moral self-loathing of a writer whose real-life subject must die before he has a decent ending to his book.
Although the plot of this installment explores 'three unforgivable curses,' the sequel avoids the 'curse of the fourth film,' proving there is still a heap of charm left in this young wizard's tale.

a monotonous and often inadvertently campy romance that rivals The Hours as the most overrated movie of the decade
The 'zany' performances are like a well-oiled machine, and, consequently, much of the movie comes across as mechanical.
When Murrow cautions viewers they should 'not be driven by fear into an age of unreason,' the film seems more culturally relevant than anything playing at the multiplex.
The sight of the mighty ape taking futile swipes at bullet-spitting biplanes from the top of the Empire State Building remains one of the most awe-inspiring and utterly sad images in movie history.
The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe fares much better in its smaller, quieter moments that test the mettle and morality of its young heroes
movie_title: The Chronicles of Narnia: The Lion, The Witch and The Wardrobe (2005)

movie_review_blurb: The movie is so relentlessly impulsive that it becomes easier if the audience just cries 'uncle' to its stylistic arm twisting.
somehow the conviction that Queen Latifah brings to the project makes some of the film's dopier choices easier to forgive.
The way filmmaker Hancock addresses the material, one half expects Travis, Bowie, Crockett and the rest of the defenders to rise from their graves after three days.

Every year or so a movie gets released that is cherished more for its look than its actual content.

When hasn't a repressed Brit met a candid American and not ended up in bed together by the second act?
This quiet film gains its power from small moments and unforced, convincing performances.
[Lee]Tamahori keeps the pacing lively enough that he doesn't allow the audience time to linger on the many plot implausibilities

Ritchie's command of the visual medium is so skillful, his criminals so memorable and his writing so undeniably entertaining, that it's a wasted criticism to try and intellectually dissect [his] movies.

Unfortunately, the film's final act crumbles faster and more irreparably than a Ross Perot campaign.

For the most part, the film succeeds, with predictable complaints stemming from the stretch marks that plague all features based on TV/animated shows.

White usually goes beyond the surface veneer of his characters, finding a lurking humanity to those that society might easily dismiss.

The Hollywood adaptation admirably avoids the urge to sanitize the material -- this isn't Mighty Ducks in the Hood.

With her earthy prettiness and WASPish demeanor, Lane effortlessly shifts between soccer mom and sexpot depending on the situation.
If Phantom Menace resulted in mindless boredom, then Attack of the Clones at least offers mindless entertainment.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode II - Attack of the Clones (2002)

movie_review_blurb: The talented Nolan won't need to lose any sleep over whether he lived up to expectations.
The Sum of All Fears proves that the Jack Ryan franchise still has some legs. Most importantly, it also has a brain.

A genuinely fascinating piece of American history reduced by Woo to a near-psychopathic bloodbath full of transparent jingoism.
Mr. Deeds has more impromptu punchouts than a Source Awards get-together.
[Sam Mendes] balances visceral action with emotional resonance, never drifting too far away from the thread of what is essentially a very simple storyline.

Eastwood seems to relish the opportunity to play a man his own age.
On its own limited terms, Blue Crush is a complete success -- a genuine Billabong-hit of adrenaline.
Gordon-Levitt capitalizes on the best role of his career, one that justifies a potential Oscar nomination.

From the bravura title sequence ... to tracking shots of the criminals casing their target, Fincher is able to expand artistically while shackled to a claustrophobic setting.
The popcorn thriller manages to keep the viewer's disbelief at bay, while offering a deceptively smooth ride through some frequently bumpy territory.
For his character being such a die-hard Cubs fan, [Lance] Bass throws a baseball like an 8-year-old girl.
Neither a jingoistic exercise in military muscle (a la Top Gun) nor an existential parable about the futility of war (as in The Thin Red Line).
Sorcerer's Stone is that rare effort that successfully breathes cinematic life into a children's classic.

Going with this title is about as original as calling the movie Animal Houses.

movie_review_blurb: The Wachowski team is on a fast track to eclipse George Lucas for the title of Most Promising Filmmaker Who is Now a Complacent Hack.
The tense action scenes work better than the implausible romance.
This crime-oriented portrait of characters snared by their environment leads to an excruciatingly powerful buildup, before it surrenders to contrivance in its final act.

Underworld is neither scary nor particularly exciting - somewhat of a drawback for a monster movie - but there's something absorbing about a tale so steeped in its own universe that the rest of the world barely seems to exist.

Like a bullet shot from a rifle, this is one shiny, noisy and mechanical affair.

like Hanks' verbose professor, the Coens continue to justify some of the simplest ideas through heaps of complexity.

The most ambitious AND most flawed of the series.
movie_title: The Lord of the Rings: The Return of the King (2003)

movie_review_blurb: This could have been one of the great date movies. But only those hopeless romantics who are dating a stoned frat guy will be totally satisfied with this patchwork picture.

movie_title: Lara Croft Tomb Raider - The Cradle of Life (2003)

movie_review_blurb: Creators Moore and O'Neill always let on that they have a better grasp of history than the average reader. Director Norrington displays quite the opposite.

movie_title: The Lord of the Rings: The Two Towers (2002)

movie_review_blurb: Individual episodes of the Next Generation TV series were always clever at addressing social issues, even if they were cloaked in the hardware of futurism. Yet the movies have routinely devolved into one-dimensional battles of good vs. evil.

The film, like the music it spotlights, begins to drone.

Whereas a TV version of the same material might flounder, this slick, big-budget film works because there is legitimate doubt as to both the level of guilt of the accused and the outcome of the trial.

movie_review_blurb: The money of the film's title should refer to Paul Newman, because the actor's presence elevates this routine caper into a pleasantly bankable diversion.

Call it a post-nuclear Jekyll and Hyde story. Or King Kong with the ape role replaced by a scientist with intimacy issues. Or Shrek meets The Ice Storm.
The narrative grows increasingly reliant on laborious chase scenes and noisy shoot-outs.
It's as much of a guilty pleasure as the loud, adrenaline-fueled original -- maybe more so because it yields even lower expectations.

The movie is the latest in a snowballing line of routine culture-clash comedies that are so light they practically float off the screen.
It's always entertaining to watch a film that is an experiment in environment. As soon as its central conflict is put in motion, Phone Booth plays out as a tidy little thriller.
This political comedy is about as convincing as a campaign promise, and most of its jokes have been around longer than Strom Thurmond.
Despite modest aspirations its occasional charms are not to be dismissed.
All the philosophical/metaphysical rambling doesn't alter the fact that this latest Matrix is a visual movie, pure and simple.

an irreverent, imaginative and often just plain weird spin on the classic fairy tale
Visually, this project ranks among the best animated efforts to embrace the 3-D craze.

The project bears the unmistakable thumbprint of producer Guillermo del Toro ("Pan's Labyrinth"), with its themes of adolescent expectations and grotesque alternate worlds whose mystical denizens intersect with our own.
More admirable than entertaining.
An indictment of the American workplace and a piercing character study.
A science-fiction (heavy on science) adventure steeped in Einstein's theory of relativity that is equal parts enigmatic, exhilarating, elaborate and emotionally wrenching.
This engrossing, uplifting movie never runs low on battery power.
Although the overall story hangs together, the individual scenes often play like improvised goofing.
Director James Marsh won an Oscar for his incredible art-crime documentary "Man on Wire," and here he proves capable of walking a tightrope between science and sentiment.

From her first hesitant step on that dusty California hillside, viewers aren't just watching Strayed's experience; they absorb the experience as if it's their own.
The character as written is so pretentious and self-destructive that it's difficult for the audience to connect with his story.
Sondheim's angular, interval-hopping material feels like one continuous song interrupted by dialogue. The cast often seems to be talking over a musical score rather than singing.
Each scene introduces a new character with little explanation, all but abandoning the previous new face that was just presented. It's like that "Too Many Cooks" video minus the entertainment value.
Once the exposition is out of the way, "Blackhat" features so much stylized momentum that it's easy to get caught up in the far-fetched hoopla.
A shopworn thriller that succeeds on a rudimentary level. Based on the gender swap of its central idea, it might as well be titled "Attraction Fatal."
Provides such a tilted spin on a familiar genre that it's easy to pardon some of the labored excesses.
The film strives to be weird as often as funny. But it's such a good-natured kind of weird that the viewer can't help but succumb to this barrage of 'nautical nonsense.'
movie_title: The SpongeBob Movie: Sponge Out of Water (2015)

movie_review_blurb: The movie itself coasts on energy, even if its presentation teeters between charming and amateurish.

A profoundly moving study of two damaged characters.
It's a disarmingly affecting film, and very sad at points. A rumination on loneliness.
Delivers a slick, serviceable blend of romance and melodrama. Your typical love and sacrifice and bull-riding tale.
It horrifies. It disturbs. It rules.
'Get Hard' might be the perfect flick to show at your next frat party at the University of Oklahoma.

The drama has a wicked premise and some memorable one-on-one scenes, but it leads nowhere.
This is a movie where the characters are more interesting than the plot twists or comedic throwdowns (of which there are plenty).
movie_title: This Is Where I Leave You (2014)

movie_review_blurb: A mostly entertaining adventure that plays like "Lord of the Flies" meets "Cube" meets an intelligent design lecture.
This is a film rife with simmering menace.
Few movies are better suited for a dine-in theater.

The novelty has somewhat worn off after we've been bombarded by six previous "X-Men"/"Wolverine" efforts and umpteen other Marvel flicks. But the talent has never been better than in this rousing adventure.

Charming and compelling, even when you know what pitch is coming.
What actually resonates is the relationship between Rogen and Byrne. They completely nail the love/hate dynamic of new parents who view their 30s as both a fresh chapter and a death sentence.
One must go back to the Joel Schumacher "Batman" fiascos to find a director more disconnected from his superhero source material.
What helps the picture work - and makes some of the unnecessarily graphic bits easier to forgive - is the interaction between the two leads.
movie_title: A Million Ways to Die in the West (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Few movies have gone off the rails on a crazy train more disastrously than this comedy.
Even when ensconced in a traditional shoot-'em-up, the film still kicks around some heady ideas. If only there were some underlying momentum to energize such poetic, intellectual flourishes.
More characters, more montages, more singing, more dancing, more preaching - it's certainly more exhausting.
an entertaining mosaic that has more in common with "The Social Network" than "Any Given Sunday."
The lack of green-screen laziness makes the red, white and blue workmanship pop out that much more.
This is not wink-wink "Commando"-type violence; this is an immersive, documentary-style barrage of exploding heads, torture, guttings and graphic crime scenes - like a drug cartel home movie.
It rivals "Battlefield Earth," "Showgirls" and other touchstones of bad modern cinema. But it's the kind of bad that only a mad genius like Aronofsky can muster.
Whether adventurous Scout is getting his claw stuck in a clam or the fuzzball siblings are riding on the back of their mom as she fords a river, the movie is crammed with memorable images.

MacFarlane's fundamental misfire is tied more to the plot than the jokes. He makes a movie about determining the nature of a soul when the individual in question exhibits only behavior that is soulless.
This is a movie that is constantly ahead of the audience, where smart characters do smart things to thwart a seemingly smarter menace.
movie_title: Live Die Repeat: Edge of Tomorrow (2014)

movie_review_blurb: The violent, nihilistic and tedious revenge drama emerges as this year's standard for meaningless.

an uneven, often aggressively unlikable tale of awkward folks making rotten decisions.

incorporates intriguing morality debates into a space adventure about young recruits fighting intergalactic bugs. But it's very serious. Almost joyless. It's like "Starship Troopers" minus the campy humor and wanton nudity.

leans on goofy sight gags, unbridled edits, look-at-me camera moves and pounding techno music to liven up scenes of people typing on laptops.
