Unique and challenging, with a foreboding nature similar to - but less intense than - Goodnight Mommy, it's definitely an evolution in the horror genre.
It's an enjoyable return to Wonderland, but still missing the wonder.
This is the film that World War Z could have been.
The movie is definitely one for horror buffs; enjoyable and carefully curated with knowing winks to its audience. Jackson has a bright future.
A welcome addition for zombie lovers, who won't be disappointed.
Not one for the weak-stomached, Zombie fans will get exactly what they expect.
Realive is a bold movie, likely to become a modern sci-fi favourite.
Here Alone poignantly conveys a sense of isolation and delivers it in both a beautiful and a bleak way.
It's a solid feature - another example of the strong creative work coming out of Toronto - and definitely worth a watch.
The film could have easily fallen flat, straying into B movie or comedy territory, but it's a masterful blend of horror, drama and comedy.
You'll (probably) have more fun watching this than any other film this year.
There's plenty of jump scares, loud bangs, creative special effects and innovative uses of props.
With a bland script and a weak story, Dwelling lacks the killer instinct that you'd come to expect from most horror films and with nothing to get the heart racing, it all becomes a little redundant.

Overall, an enjoyable film in an unlikely but imaginative setting. The legends of horror can welcome The Miller with open, bloody arms. He's a great addition to the likes of Jason and Freddy and deserves a sequel.
...the film never goes into the deeper, more fascinating concepts that it could've tackled, which feels like a missed opportunity.
...one of the most entertaining and exciting films that 2017 has to offer.
...an exhilarating and emotional movie that kept me on the edge of my seat the entire time.
This film should have caused interest in the property to skyrocket. Instead, it left this reviewer ... disinterested in learning more.
The new Planet of the Apes series has been given a fitting and powerful conclusion.
movie_title: War for the Planet of the Apes (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Anti Matter is a sci-fi thriller that blends Jacob's Ladder and Memento with fascinating concepts.
Inspiring, life-affirming, and beautifully crafted, ... [a] documentary that highlights the importance of horror as a genre, as a form of art, and as a means of catharsis.
movie_title: To Hell and Back: The Kane Hodder Story (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Simply put, it's an absolute blast and I can't wait for more!
Ultimately, Pilgrimage is an unsatisfying film, one that winds up feeling pointless.
...a film that will leave you unsettled and will challenge your view on what it means to be a villain and what it means to be a victim...
...this is a powerful and challenging release, one that demands discussion and expects viewers to begin their own investigations and research into the subject matter.
What Joe Lynch has done is craft one of the most entertaining and exciting films I've seen in a long time.
Smart, scary, and undeniably beautiful, it will no doubt be considered one of the pinnacles of its genre.
Thelma is horror viewed through a lens of poetry.
...deeply unsettling, fantastically eerie...a phantasmagoria of surreal mystery.
...a bland entry in a trilogy that has great potential.
Before We Vanish is a beautiful, wonderful tale that explores what it means to be human when faced with the threat of extinction.
Makes your heart soar...as much as it makes it pump in fear.
Whether you love it or hate it, mother! will leave you shaken and inspired...
...a film that is poetic and subtle, a slow-burn, perhaps too slow at points, that culminates in a difficult, yet compelling ending.
...the film simply suffers from poor pacing, bad editing, and a ridiculous ending that is so implausible that it's actually laughable.
...a powerful, tense, inspiring Stephen King adaptation.
Vampire Clay isn't perfect, not by any stretch of the imagination, but it is one of the most gleefully absurd and visually engaging films I've seen this year!
An overabundance of pop culture references can't save Ready Player One from its own mediocrity
Upgrade is a pure adrenaline shot of sci-fi body horror thrills.
One of the most inventive, emotional, and terrifying films I've seen ...
These kinds of stories need to be told, not only because they ensure that we do not forget our past but also for our need to recognize the complicated nature of history.
... started off incredibly strong and petered out to a predictable and dull ending. Not great, not awful, it's certainly a disappointment.
Let me put your fears to rest before we go any further... YES, there are monsters in this movie, and HELL YES do you get to see them.
If you can battle through the unnecessarily long runtime, you'll come to an ending that is darkly satisfying.
Overly long, you'll get a really great slasher that is bogged down by uneven social and political commentary.
Tightly contained, surprisingly emotional, and undeniably entertaining, Bullet Head is a film that should not go unseen.
Annihilation is a bold, gorgeous, and stunning melting pot of horror, sci-fi, and drama, culminating in one of the most fascinating films I've seen this decade.
Some minor pacing issues aside, Jungle is, without a doubt, the most thrilling, exhilarating, and inspiring film I've seen this year.
Packed with gore and atmosphere, it suffers from pacing issues and an out-of-place score.
A beautiful but flawed adaptation.
Mon Mon Mon Monsters is exciting ... but there are serious issues with pacing.
Junk Head is a marvel of imagination, scope, and detail. While the story is a little thin and the ending was clearly left open for a sequel, there's a ton to love here.
From impeccably timed comedy to white-knuckle, anxiety-inducing tension, Creep 2 delivers all the goods.
Blade of the Immortal is Miike's hyper-violent self at its finest and it proves that he is just as capable now as he has ever been.
movie_title: Blade of the Immortal (Mugen no jûnin) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: [If] you're looking for something engaging or haunting, 1922 is about as barren as Wilfred's fallow fields.
Zahler's latest offering is an assault on your senses that sees Vaughn in one of the best performances of the year.
There is no doubt that Maus is a powerful film; but with so much going on, it ultimately takes away from the overall experience.
Never feels anything other than a single thread of a larger narrative.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Wings of Desire has an ingenuousness, a sweetness of spirit, that triumphs over the conventional rigidities of its calculation.
Perhaps the strangest and most rewarding romance you'll see all year.
Despite its occasional over-simplification, however, Bread and Roses is a powerfully affecting film.
The essential desire to 'change life and the world' is still there for you to see in Dali's painting and Buñuel's film.
movie_title: The Discreet Charm Of The Bourgeoisie (Le Charme Discret de la Bourgeoisie) (1972)

movie_review_blurb: Willingly exploits cliches of black and Asian manhood.
A remarkably average movie in every respect. Script, plot editing, acting, resolution, all add up to something like the degree zero of contemporary Hollywood cinema.
For me, the most poignant scene in the film occurs when Wigand has lost his home, spouse, and family to the enormous pressure of fighting a huge corporation, and 60 Minutes cuts his interview.
Offers far more than a thesis about repressed desire; it evokes and engages such desire, seeking its release.
movie_title: Todo sobre mi madre (All About My Mother) (1999)

movie_review_blurb: A riotous good time in the theater.
This film shrewdly brings forth two features of contemporary life which everyone suspects but no one seems to be able to prove.
This film kicks butt, and in doing so it also manages to suggest that your need for it and for other butt-kicking films is a late capitalist symptom of contemporary psychosis.
How much fun is all this? As much fun as being the only sober inhabitant of a bar populated by rich, drunk, ironic show-offs deliberately singing off-key.
Once the actual story element of The Do-Over kicks in, the movie's periodic lurches back to gross-out humour seem increasingly out of place.
It's the perfect date movie for couples so bound up in their own cynicism that they're able to classify the vocal style and range of their orgasms into eras before they were born.
The earlier version scores two great points over its remake. One, of course, is Peter Lorre's brilliant, wheedling turn as the oleaginous Mr Abbott. The other is its climax.
movie_title: The Man Who Knew Too Much (1935)

movie_review_blurb: The Unborn becomes rapidly tedious even as the body count racks up.

Twisted with black comedy, off-kilter performances, unsettling sound design and jolts of violence, Jennifer Lynch's eminently Lynchian psycho-thriller is far better than its fairly predictable final rug-pull.
This absorbing doc is a funny, heartbreaking reminder that we're all wounded survivors of the original war zone.
The moral horror and charismatic performances leave a deep impression.
movie_title: Flammen & Citronen (Flame & Citron) (The Flame and the Lemon) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: There's a saying that a masterpiece has already found its perfect medium. Snyder has done as good a job as anyone could have done. That's a loaded compliment. But as compliments go, it's a huge one.
A small, dark, simple love story with big, burning, complex emotions. If this really is Phoenix's final performance, it's one hell of a way to go.
Not the full story - not even close - but this is 'Iron' Mike Tyson as you've never seen him before. One of the most devastatingly personal on-camera confessionals ever put on screen.
The footage of the tiny figures riding these ferocious 50ft monsters goes past awe-inspiring into something almost indefinable.
Too loose and aimless to sit with Herzog's best, Encounters drifts along on its filmmaker's frostbitten humour and his ever-searching eye for weirdness and wonder.
movie_title: Encounters at the End of the World (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Rich, ingenious and frighteningly close to home, Selick's new nightmare puts him nearer to Guillermo del Toro and David Lynch than Tim Burton. See it in 3D. Then sleep with the light on.

Gorgeously rendered in subtly immersive 3D and full of organic cinematic nods, this is a rare, wondrous story of true love and dream-catching. Of holding on and letting go. You will believe a house can fly.
Through it all, Park's film never loses its big, bloody-fanged grin. Expect sex (weird), blood-drinking (through a straw), stabby-bitey violence (lots) and laughs (even more).

Boasting strong performances and lightened by a few flashes of much-needed easy humour, Precious is let down by Daniels' ropey direction - which leaves you feeling like it could/should have been a much better film.
movie_title: Precious: Based on the Novel Push by Sapphire (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Coppola's self-involved family drama Tetro feels like an attempt by the filmmaker to recapture his youthful for appetite for moviemaking and art. Which makes Tetro sound a lot better than it is.
For all the exquisite cinematography and fine performances, Bright Star remains curiously unaffecting.
One of the Potter franchise's breeziest entries yet offers flashes of darkness but lashings of teen tension. Less a movie than a set-up for next year's epic conclusion. Bring on V-day.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince (2009)

movie_review_blurb: It's thrilling to see that von Trier's vicious sense of mischief, his moviemaking skill and his desire to smash limits and expectations all remain undimmed. However you swallow it, this bizarre, hysterical melodrama is impossible to ignore.

Gripped with an unnerving iciness, Afterschool has style and smarts, but Campos never really manages to slice cleanly into his mega-relevant themes of voyeurism and violence, isolation and info-culture.
QT has let loose completely: flashes of cine-genius curdle with crude, crazy juvenility, although it doesn't stop this being his most purely enjoyable film since Kill Bill: Vol. 1.
The vintage surf footage packs some thumping wipeouts and there's fresh relish in the sidestory of local Hawaiian surfers handing out beatings to their gnarly foreign invaders.
A rewarding change of pace for Sam Mendes, Away We Go is a small, lovely film that gently sneaks up on you with unexpected depth and feeling. Let it.
Some new moves and old tricks from Tony Jaa, still packing a wallop but in need of a truly knockout narrative. Then again, when have you ever seen two men fighting on top of an elephant?
Red blood and black humour spurt hard as Thirst reveals itself to be one of the most deliciously skewed incisions into the vampire romance subgenre.

If The Cove isn't in the running for next year's Best Doc Oscar, there's something terribly wrong with this world. Gripping exposé, harrowing horror-thriller and devastating agitprop, it takes us to "a little town with a big secret".
Soderbergh's ultra-indie isn't about feelings - business and pleasure don't mix. But this intriguing, cerebral, beautiful little movie rings with cold, hard, ugly truths.
A jumble of kiddie slapstick and pointless chases.
Fresh, funny and subtly insightful, this daring little indie bromance feels like the movie Hollywood wouldn't have the balls to make.
As it geysers forward from that claret-soaked opening scene, V For Vendetta director James McTeigue's mega-violent B-movie packs shock and gore and, to be frank, not much else.
An enjoyably bloody homage to Universal's classic hair 'em, scare 'em monster. There's plenty of gore and guts to cheer; it just needed more of everything else: heart, horror, affection and artistry.
Zellweger's face looks stuck in a permanent wince. Oh wait, it's the clunking script about a spike-heeled career girl forced to move from Miami to Minnesota.
Not a lot of it adds up, but you can't say this dark Brit mystery isn't interesting.
By the climax, his truly ambitious, truly flawed film finally disappears into the 'time-space rift' (or whatever) to achieve some sort of cosmic transcendence.
Overlong and underwritten, this corporate-noir thriller is propelled by its gleaming good looks.
Lobotomised entertainment that's dark, violent, and hilariously dumb.
Dig deeper than the classy looks and the shovelful of psychological topsoil ... and there's nothing here that hasn't been done before -- and done better.
Mick Jagger? In a Brit gangster classic? Believe it. And believe that Performance is much, much more.
Deliberately Louisville-slugs its audience over the head.
It provides the thinnest of excuses for rerunning the 'dramas' of the night before, but it doesn't do anything to salvage the venerable formula.
The Rocky Balboa you were hoping for, dreaming for, and an astonishing personal triumph for Stallone. Bring on Rambo IV?
Guaranteed to thunder on the big screen.
Hoffman and Linney are wonderful -- underplaying so perfectly that crumpled, bittersweet truths continue to surface.
Crudely mangling Arthurian legend into Roman history, this creaky swords 'n' sandals romper trundles forward like a hurriedly upholstered TV movie.
Scatological grue, nudity, swearing, drug-taking and the chance to watch two grown men wrestle a midget...

Like much of his oeuvre, Scott's scaled-up movie is bigger than life - and lesser for it. But while never digging deeply or darkly enough to match its own grand vision of itself, slick technique drives the story forward with pace and style.
Thanks to its two leads, the film remains vivid, honest and deeply felt.

Dobkin's film is lit up by a couple of genius scenes: first, a siblings support-group attended by Frank Stallone, Stephen Baldwin and Roger Clinton; second, a superb in-joke triggering Spacey's redemptive thaw-out, stoking a festive glow against the odds.
Still fighting the good fight for the working man, Capitalism is entertaining but conspicuously bankrupt of fresh ideas and insights. By now, Moore is starting to feel like less.
Think of every scary-kid horror you've seen - this was how The Unborn was made.

This stunningly derivative Latin ghost chiller might have had audiences Jackson Pollocking their underwear 10 years ago. Now (unless you've spent the past decade down a well), only the sheer poverty of ideas is terrifying.
It's tough to beat as an outrageously phlegmy deposit in Hollywood's spittoon.
Even if the director eventually hard-pedals her pantheist imagery into cliché, this inconvenient truth is discreet, intimate and regularly surprising.
Back, baby, back. An excellent police procedural and a personal triumph for Ben Affleck, steering his younger brother to a performance that deserved louder applause from gong juries.
Gorgeous but thuddingly obvious...
Steep is more promo-reel than documentary.
The lasting soul of Thieves' pure cinema poverty-parable finally nestles in its deeply affecting father-son pairing in which seven-year-old Staiola dazzles as one of cinema's wonder-kids.
Jean-Claude Van Damme, B-movie megastar gone straight-to-video, is back with a career-best performance in one of the coolest indie movies of the year.
No doubt about it, Allen's latest throwaway rom-com is utterly silly, forgettable and predictable. It's also his most purely entertaining film in years.
Stylishly shot, this tense Spanish thriller sees the couple lost in a mountain wilderness while being hunted by an unseen sniper.
movie_title: El Rey de la montaña (King of the Hill) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Turkish director Nuri Bilge Ceylan's aching film is driven by complex, powerful performances. Too many angsty silences deflate the tension, but it's gripping while it lasts.
Gripping, elusive and something to be experienced, Che Part Two continues to offer up surprises, frustration and - above all - fascination.
It's a movie for Eastwood fans. Which should mean it's a movie for you.
One thing's for certain: whether it's a meditation on guerrilla warfare, on Che or on moviemaking itself, you've seen nothing like it and are unlikely to ever again.
Totally watchable, totally forgettable.
A desperate violence and urgency spills out in the film's flash-point set-pieces - not least a sensational car chase, shot through a windscreen, hammering rain and a blur of fear.
Date Night is held together by a terrific cast that make a little go a long, long way. Somewhere in all of this there was a seriously good movie. As it is, we have a seriously weird one.
Scenes spark then fade, until the sinuous climax arrives with collision force.

Every empty corridor is full of unease. The carnage is frantic, bloody, relentless. The drama comes veined with black humour. And when the jolting finale hits, you realise this could easily be horror's next big franchise.
Big, brash and very funny, Joss Whedon's Avengers is equal to the sum of its parts - and for once, that's no faint praise. Suit up.
American Pie's characters have grown up and settled down. Don't worry, the franchise hasn't. More than a decade on, Reunion opens with two wank jokes and never looks back.
Fluidly lensed and unsettling for an hour, writer/director Kieron Hawkes' debut thins out badly in the final third, leaving the charismatic Anderson to prop it up.
Shredding while it lasts, Silent House is really just a fun campfire horror tale.
Anderson's film breezes irresistibly on style, charm, a lovely score by Alexandre Desplat and that winning indie ensemble.
You can't shake the feeling that Hillcoat just should have gone for broke with his florid, bloody drama.
It's a much better hitman movie than an economic critique. In fact, Dominik calls it a comedy.
Not as frightening as Alien, not as thrilling as Aliens, but a 3D sci-fi blockbuster that's easily the saga's most spectacular entry.
The bleak, dramatic scenery and sheer oddness here just about keep up the intrigue.
Smart dialogue, a gifted ensemble and good intentions from Jennifer Westfeldt, but her grown-up romcom can't quite escape feeling like a sitcom on the big screen.
An effortless, emotional, funny little indie that few people will see. Be one of them.
Freestyle, funny but finally just too repetitive, Ice's affectionate home-movie needed someone to structure it into a deeper documentary.
movie_title: Something from Nothing: The Art of Rap (2012)

movie_review_blurb: The Lorax is immensely colourful, catchy and cheery. Then again, it's also gaudy, bland and recycled. You can do better.
Grungy, compact and delightfully violent, Dredd wants to hit you as hard as it can.

It's this terrific ensemble that offers real bang for your buck here - Mendelsohn's skaghead Aussie is a brilliant creation - as Dominik builds a grimy world of bad men, brutal violence and stylish cinematics.
An amusing, thoughtful romcom about love, literature and coming of age. Whatever age.
Argento's masterpiece is a movie in which nothing and nobody makes sense.
Surprise: Twilight has discovered a fresh sense of danger and energy.
movie_title: The Twilight Saga: Breaking Dawn Part 2 (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Not a masterpiece, but a funny, violent, very entertaining crowdpleaser.
Brace! Brace! Smart entertainment from Zemeckis, superior acting from DW.
Fades in the mind all too quickly.
movie_title: A Liar's Autobiography - The Untrue Story of Monty Python's Graham Chapman (2012)

movie_review_blurb: [A] massive, magnificent historical biopic.
Brimming with colour and passion, it pulls its emotional kick from tremendous performances, not least from Vivien Leigh and Clark Gable as the love-hate lovers.
Pulsing with loud style, it's a vibrant, vibey joyride.

Man Of Steel just keeps bouncing from big scene to big scene. What's missing is the strong connective tissue inbetween them - the film doesn't earn its big moments and this highlight-reel cinema leaves little room for character development.
Flying as high as an eagle or scampering across the tracks like a lizard, Verbinski's camerawork is off the-chain and the visual-effects are first class.
A confident sidestep from District 9 rather than an ambitious leap forward, Elysium confirms Blomkamp as an expert genre director. Question is now: can he become more?
Yes, it sounds like hard work. But Tarkovsky gets away with the doleful pace and elusiveness thanks to one thing -- his breathtaking eye for simple, stunning beauty.
Powering forward on a punky soundtrack and a don't-give-a-damn grin, this comic-book actioner never stops moving long enough for you to think about how little sense it makes.
A handsome new sci-fi adventure that feels rather familiar. Enjoyable enough while it lasts, John Carter is big on ambition and disappointingly short on action.
Edged with cynicism and wit, Tuschi's film can't hide its admiration - but real answers lurk tantalisingly out of reach.
Oddball comedy instantly kills zombie scares - the neck-ripping is bloody but boring - leaving you clinging to the fun moments when director Paco Plaza nails it.
A film that awes and bores in frustratingly equal measure. Visually and musically, it's a triumph. Dramatically, it needs some re-wiring.
Everybody hurts, all the time, as Ben Stiller aces his dramatic turn in another witty, discomforting comedy drama from Baumbach. No happy endings here, but a climactic note of hope feels hard-earned.
Infinitely assured moviemaking.

Better than Predator 2, not a patch of the original. A throwback game-of-death, Rodriguez and Antal's sequel hurls out plenty of gore but few surprises. Left wide open for unlimited sequels, could this be a vehicle for RR to blood new directors?
Adapted from Brian O'Malley's comic-book saga with breakneck stylistic verve by Edgar Wright, Scott Pilgrim Vs The World is the ultimate geek wish-fulfilment flick.
Another quality Bong hit.
Stone swaps fury for fun. But it sure beats another Fidel Castro interview.
A strange, fascinating vision of art consuming its maker that lodges in the mind.
movie_title: Over Your Cities Grass Will Grow (2011)

movie_review_blurb: If we hadn't already seen it in Swedish, we'd probably be talking up Reeves' dark, gripping vampire remake -- and its two lead performances -- as something rather special. Actually, we're going to do that anyway.
The film this year you'll want to miss but mustn't. See it. Thank us later.
Not quite Disney at its very best, but a fast-moving, witty, heartfelt animated CG 'toon that sees the Mouse House leaping into the new era of animation with some style.
Engineered to do exactly what you want: smash, crash and gurn. Another B-movie franchise for The Stath? Quite possibly.
Despite leaving you flailing at times with its sheer weight of detail, this superior documentary is packed to the gills with enraging, depressing answers as to what ignited the 2008 recession.
An enjoyable teen rom-thriller that never swerves off the beaten path but always keeps its footing. Expect a franchise, and career boosts for Pettyfer and Agron.
Really need to watch District 9 again. Immediately.
Despite wobbling under the weight of some hefty ideas while straddling two genres, this sci-fi mystery surprises by emerging as a sweet, star-powered romance.
This indie drama puts its best foot forward, only to strut face-first through every cliché in the genre.
Marsden, Bosworth and Skarsgård are superb. But what was the point?
A dark drama that gleams with pure quality.
Melancholia is incredibly eerie, and is lent an exciting frisson by the authenticity of an actress and filmmaker with first-hand experiences of psychological trauma.
Crazy Stupid Love is funnier, smarter and more touching than your average cut-out-andkeep Hollywood relationship flick.
Crushingly bleak anti-drama erodes your interest with every scene.
Marsh's sensitive doc is a light look at some dark clues to the kind of creatures we really are.
Malick's spiritual odyssey is baffling, unique and overspilling with wonder.
A worthy, important effort - but not a great one.
Sobering stuff, especially when smart talkingheads - including former Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev and ex-US Secretary Of Defence Robert McNamara - confirm it's a matter of "when" not "if". Eek.
There's just enough sexy sex (gratuitous lesbians for good measure) and violent violence (too nasty at times) to keep this bumpy ride on track.
Gentle, touching and beautifully captured, this is the best surfing documentary since Riding Giants and a personal, genuinely painful true-life drama set on the brink of childhood's end. Discover it.
Don't be put off by the title. Wells harnesses 3D mo-cap wizardry for a children's adventure that balances storytelling and sci-fi.
Daring and different but just way too dark.
The filmmakers stay back, observing, for a restrained, intimate and poignant result.
A silly, snarling romp.
Nearly everything about Yi Yi is odd and wonderful.
An almost irresistible work of art.
[A] film of substance and poignancy.
Not a bad way to spend a couple of hours.
A documentary that is as thoughtful and inspiring as the music it celebrates.
movie_title: Amandla! A Revolution in Four-Part Harmony (2003)

movie_review_blurb: A pedestrian film that provides little more than a superficial treat.
A movie that's clever, hilarious and -- in its own stylish way -- ironic.
This documentary is a treat to behold.

When the old guys sit around and tell their stories, Standing in the Shadows of Motown catches magic on the screen -- a behind-the-curtain peek at some of the world's best-loved music, straight from the cats who made it happen.
movie_title: Standing in the Shadows of Motown (2002)

movie_review_blurb: Once you get into its rhythm ... the movie becomes a heady experience.
A portrait that stays with conversations as they unfold, stays with scenes as they progress naturally and stays with small moments that turn into poetry both beautiful and sad.
A timely look back at civil disobedience, anti-war movements and the power of strong voices.
movie_title: Le Fond de l'air est rouge (A Grin Without a Cat) (The Base of the Air Is Red) (1977)

movie_review_blurb: A touching, sophisticated film that almost seems like a documentary in the way it captures an Italian immigrant family on the brink of major changes.

[8 Mile is] more funny than foul, more inspiring than infuriating, more touching than not. In many ways, 8 Mile is a Rocky-like tale of determination and long odds that will appeal even to those who are turned off by most rap.
The jokes are sophomoric, stereotypes are sprinkled everywhere and the acting ranges from bad to bodacious.
A rare chance for viewers to eavesdrop on everyday talk in Tehran that, although fictionalized, must approximate what really happens in Iran's busy capital.
An Oscar-worthy documentary.

Ayouch takes a subject that could be thoroughly depressing ... and -- through a simple story line, dramatic acting and National Geographic-like shots of the city's rough and pristine edges -- creates cinematic magic.
movie_title: Ali Zaoua, prince de la rue (Ali Zoua: Prince of the Streets) (2000)

movie_review_blurb: A provocative movie about loss, anger, greed, jealousy, sickness and love.
movie_title: Alias Betty (Betty Fisher and Other Stories)(Betty Fisher et autres histoires) (2002)

movie_review_blurb: A seven-year time lapse that's full of drama, poignancy and some heartbreaking moments.
A counterintuitive film about a small schoolhouse in rural France, To Be and to Have gets its punch from simple scenes and conversations.
movie_title: To Be and to Have (Etre et Avoir) (2003)

movie_review_blurb: An unforgettable film.
The experiences of this family from Fairfield will resonate with moviegoers around the country.
This is Marker's masterpiece.
It's a movie that works on many levels, including symbolic and metaphorical.
Unforgettable movie.
A bittersweet film that tells the story of Palestinian life as eloquently as anything ever done.
Funny, ironic (in the best sense of the word), dramatic, sweet and metaphorical, Carnage never lets go of its witty mix.
The movie flounders in a way that calls too much attention to itself -- and is hurt by jarring and unbelievable plot twists.

Documentaries can be informative, entertaining and provocative, but rare is the documentary that makes you feel so engaged (and enraged) that it prompts you to action somehow. Tibet: Cry of the Snow Lion is that kind of film.
movie_title: Tibet: Cry of the Snow Lion (2003)

movie_review_blurb: By humanizing an immigrant/ refugee crisis that is not abating, Winterbottom does a cinematic service that happens to be damn interesting, too.
At times dramatic, sweet, funny and sentimental, Small Voices almost seems like a fable -- except that it's based on a real story and includes a subplot threaded with violence.
A good introduction to a man who almost defied description.
movie_title: Nusrat Fateh Ali Khan: A Voice from Heaven (2001)

movie_review_blurb: Illuminating.
Seeing Himalaya is to bear witness to a proud and rich people.
A kind of strange, existentialist comedy.
A movie that is not only achingly funny but also full of serious and philosophical truisms.
Fans of Nijinsky will savor every minute of Cox's work.

Because Eight Legged Freaks is partly an homage to Them, Tarantula and other low- budget B-movie thrillers of the 1950s and '60s, the movie is a silly (but not sophomoric) romp through horror and hellish conditions.
Do you really want to spend money watching what is essentially marginality, or would those dollars be better used to see a better film or even buy a good book?
It is enthralling and evocative, despite some flaws.
The film deserves some kind of honor for its campy originality, smart and funny dialogue, and provocative yet sensitive look at the making of a film circa 1969.
The film becomes an overwhelming pleasure, and you find yourself rooting for Gai's character to avoid the fate that has befallen every other Carmen before her.
For most of it's 117 minutes, Enigma delivers a powerful story from World War II that's based on real events.
The premise of Jason X is silly but strangely believable.
Quote not available.
Under the lens of Brazilian director Andrucha Waddington, love with multiple partners becomes a dreamy kaleidoscope of passion and possibilities.
Existential terror is just one of the many layers that give The Pledge a sheen that is sickening and yet satisfying to watch.
Reds, yellows, blues, and grays come alive in Pollock, letting viewers exhilarate in the glory of creating great abstract art.
An engrossing tale of class differences that reveals tiny details of one man's descent into hell.

This is not just a 'B-movie' -- it's a B-movie that fails to entertain on any level.
Its by-the- numbers plot is depressingly familiar, and each line of dialogue is so predictable that the script could have been generated by a computer.
It would be hard to overpraise Johansson -- who could hardly look more perfect for the part -- for her extraordinary ability to convey so much emotion with so few words.
Sanctimonious, relentlessly predictable and willfully ignorant of the period it's set in.
Despite its more tendentious moments and sometimes irritating slickness, Fog of War is every bit as fascinating and unnerving as its subject.
movie_title: The Fog of War: Eleven Lessons from the Life of Robert S. McNamara (2003)

movie_review_blurb: Unlike Woo's Face/Off or Broken Arrow, there are no stunts, special effects or kinetic moments in Paycheck that really blow you away.
Recycles gags from various, more successful gross-out and romantic comedies, but without any zest or imagination.
It offers a rare glimpse into the lives of the Iranian wealthy. And it does so in the service of a surprisingly bleak, radically class-conscious vision of Iranian life.
One of the best climbing movies ever made, doing justice to a sport that has not been well served by the cinema.
Quote not available.
An enjoyably spare and fast- moving French thriller.
For the most part it's either clunky (as when Alain speaks directly to the camera) or shrill.
A kind of art-house Showgirls -- which actually exceeds Showgirls in its self-indulgence, shallowness and sheer stupidity.
That it is such a powerful and indeed beautiful film is simply extraordinary.
The fine performances by Blanc and Melki give Belvaux' whole clever undertaking some needed weight.
A lazy and uninspired knock-off of the hilarious 2002 movie Road Trip.
Fails as entertainment, being so ineptly directed and written it often has the feel of a high school production by kids with more money and ambition than talent.
Mel Gibson's Passion, though well-acted, technically impressive and initially moving, is for the most part not beautiful and certainly not ennobling.
Becomes laugh-out-loud awful, with dreadful, lame lines delivered painfully badly -- as if a different screenwriter and director had taken over for the movie's final act.
A quietly compelling documentary that is refreshing in both form and content.
Probably the most enjoyable Hollywood update of a decades-old TV series since the first Brady Bunch movie.
Its thrills are too cheap to be worth a $10 movie ticket.
Quote not available.
Inept, tedious kitsch that even at its best feels like John Waters minus the joie de vivre.

More tedious than affecting, the film feels like an excuse for reproducing more of the kind of kinky imagery notoriously employed by fashion photographer Steven Meisel in his creepy pedophile advertisements for Calvin Klein.

The real triumphs in Igby come from Philippe, who makes Oliver far more interesting than the character's lines would suggest, and Sarandon, who couldn't be better as a cruel but weirdly likable WASP matron.
Hokey, embarrassing costumer.
Compassionate, funny and honest.
A lumpy and disorganized film that remains unsatisfying.
movie_title: Porn Star: The Legend of Ron Jeremy (2001)

movie_review_blurb: The genius of the This Is Spinal Tap team becomes even more apparent with each failed imitation, of which The Independent is the umpteenth.
Even more impressive is the way Haneke evokes violence without showing it, and whips up tension and dread without music or any of the manipulative tricks so popular among Hollywood filmmakers.
movie_title: Code Unknown (Code inconnu: Récit incomplet de divers voyages) (2000)

movie_review_blurb: Never less than breezily entertaining.
A far more impressive and affecting piece of filmmaking and storytelling than most movies put out by Hollywood this year, and offers, as a bonus, a glimpse into a fascinating, contradictory society.
The end isn't satisfying enough to justify their efforts and your time.

Many of the movie's targets are just too big and too obvious to elicit more than a smile of recognition, and the movie quickly degenerates into little more than a game of spot the (generally unfunny) reference for fans of the teen genre.
Despite the self-consciousness and occasional crudeness of the exercise, there is often a visceral intimacy to Makhmalbaf's depiction of the cruel, medieval oppressiveness of Taliban rule.
movie_title: Kandahar: Le soleil derrière la lune (2001)

movie_review_blurb: The demands of formula eventually stifle anything that even looks like inspiration or honesty.
Timely, powerful but underedited and messily structured documentary.
movie_title: Jung (War) in the Land of the Mujaheddin (2001)

movie_review_blurb: Terrific, surprisingly gripping true-life tale of a math genius battling madness.
This overlong but sketchy biopic by Michael Mann, in which style repeatedly tramples substance, actually does the great man a disservice.
Even by movie standards, the time-tripping in K & L doesn't work.
Ranks among Robert Altman's best work ever.
A beautifully filmed, scrupulously authentic but strangely evasive exercise in combat ultra-realism.
Impostor doesn't do much with its template, despite a remarkably strong cast.
Pale, stale teen comedy with a (lame) message.
Even though it's common knowledge that Park and his founding partner, Yong Kang, lost Kozmo in the end, you can't help but get caught up in the thrill of the company's astonishing growth.
The dialogue is dubbed into English by generic actors, whose phony, emotionless rendition undermines what's on the screen.
Creepy but ultimately unsatisfying thriller.
It tells a compelling story while making a devastating, entirely convincing argument about the corrosive effects of Chinese capitalism on traditional values and human dignity.
An inept, tedious spoof of '70s kung fu pictures, it contains almost enough chuckles for a three-minute sketch, and no more.
A gorgeously photographed, sun-baked fable about a rural vendetta.
Slack and uninspired, and peopled mainly by characters so unsympathetic that you're left with a sour taste in your mouth.
The filmmakers ... seem to have been inspired mainly by contempt for the audience: everything about their work feels lazy and slapdash.
A remarkably beguiling documentary, on a number of levels.
A cheap scam put together by some cynical creeps at Revolution Studios and Imagine Entertainment to make the suckers out there surrender $9 and 93 minutes of unrecoverable life.
So daring and unsparing in its depiction of the psyche and experience of adolescent girls that it's hard to imagine an audience that wouldn't find it deeply provocative despite a slow pace.
Highly entertaining escapist fare.
Almost from the beginning, you're jarred by lame gags that fall horribly, embarrassingly flat.
Lerner -- a fascinating man, telling an extraordinary story.
A film of remarkable honesty and courage.
One of the best date movies to come out in months.
Hubertus' deliberate flouting of any chronological order turns his film into an incoherent collection of conversations and images.
It strains for bittersweetness, but a heavy directorial hand (wielding a ladle of schmaltz) tends to overwhelm both the humor and the pathos.
Essential viewing not just for those fascinated by adventure, exploration and survival, but for anyone interested in the magic of leadership.
The story is a stirring vehicle for serious themes embodied by sharply drawn characters.
Strong supporting actors ... give performances that serve to make their co-stars or the material look worse.
A rather crude affair that feels like a student film.
Given the inherent interest of the subject, it's unfortunate that the people DuBowski profiles tend to be self-indulgent or otherwise unappealing.
Gruesome, loud, but unsatisfying haunted-house thriller.
An intermittently instructive and amusing jumble that might have been seen as daring and 'transgressive' in both form and content if it had been released, say, three decades ago.
The drollery isn't all that funny.
Quote not available.
movie_title: The Vertical Ray of the Sun (Mua he chieu thang dung) (2000)

movie_review_blurb: Elegant but cold and meandering homage to film noir.
Laughs are few and far between, and the film feels brutally long.
movie_title: Citizen Toxie: The Toxic Avenger IV (2000)

movie_review_blurb: This sci-fi/martial arts hybrid has the stale aura of a product assembled out of bits of other action movies.
You do get a sense of a German society that is still amazingly bureaucratic and authoritarian.
Remarkably faithful, consistently entertaining if overlong adapatation.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone (2001)

movie_review_blurb: One of those exercises in romantic whimsy that misses its mark: It's alternately sappy and uncomfortably harsh.
Quote not available.
The screenplay by James Eric, James Horton and director Peter O'Fallon ... is so pat it makes your teeth hurt.
One of those films that feel drunk on their own virtue.
Sometimes makes less sense than the Bruckheimeresque American action flicks it emulates.
Uneven, with long sections that are completely unfunny.
Given the trajectory of the plot of About a Boy, it's almost a miracle that this smart, painfully funny adaptation of the best-selling Nick Hornby novel never gives way to sentimentality.

Oscar Wilde's masterpiece, The Importance of Being Earnest, may be the best play of the 19th century. It's so good that its relentless, polished wit can withstand not only inept school productions, but even Oliver Parker's movie adaptation.
Dotted with the 'Oh, please!' moments of grotesque implausibility you get when cynical, shameless filmmakers ... feel contempt for their audience.
A surprisingly 'solid' achievement by director Malcolm D. Lee and writer John Ridley.
A lean, deftly shot, well-acted, weirdly retro thriller that recalls a raft of '60s and '70s European-set spy pictures.
This zillionth comedy about a guy who learns valuable lessons from his time as a woman is remarkably lacking in inspiration.
Wonderfully acted but underedited ensemble piece.
A wry comedy.
Read My Lips isn't just scary, charming and delightfully unpredictable - it's also smarter and subtler than any new movie out there.
Sexy but pretentious melodrama.
If you can swallow its absurdities and crudities Lagaan really is enormously good fun.
movie_title: Lagaan: Once Upon a Time in India (2001)

movie_review_blurb: [A] real pleasure in its laid-back way.
Worth watching for Dong Jie's performance -- and for the way it documents a culture in the throes of rapid change.
Uneven, self-conscious but often hilarious spoof.
No one but a convict guilty of some truly heinous crime should have to sit through The Master of Disguise.
Clever but slow.
Unfortunately, its efforts to pander to this pubescent demographic are often laughable.
Unlike most surf movies, Blue Crush thrillingly uses modern technology to take the viewer inside the wave. By the end you can't help but feel 'stoked.'
Staggers between flaccid satire and what is supposed to be madcap farce.
Davis ... gets vivid performances from her cast and pulls off some deft Ally McBeal-style fantasy sequences.
movie_title: Amy's O (Amy's Orgasm) (Why Love Doesn't Work) (2002)

movie_review_blurb: [Swimfan] falls victim to sloppy plotting, an insultingly unbelievable final act and a villainess who is too crazy to be interesting.
This oddly scrambled new version eventually falls apart so badly you feel embarrassed for the people who made it.
Compelling but self-undermining documentary.
It's almost impossible not to be moved by the movie's depiction of sacrifice and its stirring epilogue in post-Soviet Russia.
A charming, vibrant, if under-edited adaptation of V.S. Naipaul's genially cynical novel.
Well-shot but badly written tale set in a future ravaged by dragons.
Everything else that the filmmakers have done in their thoughtless, lazy way to 'improve' the original formula serves only to leach the drama and excitement out of the underlying story.
A surprisingly charming and even witty match for the best of Hollywood's comic-book adaptations.
Sappy, mechanical tripe.
Cherry Orchard is badly edited, often awkwardly directed and suffers from the addition of a wholly unnecessary pre-credit sequence designed to give some of the characters a 'back story.'
Exhilarating ensemble piece from India.
Often stirring, but crude and cliche-ridden.
It's quite an achievement to set and shoot a movie at the Cannes Film Festival and yet fail to capture its visual appeal or its atmosphere.
In the era of The Sopranos, it feels painfully redundant and inauthentic.
Almost everything about Ice Age proves to be disappointingly generic.
Sloppy, half-baked mess.

Director Alfonso Cuaron gets vivid, convincing performances from a fine cast, and generally keeps things going at a rapid pace, occasionally using an omniscient voice-over narrator in the manner of French New Wave films.
Not a movie but a live-action agitprop cartoon so shameless and coarse, it's almost funny.
Thanks to a superb performance by Isabelle Huppert, it's compulsively, gruesomely watchable.
Whatever the movie's sentimental, hypocritical lessons about sexism, its true colors come out in various wet T-shirt and shower scenes.
Unlike so many recent films set during WWII, it makes history exciting without dumbly distorting or misrepresenting it.
Even a hardened voyeur would require the patience of Job to get through this interminable, shapeless documentary about the swinging subculture.
Partly a schmaltzy, by-the-numbers romantic comedy, partly a shallow rumination on the emptiness of success -- and entirely soulless.
Feels like a joyless piece of exploitation, punctuated with embarrassing, witless dialogue.
OK, kid-friendly sci-fi.
Calling it pretentious doesn't do justice to the toxic faux-bohemianism and unearned self-regard that bubble and ooze out of every aspect of Chelsea Walls.
Initially gripping, eventually cloying POW drama.
Thin period piece.
An awkward hybrid of genres that just doesn't work.
Intelligent, well-acted, all-American version of the Shakespeare tragedy.
It's a shame that the storyline and its underlying themes ... finally seem so impersonal or even shallow.
A good-natured ensemble comedy that tries hard to make the most of a bumper cast, but never quite gets off the ground.
Pride And Prejudice And Zombies is patchy, but the laughs come with enough frequency and the cast is so game that this is a surprisingly entertaining and likeable comedy.
It's not just for fans, but it might make some new ones.

It's a very accomplished horror feature that doesn't sacrifice characters for cheap scares, and celebrates its excellent effects work with beautiful cinematography and a love and respect for its creatures.
Evolution is a stunning cinematic experience that is both beautiful and utterly engaging, and it will prompt further discussion and reward repeat viewing.
While it may not be for everyone, this could be the new addition to your annual seasonal viewing.
If you're a Miike fan or simply looking for something weird and wonderful then you certainly won't forget this in a hurry.

Gods Of Egypt looks beautiful, and is not without its weird charms, but the stodginess weighs down its silliness and makes it drag when it should soar. All in all, it's a missed opportunity in many ways.
Beautifully made, bone-chilling horror.
Crimson Peak is a stunning sensory experience.
This gruesome, scabrously funny and bold adaptation is most definitely worth taking a chance on.
It's a very handsomely made film, the performances are very good, and Palermo's understated vision is definitely intriguing. We just can't help wishing that there was a bit more to it.
The Forbidden Room is hard to explain but impossible to forget.
Fast, funny and fiendish.
Like Blue Ruin, Green Room is both unflashy and brilliantly constructed.
Requiring both patience and a cast-iron stomach, Bone Tomahawk is an acquired taste, but it stays with you long after it's over.
When it works, X-Men: Apocalypse is great fun. When it doesn't, it's dull and messy. The pros do outweigh the cons, but only just.
This is a potent and disturbing nightmare, with flawless performances and a rich imagination behind its grim façade.
It putters along through the story notes that you'd expect, but strong performances and direction make for a solid ghost story.
movie_title: The Other Side of the Door (2016)

movie_review_blurb: The much hyped anthology horror... ties five stories together as strangers running from their guilt collide on a stretch of desert highway that isn't all it appears to be. The linking is done brilliantly, especially between our two favourite segments.
Byrne has such a clear identity as a filmmaker that the story is immediately elevated. He finds the absurd and the mundane in the terrifying, and the horror in no way suffers from the dark humour.
It is intermittently rewarding, but ultimately a bit disappointing.
movie_title: Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Nichols has managed to combine that Spielbergian feel of something magical we'll never quite understand with a family story that is utterly involving and moving. This is something special.
Although there are some fun jolts and gruesome shocks to be had, Friend Request struggles to find anything new to say, feeling instead like something you'd half-remembered from a decade ago.

1987's Creepshow 2 never matches the heights of its predecessor, but those looking for more of the original's blend of throwback comic book chills and gory shocks should give this loving restoration from 88 Films a look.
This new vision is produced by Roth, but the stamp of approval isn't a guarantee of quality.
Cohen's performance is excellent, Alice is still a wonderful heroine, the visuals are stunning and there is a beating heart beneath the gloss. If you're tempted, why not take a trip?
A director's cut might run more smoothly and offer some of the characters time to actually develop, but what we've got for now is an ambitious disappointment with its heart in the right place.
It's a little slow, and self-consciously so, which viewers may find frustrating, but it's emotionally engaging, moving and beautifully performed, and a journey worth taking.
movie_title: Journey To The Shore (Kishibe No Tabi) (2015)

movie_review_blurb: although it's about ten minutes too long, The Last Days is a moving, often thrilling piece of end of the world cinema that has a little too much treacle.

Inevitably the jokes don't all land, and you may well be irritated by its sense of humour and revolted by what it has to offer, but if you're looking for a midnight movie that's genuinely strange, this is for you.
Anxiety-inducing and beautifully constructed, we highly recommend this intelligent, sensitive and powerful film.
You'll laugh, you'll cheer, you'll wince, you might even shed a tear. Simply put, Turbo Kid is awesome.
This odd, funny and surprisingly sweet horror romance is highly recommended.
The most important thing to know about What We Do In The Shadows is that it's laugh-out-loud hilarious and we urge you to see it as soon as possible.
movie_title: What We Do In The Shadows (2015)

movie_review_blurb: With a tremendous first half and more brains, heart and laughs than any of its promotional material indicated, this is smart, witty, thrilling and, above all, fun.
movie_title: Live Die Repeat: Edge of Tomorrow (2014)

movie_review_blurb: With strong performances and a surprising tenderness, Freaks more than deserves its towering reputation.
Fittingly, it's a theme park ride itself: bumpy, and at times worryingly poorly maintained, but you'll laugh and scream.
Hugely stylish and wonderfully witty, this is a darkly comic treat.
movie_title: A Girl Walks Home Alone at Night (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Tom Hardy is perfectly cast as the leather-sporting, crazy-eyed Road Warrior, but the reason why Mad Max: Fury Road feels so right is simple: It's Miller's world, and he's taking us back.
It stumbles in the final act due to the need for an ending, but The Falling is beautifully shot, wonderfully atmospheric and very powerful.
This is a confident sequel from Reeves and company; gripping, moving and recommended.
movie_title: Dawn Of The Planet Of The Apes (2014)

movie_review_blurb: As a chilly tale of a young woman striving to escape her family and her claustrophobic small town, it succeeds on its own merits.
It's self-aware and funny, and packed with veterans who are all having a good time.

By rooting its clever narrative structure in a tragic story, Flanagan has created a horror that pulls on the heartstrings as often as it grabs you by the throat... Nail-biting, mind-bending and very, very scary, Oculus is a must-see.
This debut feature from TV veteran Jeremy Lovering (Sherlock) has a familiar premise, but uses it to create a good deal of tension and, indeed, fear.
Honeymoon is chilling, it will make your skin crawl, and it will stay with you for days. Seek it out.
It's certainly not a great film, but it's definitely an Independence Day sequel. For all its many, many flaws, that's kind of fun.
Pearce seethes with searing, desperate energy that's beautifully matched by Pattinson's mumbling, cautious attempts at optimism.
Dark Summer is worth taking a chance on.
Writer-director Abner Pastoll delivers an accomplished, tense and unpredictable thriller that makes the most of a strong cast.
Kick-Ass 2 delivers a lot of laughs, the performances are still good, and it's certainly ambitious. But it's also decidedly hit and miss.
It's supposed to be upsetting, and it is, but that doesn't make it any more watchable.
Funny, smart and sweet, with a great character at its centre, Night Of The Living Deb is a rom-zom-com that we can heartily recommend.
They Look Like People wouldn't be nearly as effective if the relationship at its core wasn't so involving and affecting.
By treating a bizarre, ridiculous situation with determined realism, the Blaines have created something that is both otherworldly and somehow relatable.
Sudden sharp shocks are contrasted with beautiful cinematography, moments of giddy freedom are followed by severe punishment, and it's decidedly powerful stuff.
We'd recommend knowing as little about it as possible, but we'll open by saying that it's funny, it's puzzling, and it's utterly beguiling.
Pod may not break the rules of the cabin in the woods genre completely, but it's a smart, gripping chiller that delivers. Seek it out.

One of the most exciting things about Guardians Of The Galaxy is that it is a departure from the Marvel feature film template. Guardians Of The Galaxy is very much a Marvel movie, but it's also (way) out there, doing its own thing.
Geoghegan's debut is a stylish, assured and highly entertaining horror throwback.
It's affecting, it's thoughtful, it's often gripping and it is different. Despite its faults, if you're wearying of comic book movie homogeneity, this is worth taking a chance on.
There's an energy to Knock Knock's single location thrills that propels it through some of its missteps to make for an entertaining, if inconsistent, skin-crawler.

First-time writer-director Johnstone's ingenious script consistently wrong-foots the audience and shifts from one subgenre to another without ever once losing its grip on the comedic elements. It's creepy, tense and scary.
There are times when Maggie should cut a little deeper or be a little bleaker, but this is an impressive, understated and moving take on the zombie-movie sub-genre.
There are plenty of jump scares which might satisfy the Friday night crowd, but if you're a genre fan looking for a pleasant surprise, you won't find one here.
With a good sense of humour, strong action set pieces and Hiddleston and Hemsworth on top form, it's just great fun.
This may not be as scary or cohesive as its predecessor, but the kill films retain their power to shock and Ransone and Sossamon make for a very watchable lead pairing.

Alex Ross Perry has been hailed as one of American independent cinema's most exciting auteurs, and hot on the heels of his brilliantly bleak comedy, Listen Up Philip, comes this searing homage to the psychological horrors of Roman Polanski.

We didn't think anything was going to get us excited about a sequel to 2014's crushingly routine Blumhouse horror Ouija, but we didn't reckon on the addition of director Mike Flanagan and writer Jeff Howard.
This is really quite wonderful.
Ghost In The Shell certainly isn't dire, but it is dull.
There are some problems, but this is an intelligent, unpredictable and very well-made horror mystery that subverts the expected genre clichés and really does get under your skin.
Although Gavin makes us wait for the horror elements, they are highly effective once they arrive.
It's savage but heartfelt, gruesome but wickedly funny, and as Justine is forced to find her own way through this nightmare, it's moving too. This is essential viewing.
As grisly entertainment, it works, and it does have a mean bite, but it doesn't quite live up to its potential.

It's a well-made, well-acted monster movie with some interesting ideas that should hold up to repeat viewings, and while its uneven second half stops it from being a complete success, it's a lot of horrible fun.
It's a simple and profound story that is both intimate and universal. This is a beautiful film that must be seen.
Phenomena may not be as consistent as Argento's masterpieces but it's frequently fantastic and deserves a reappraisal.
It's the mix that so many other low-budget schlock-hound filmmakers have gone for, but so few make it work. It's imperfect, tasteless, but hugely watchable.
There are one or two fun moments, particularly when Boutella gets to cut loose, but she's a monster in dire need of more screentime and a much better film.
This is a brilliant technical achievement but it's more than that. It's a potent, political and moving work of SF with a stunning performance from Andy Serkis.
movie_title: War for the Planet of the Apes (2017)

movie_review_blurb: The film's wilful ambiguity will doubtless prove frustrating for many, but this is a truly nightmarish tale, as real people in a terrible situation make snap decisions that lead to devastating consequences. It's gripping, terrifying, and heartbreaking.
The Ghoul proves to be a dark, atmospheric and surprisingly moving portrayal of a crumbling psyche.
It's well-directed, it's well-acted, and it's genuinely creepy while offering some great jump scares too.
It's a little inaccessible, perhaps, with long sequences of reflective silence, but A Ghost Story has a real emotional power that is sincerely haunting.
It's a truly rare thing to come out of a summer blockbuster wishing it were longer, but in its rush to get down to the bare essentials, The Dark Tower loses too much of what makes it unique.
Whether you guess the identity of the Golem or not, this is a richly rewarding riff on penny dreadful horrors with a real wit and bite to it, and it's a wonderfully chilling treat.
Mom And Dad never quite crosses a line but it definitely enjoys getting close to it.
That verdant blend of Giger and Carpenter is fantastic, but what will really stay with you is the effect all this has on the characters.
It is a satisfying thriller but, for the most part, Mohawk wants to show us the hopelessness and cruelty of this conflict and this sorry chapter of American history.
Horror fans have seen all of this before, and they've seen it done better.

It's a little overlong, and a lot of viewers may find themselves feeling a little queasy for several reasons, but this is a powerful cinematic experience that Refn fans should absolutely treat themselves to.

Bright wants to say something about racial prejudice and it wants to be a badass R-rated genre movie. Those good intentions are evident but the end result is a two hour-long, tedious, uninspired slog.
The Void is a creepy, tense and gory tribute to the horror master [Lovecraft] that offers invention and wit beyond mere homage, and we recommend it.
The emotional pay-offs are huge, the visuals are stunning, the performances are brilliant and, even as it eagerly explores the darkness, The Last Jedi never loses sight of its heart.
It's so exciting to see a film with such a firm grip on its audience's collective throat.
There's a sense of laying the groundwork, with new characters to be introduced, new attitudes to establish, and a new team to bring to life. On those three counts, the film gets the job done.

If you think you know what you're getting with Geostorm, well, you're probably right. It's big, it's stupid, it's got people outrunning enormous weather events, and it's bad in most of the ways that matter.
While there is a myriad of issues to pick apart, the most disappointing is that there is simply no atmosphere.
Blade Runner 2049 is excellent. Hampton Fancher and Michael Green's script continues to push the themes and questions of the original and finds a new angle from which to do so.
IT is pure popcorn horror: crowdpleasing, gruesome and guaranteed to make you jump. It just may not crawl under your skin like you want it to.
The final act stumbles once or twice, but it's engaging, tense, the conclusion is earned and affecting, and [Jasmine] Hyde's superb performance carries it through any wobbles.
Although it doesn't reach the heights of Edwards' Godzilla, Kong: Skull Island works hard to bring us something new, and it does deliver some pretty impressive punches.
Creating a convincing romance between a woman and a fishman is probably the film's biggest challenge, but sensitive performances ... make it not just believable but compelling.
Jackman taps into the darkest elements of the character but never loses the humanity, and if this is his last outing, he's gone out with a perfect, heart-breaking portrayal full of rage and grief.
[An] overripe, overblown, gorgeous oddity.
Men & Chicken is strange and often dark, but it's weirdly sweet, too, not to mention very funny. If you like The League Of Gentlemen then you're going to want to catch this.

With some great practical effects and some strong gory surprises, there are things to like her, but ultimately Bed Of The Dead doesn't quite come together. Still, we're definitely interested in seeing what Maher does next.
This is a very promising debut.
This is another superb film from Na Hong-jin.

The deliberate pacing will put some viewers off (even though it's less than 80 minutes), and some may complain that it's a little hollow, but as a cinematic experience, this is truly impressive, and it will stay with you.
A powerful, thoughtful and moving work of science-fiction that engages the head and the heart.
Part Gothic horror, part body horror and part social commentary, Shelley is an atmospheric and thoughtful chiller with real power.
This is a strong, well-acted debut that treats its oddball lead with respect and sensitivity, and we're excited to see what Borowiec and Marine do next.
The Inerasable is clever, gripping and very scary, a ghost story that will engage genre fans intellectually while sending a shiver down their spine. Seek it out.
movie_title: The Inerasable (Zan'e: Sunde wa ikenai heya) (2015)

movie_review_blurb: While reports of reshoots and studio interference are as prevalent in blockbuster cinema as superheroes, there's a jarring mash of tones and clumsy editing that suggests that someone felt that something wasn't quite right on Suicide Squad.
There are elements that don't really work and even at 81 minutes it starts to push its welcome a little, but there's no denying Parasites' raw power. This is fierce stuff.

The appeal of La Rage Du Demon may be somewhat limited, and at times it does feel a little like an exercise, but it's as much a celebration as it is a sleight of hand, and an engrossing and entertaining one at that.
movie_title: Fury of the Demon (La Rage du Démon) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: It's always impressive when a film manages to truly immerse the viewer in the world it's presenting. In the case of We Are The Flesh, which played at Fantasia Film Festival, it's not necessarily a pleasant experience, but good lord, it is powerful.
movie_title: We Are the Flesh (Tenemos la carne) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: It's just a shame that the dialogue and plotting can't match the message and the jolts of well-executed genre thrills. It's bold and kind of fun, but this is a step down from Anarchy.
The Unseen may take its time, but it's definitely worth it. It delivers a new approach to a classic story with an unexpected emotional impact that lingers, and it is well worth seeking out.

With enough narrative complexity, homages to vintage science fiction and sheer entertainment to justify repeat viewings, The Similars is an absolute treat for genre fans and we highly recommend that you hunt it down as soon as possible.
It's not without its weird charms, but those moments are few and far between, and for the most part it's gloomy and plodding.

The B-movie thrills on offer here are solid. The action, the fights, the jump scares...they're all entertaining, and there's a long-serving genre heroine who's finally allowed some evolution and a bit of closure.
This is Lowe's showcase. She gives a predictably excellent central performance, and it's exciting to see a film that's this confident, bold and entertaining.
To call it a disaster would be unfair as there is some spooky, cheesy fun to be had, but the plotting is somehow both slow and rushed, the writing is poor, and the performances aren't great.
It's a difficult film to love then, but it is beautifully made and boasts a superb central performance. There are wonderful chills to be found in the chilliness.
movie_title: I Am the Pretty Thing That Lives in the House (2016)

movie_review_blurb: The pacing and subject matter may alienate some viewers, but this is the kind of film that deserves to find a cult audience. It's a chilling, surprising and sensitive horror that you won't forget in a hurry.
movie_title: I Am Not a Serial Killer (2016)

movie_review_blurb: It's far too long at 102 minutes, it doesn't follow through on any of its interesting ideas, it's never scary and, most unforgivably, it's boring. You can skip this one.
Rest assured, Jennifer Kent's debut more than lives up to the hype.
It's hard to describe it as a success, but this is a laudable attempt at something unusual. We recommend approaching with caution, but hope that this beautifully made oddity finds its admirers.
Even though it's roaring its message in your face, it's a message that is undeniably important, incredibly moving and honestly delivered.
This is superb horror with got modern classic written all over it.
This is an excellent horror that is gripping, scary, witty and timely, and it's got something to say. Even if you don't think all of it comes off, you will be talking about it.
Blair Witch isn't going to change the landscape of horror, but it's a worthy successor to a true classic.
Moving, intelligent and frightening, this will grip you by the throat.
movie_title: The Girl With All the Gifts (2017)

movie_review_blurb: This is an easy film to like. It's just a shame that it merits such an ordinary sentiment as 'likeable'.
movie_title: Miss Peregrine's Home for Peculiar Children (2016)

movie_review_blurb: An emotionally satisfying and brilliantly played take on the ups and (mostly) downs of a group of less-than-typical female friends.
movie_title: Todo sobre mi madre (All About My Mother) (1999)

movie_review_blurb: Pic has more in common with standard child/parent conflict dramas than it would probably care to admit, but its sensitive treatment of an equally sensitive theme elevates it into something memorable.
A leisurely but rewardingly intense dual narrative that delicately unpicks the secret lives of women.
An airy, ultra-Gallic delight whose apparent weightlessness is anchored by real substance.
movie_title: En la Ciudad de Sylvia (In the City of Sylvia) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Period detail is lovingly rendered (it's a nice touch to have people smoking in the cinema), while the technology is wonderfully '60s.
The result remains firmly theatrical, despite helmer's best efforts, but its deftness of touch and sheer humanity make it surprisingly accessible fare.
The latest in a line of effective, low-budget genre items out of Spain, Nacho Vigalondo's feature debut shows that good cinematic time travelers can be done on a shoestring with the right script.
An involving love story between two emotionally damaged outsiders.
A polished but verbose whodunit that's surprisingly buttoned-down given helmer Alex de la Inglesia's rep for comicbook wackiness.
A tardy romance between two aging lovebirds, Elsa & Fred is predictable fare that only occasionally fulfils its intention of being simultaneously heartbreaking and heartening.
Illuminated by Fire is a watchable if none-too-penetrating analysis of the traumatizing effects of a war largely forgotten.
movie_title: Blessed by Fire (Iluminados por el fuego) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Dramatically wobbly and sometimes unconvincing, this potent and disturbing item still exerts a powerful pull, particularly in its later stages.
The pic's thrills remain consecutive rather than cumulative, and fail to resonate.
Held together by the extraordinary force of Almodovar's cinematic personality.
Noisy and excessive where the original was hushed and restrained, and wholly devoid of mystique...
A deeply rewarding throwback to the unself-conscious days when cinema still strove to be magical.
movie_title: The Secret in Their Eyes (El Secreto de Sus Ojos) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: A powerful, richly layered indictment of the plight of Latin America's dispossessed that cunningly parallels the Spanish conquest of the Americas with the 20th-century spread of capitalism, Iciar Bollain's fifth feature is her most ambitious and best.
Film noir and contempo Spain make a near-perfect match in the explosive No Rest for the Wicked.
Though it slickly offers up drama, black comedy and enjoyable perfs in due measure, the pic never develops much bite, though it does bare its fangs.
movie_title: La chispa de la vida (As Luck Would Have It) (2013)

movie_review_blurb: A perceptive, ultra-wordy stab at catching the zeitgeist at a time of change in Spain, David Trueba's two-hander nonetheless feels like a working-out of social and personal themes that hasn't quite achieved the full leap from page to film.
A quietly devastating exploration of the cruel paradox that, in order to feed their loved ones, emigrants have to leave them behind.
A hugely entertaining, feelgood celebration of human sexuality that unfolds as a cathartic experience for characters, auds and helmer alike.

An exquisitely crafted miniature about the creative rebirth of an aging sculptor, Fernando Trueba's The Artist and the Model brings the same craft and care to its subject as its titular artist does to his own work.
movie_title: El artista y la modelo (The Artist and the Model) (2013)

movie_review_blurb: The subject of old age gets the kind of attention it deserves but is too rarely afforded in the affecting Wrinkles.

Overall treatment is flat, with nobody speaking above a mutter. Helmer Felipe Vega has previously shown he can transmit subtle dramatic registers, but his desire to convey emotional truths mostly sacrifices any sense of drama.
Though it fails in its final reels to capitalize on its early promise, pic is still stylish, accomplished and tremendously enjoyable fare.
movie_title: The Devil's Backbone (El Espinazo del diablo) (2001)

movie_review_blurb: A deceptively simple and lyrical labor of love about freedom, passion and loss.
Sud Express is a heartwarming and thought-provoking item.
A technically classy mood piece that ultimately falls victim to stylistic excesses.
movie_title: Summer Rain (El camino de los ingleses) (2006)

movie_review_blurb: A slick and mostly rewarding mystery whose action is divided up between the outer and inner worlds.
Superbly orchestrated, visually impressive pic.
Though pic boasts decent perfs, potent atmospherics and eye-catching visuals, both psychology and plot are bargain-basement.
Absorbing and almost unbearably poignant.
movie_title: The Sea Inside (Mar Adentro) (The Sea Within) (2004)

movie_review_blurb: This first Spanish feature helmed by two women sidesteps the over-earnestness or high camp that hallmark so much gay-themed Hispanic cinema, and also provides the best showcase so far for actress-to-watch Leonor Watling.
movie_title: My Mother Likes Women (A mi madre le gustan las mujeres) (2002)

movie_review_blurb: A general lack of drama, a low-budget docu feel and an ultraslim storyline are more than compensated for by a sterling script and perfs.
Somewhat wacky tale, based on real events, is kept anchored in reality through attention to detail and by first-rate central perfs.
Roberto Santiago's sophomore laffer The Longest Penalty in the World has a nice concept but a weak script.
A distinctive, sharp-witted and good-looking period comedy.
The stellar cast can do little to paper over the cracks in an awkward, unevenly-paced script that is composed of a series of sometimes-attractive scenes with little emotional undertow.
movie_title: The Bridge of San Luis Rey (2005)

movie_review_blurb: This majestic film has all the hallmarks of Beeb quality workmanship.
A mesmerizing and evocative experience for protagonist and viewer alike.
A high-energy rags-to-riches satire about a deranged New York paparazzo and a wannabe thesp, Delirious is hilarious.
Virgins should snuggle up in plenty of fest beds, with arthouse interest a certainty in Spain-friendly territories.
Handles the subject of domestic violence with intelligence and compassion.
movie_title: Te doy mis ojos (Take My Eyes) (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Richly evocative.
A slick, derivative, too-obvious psychodrama with a superficially stylish air that's too thin to conceal its lack of substance.
Sarah Polley gives a wonderfully searching performance, as a woman in a state of extreme isolation.
Queens is distinguished from a hundred other slick screwballers only by virtue of its theme -- the first mass gay wedding in Spain. Otherwise, it's middle-of-the-road formula fare all the way.
Fernando Leon de Aranoa confirms his Loach-like ability to convert marginalized subjects into socially committed cinema.
Its visual flair and some good perfs by well-known contempo Spanish actors cannot redeem an over-episodic, over-busy script with little dramatic undertow.
A decent cast and ok production values get completely lost in The Backwoods, an atmosphere-rich psychological thriller in which psychology and thrills are missing.
Refreshingly unconventional pic tackles its taboos with compassion, grace and wit.
movie_title: The Art of Crying (Kunsten at græde i kor) (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Showing a stylistic bravura and confidence rare among upcoming Spanish helmers, Ramon Salazar's campy 20 Centimeters is a self-regarding but vastly entertaining sophomore effort.
Ambitious script is stranded between entertainment and intellectualism, leaving us with a magnificent folly, thoroughly watchable for its visuals but ultimately hollow.
A deft, witty and emotionally rewarding study of a thirtysomething man in his roles as father and son.
Combines a deftly-turned script, fine perfs and a feel-good message to mostly delightful effect.
Alex de la Iglesia has experimented with various genres down the years, but the shamelessly crowd-pleasing Witching and Bitching is a return to what he does best -- pure mayhem.

[Antonio Mendez] Esparza has done terrific work with his cast of non-pros, and several exchanges - particularly those between Regina and Robert - drip with an engaging realism that can only have been the result of guided improvisation.
movie_title: Life and Nothing More (La Vida y Nada Más) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: The overwrought, uncontrolled sci-fi thriller Automata is a disappointing example of a film that lacks the imagination to follow persuasively through on its engaging initial premise.

Queen is the sort of project which marketing teams like to talk about as "classic" while secretly knowing that it's just old-fashioned.
movie_title: The Queen of Spain (La reina de España) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: A brightly colored, eye-catching dark comedy that's inevitably hit-or-miss but never, ever dull ...
Anita Rocha da Silveira's debut is free of most of the moral nuances that might make it interesting to an adult viewer.
Aided by some great child performances, plenty of stylistic chutzpah and a strong sense of place, [Plaza] makes it work, despite the project's overall lack of finesse.
A compassionate, critical study of teenage loneliness.
A high-risk shot at a screen adaptation of a novel within a novel, The Motive is entertaining and buzzes with fun ideas, but as an involving drama, it never gets past the first chapter.
A punchy and entirely unsentimental study of a few days in the life of a young Buenos Aires sex worker that's as defiantly non-miserabilist as its heroine.
Simmering with controlled bitterness, Jesus has an intensity and rawness that more than make up for its flaws.
A carefully assembled, perceptive slow-burner.
This is one comedy that deserves to resonate beyond its country of origin.
movie_title: Another Story of the World (Otra historia del mundo) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Although it's entertaining and lively enough, Gold Seekers does lose out by not feeling as focused or as rooted.

Although it's enjoyable to make the acquaintance of the well-played, crowd-pleasing Strangers, the encounter is quickly forgotten.
A deft balance of the pessimistic and the playful
A celebration of the life of an extraordinary woman with whom most viewers will probably also have fallen in love by the time the credits roll.
movie_title: Lots of Kids, a Monkey and a Castle (Muchos hijos, un mono y un castillo) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: A quiet, touching film about unrewarded heroism in adverse conditions, shot through with an attractive mix of celebration and melancholy.

A heightened, cartoonishly violent tale of fatherly retribution that's totally implausible but nonetheless fun.
